<p>Often overlooked (and sadly so, because we are far to easily giving it up nowadays) is that Google Now requires me to surrender my entire habits and life to Google, to be leveraged for other purposes. Siri requires me only to ask a question. Yes, Now is potentially great, but only if you&#8217;re willing to be wholly locked in for it. Also, if things like targeted ads, &#8220;suggested people&#8221; on G+, and similar algorithmic things through Google, FB, whatever that claim to be able to deduce relevant things to your interests and needs are any indication, it will quickly become more work to curate than it&#8217;s usefulness provides (and most people probably won&#8217;t notice). I will always know better what I want and am looking for than any algorithm will be able to deduce. I&#8217;m uncommonly idealistic in my views of what technology should do for us, and at what cost to our own personal value.</p>

<p>Mate, you failed to understand one thing: if you decided to take advantage of either of these two technology, you will be tracked up anyways. If you hire a personal assistant, you will still need to tell her your work, your life and habit. For this case, instead of telling everything to a real person, you just tell to Google. <p>The difference between Google Now and Siri is one requires you to ask every single time, and the other one has the info ready for you already without you even openning your mouth.</p>

<p>Two things to remember -</p>
<p>First &#8211; Google&#8217;s back-end is second to none &#8211; they already deal with millions of users all the time in search and scale beautifully.</p>
<p>Second &#8211; Google&#8217;s voice recognition has been shrunk and can fit on the device &#8211; thus will likely fall to sending voice data to the cloud only when it fails locally.</p>
<p>Siri is a 3rd party acquisition that Apple has done very nice things with &#8211; but they do not have the back-end information that Google already has and they do not have the voice recognition expertise in-house that Google has &#8211; Nuance I believe still handles a lot of the voice stuff for Apple.</p>
<p>Google&#8217;s voice, according to my understanding (and I might be wrong here) &#8211;  was developed in-house and was available in Android before Siri.</p>
<p>Siri is basically something that combines stuff from multiple vendors &#8211; Nuance, Wolfram, Google, Yelp and the like &#8211; and puts a shiny wrapper around it. It is a lot less integrated than what Google has &#8211; and all you need to do is look at a classic PC vendor that buys the CPU from a vendor, the OS from another, the memory from another etc&#8230; and assembles it all together to understand that there are real limits to how much you can push these together.</p>
<p>Apple will have to bring an awful lot of these pieces in-house to really keep up with Google as time goes on, one suspects.</p>
<p>Regarding your &#8220;win for the consumer&#8221; remark &#8212; I whole-heartedly agreed.  I was annoyed with Apple thinking they were &#8220;years ahead&#8221; with the Siri technology because it made me think that they would drag their feet with updates.  Indeed there were things the old Siri app could do that iPhone 4S Siri can only do in iOS 6 (e.g.: book a table, pull up movie times).  The old Siri app could even buy you movie tickets which I did not see in Apple&#8217;s iOS 6 demonstration (perhaps the partner for movie ticket purchases is still under negotiation).</p>
<p>I love that Google is taking on Apple on this front because it will light a fire under Apple to improve the performance (especially by moving some of the processing from the server to the device &#8212; at least I hope).</p>
<p>Nothing like having an iPhone 3GS that could voice-dial without a data network and an iPhone 4S that cannot with Siri turned on.  Worst scenario is when I get in the car from home and need to call somebody as I am driving away.  The iPhone 4S is still on WiFi because I am in my garage or driveway, but if I attempt to use Siri, it will lose the WiFi signal before it completes and Siri will tell me to try again.  I have to wait until I see the cellular network activate to try again because it no longer processes &#8220;Call Dave&#8221; on the device.  It should handle things like &#8220;Call [Name]&#8221; or &#8220;Call My Wife&#8221; or &#8220;Call My Brother&#8221; or &#8220;Call Home&#8221; without the server (I do like that Siri knows how contacts are related to me).</p>
<p>My other gripe with iOS 5 was along the same lines.  While I use and love WiFi sync to iTunes, when I place the iPhone in my car cradle and start the car it begins charging.  It then tries to sync with iTunes because it is still on WiFi, but in a matter of seconds it will no longer be on WiFi and the sync will fail.  iOS recovers nicely from this, but I wish I could tell it to wait until it is sitting on the charger with WiFi for a full minute before initiating an iTunes sync.</p>

<p>As an iOS user, I have said it before, and I will say it again.  Siri&#8217;s biggest problem (actually a regression from the old voice control) is that it ALWAYS uses the server to figure out what you have said.  This adds a lag time in between question and response that is sometimes annoying.</p>
<p>Setting reminders, timers, and managing calendar is great with Siri.  Asking natural language questions is hit or miss.  Dieter&#8217;s review highlights some of the advantages and disadvantages to Google&#8217;s solution.  To me the biggest advantage is the local handling of voice interpretation regarding speed.  Apple needs to add this back into their voice control solution because it just makes things snappier.  This issue may diminish as Apple builds out more data centers and starts shipping LTE devices which have less latency, but there is something to be said for on-device voice interpretation.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m pretty sure the only on device interpretation in Jelly Bean is dictation, not anything in Now</p>
<p>I think Google Now is also contacting the server as its offline voice recognition is not nearly as accurate as its remote recognition.  Would be nice to find out. Perhaps they&#8217;re using a hybrid solution, but my bet would be that it&#8217;s all server based.</p>
<p>If that&#8217;s the case then the speed difference is likely attributable to:</p>
<p>1) Apple&#8217;s needs to quickly beef up their cloud presence to increase response time.  They are slowly doing this with new data centers planned in Oregon and Reno, Nevada.  All I can say is &#8220;more&#8221; &#8212; no better way to spend that $100B in cash.</p>
<p>2) Galaxy Nexus has low-latency 4G LTE and iPhone 4S does not, meaning that server round-trip is much faster on the Galaxy Nexus.  Though putting both on WiFi should create a level playing field.</p>
<p>Speed difference is also attributable to Siri&#8217;s reluctance to search the web since they don&#8217;t contract to have a directly integrated web search &#8212; they instead launch Safari.  From a user perspective, having Google as a provider just as Wolfram Alpha or Yelp would make the most sense.  Google is just really good and fast at search &#8212; there has never been any denying of that.</p>

<p>I don&#8217;t get it. So Siri never searches on Google?</p>
<p>Unless you say &#8220;Search the Web for XYZ&#8221;, Siri will only search the Web as a last resort.  It first tries Yelp!, Wolfram Alpha, and a few other sources depending on your query.  Sources could be &#8220;Find my Friends&#8221; if you ask &#8220;Where is My Wife?&#8221; or it could be your calendar or your SMS messages or your email.  If Siri can&#8217;t find what you need it will ask you &#8220;Do you want me to search the Web for XYZ?&#8221;  When Siri searches the Web there is no pretty card for the response &#8212; it just launches Safari with whatever default search engine you have configured and inputs your query in the search box and executes it.</p>
<p>So if your intent is to search the Web, Siri is slower because it has to launch Safari and you have to specifically tell it to &#8220;search the web&#8221; unless you want to answer Siri&#8217;s follow-up question.</p>
<p>If Siri had specially designed cards that were fed by Google, Bing and Yahoo (similar to Wolfram Alpha and Yelp!) then Siri would be faster and more seamless at searching the Web.  The three potential Web search engines on iOS are Google, Yahoo and Bing (you configure your favorite in settings, but default is Google since Google paid for that right).</p>

<p>Perception bias<br />

just look at the completely different anecdotal posts all over this thread</p>
<p>My experience is that its a different lag between iOS and Android.  iOS stalls at times when you are launching an app or first unlocking the phone.  Android tends to lag when something is being animated and something else wants to be processed in the background.</p>
<p>In iOS the UI rendering takes precedence, but when something has to load or the device has to be brought back from sleep there can be a noticeable stall.  My experience is that most iOS lags are on the lock screen.  Sometimes I go to slide a lock-screen notification and nothing happens because the UI is not ready for me yet (still waking up from sleep).  Same goes with the standard slide-to-unlock bar on my iPhone 4S.  Once the wakeup occurs, things are typically smooth since UI rendering tends to successfully override anything else I am doing 99.9% of the time.</p>
<p>Android&#8217;s project butter sounds like it was about figuring out which background processing were overriding UI rendering and fixing that.  iOS has had that sort of optimization since inception.  iOS struggles more as it tries to fight between putting things to sleep to conserve battery life and making them be instantly available &#8212; unloading an app means having to reload it to use it again.  Android typically sacrifices some of the battery life to keep things always running and ready to go.  Keeping things running and ready to go can also expose you to third-party app bugs that could crash things unexpectedly.  Shutting down a third-party app limits its ability to crash in the background and screw something else up.  There are trade offs to each, just like their are trade offs between buying a Porsche and a Ferrari &#8212; either way you still get a great car (or gadget) in the end.</p>
<p>Well said. While I dont have lag on my iphone i am developing iphone apps and so I am acutely aware of all the tricks one needs to employ to get a non-laggy app. The thing that ios nails is the drawing pipeline, and that was awesome from day one &#8211; opengl rendering all the way, and it shows.</p>
<p>Project butter is the reason i am going to consider android devices again going forward. Tried a few brand new Samsung top end models in the mall and the stuttering is both obvious and unacceptable. Only the SGS 3 seemed a little better. I know theres no reason hardware side for this to happen, its all software. With Butter Google has actually got some people with game experience on board, people who understand and care about FPS. Cool!!</p>

<p>As an aside for why that happens &#8211; iOS will stop loading the webpage while you scroll (touch takes precedence), whereas Android continues to render it (touch is equal). Not necessarily better or worse, but that&#8217;s probably what you&#8217;re seeing.</p>

<p>Here are some of the improvements:-</p>
<p>The UI looks more fluid and rich.<br />
Better support for bi-directional languages.<br />
The new notifications look awesome.</p>
<p>The Direct Wifi service discovery feature allows peer to peer connections. This will give a boost to various mobile connected devices. You may connect your Wifi camera directly with your phone and upload pictures. Data available from a multitude of phone inputs like GPS, compass, NFC etc can be shared easily across devices.</p>
<p>Another important feature for the developers is App encryption. Many paid apps are distributed freely and developers loose a lot of money. App encryption will ensure that at least 10 year olds don&#8217;t hack their devices and give away apps for free.</p>
<p>Android Jelly Bean brings support for Television screen. Android is being used on set top boxes as an OS for TV. But the OS wasn&#8217;t supporting non touch input devices until now. The new support for television screen will help developers in optimising their apps for television screen.</p>

<p>So, please, tell me what the downside would be to Google taking a more active approach in the future of the platform? <p>This has nothing to do with which OS is better. I happen to disagree with you re iOS vs Android but that&#8217;s not the point (and besides, I think it&#8217;s more a matter of personal preference).</p>
<p>The point is, in the words of Steve Ballmer, &#8220;developers developers developers&#8221;. I&#8217;m willing to accept that the Android ecosystem offers users more choice in the way of devices and OSes but the current fragmentation isn&#8217;t benefiting anyone and in the long run is going to hurt users (it actually already is).</p>
<p>Why? Because trying to develop for all the devices and OSes out there in the wild is near impossible. The average  TTM for an Android app vs the same app on iOS is much much larger and the quality will usually be lower because you have to appeal to the lowest common denominator in order to support the most devices. Add to that the monetization problems on Android (users are far less willing to pay for content and even consume less free content than iOS users) and for many developers except perhaps vey large and wealthy companies &#8211; the ROI for developing for Android simply isn&#8217;t worth it. Despite the larger market share, most of us would rather invest our resources into improving our iOS version.</p>
<p>The future of mobile is no longer about one OS or another &#8211; it&#8217;s about content and services. Android needs these just as much as iOS otherwise its users will bail. And in order to get them it needs developers on board who are receiving worthwhile compensation for their efforts. Currenty that&#8217;s not the case, at least compared to iOS.</p>
<p>To claim that users shouldn&#8217;t complain if they didn&#8217;t buy a Google phone or that this isn&#8217;t even Google&#8217;s concern is condescending and missing the point entirely. Most consumers have never even heard of Froyo, Gingerbread, ICS or Jellybean. Many (esp. Samsung users) don&#8217;t even know what Android is. All they know is that they bought a cool touch-thingy-phone that someone (probably their carrier) recommended to them but for some reason Temple Run crashes every time they launch it. Do you really think the best way to fix this is to simply berate them for being &#8220;dumb&#8221; and not buying a Nexus? I can&#8217;t see how making it their fault will win back their love.</p>
<p>Google can claim that upgrades aren&#8217;t their responsibility but that&#8217;s just burying their heads in the sand. It&#8217;s definitely their concern and I&#8217;m sure they think about it a lot &#8211; because if this fragmentation continues and spirals out of control, users and developers will either  abandon Android or it&#8217;ll simply split into incompatible flavours maintained separately by each OEM. I doubt that&#8217;s a future they want to see (which is maybe why they bought Motorola&#8230;).</p>
<p>Good points except&#8230;</p>
<p>I travel quite a bit around the US for work. I also have deep connections in open source communities going back to the early 90&#8217;s. I don&#8217;t  know many developers who don&#8217;t universally agree that the biggest issue is not the monetization of apps on iOS or Google Play, but how to get noticed in a sea of 600,000+ apps &amp; growing daily. Apples curation efforts miss just as many good apps as Google&#8217;s open ended approach so it&#8217;s not exclusive. You cannot simply make  a decent app then release to Apple or Google &amp; suddenly see big money flowing in the bank acct. It takes time to get noticed, if you are lucky (most good to great indie developers are expert self promoters) &amp; even more time to get paid a livable wage for your efforts. The reality is app deveolpemnt for most, my best guess is 95% of all developers in these app ecosystems, is that they fail or it&#8217;s a very liited part time income.</p>
<p> Like it or not there is a reason the big software publishers are still around &amp; not going away anytime soon.  And this coming from somebody who used to be heavily involved in the old BBS days with a profiatble board &amp; wrote lots of shareware. Distribution, regerdless of the Android-iOS-Windows build on the phone being used isn&#8217;t so much the issue as getting noticed is. Otherwise the besy app ever is just floating aimlessly at sea in the respective app store.</p>

<p>You&#8217;re missing the point. Google doesn&#8217;t control what the device manufacturers/carriers do with each device that makes it to market, except for the Nexus devices.</p>
<p>Each hardware manufacturer is beholden to the carriers. If Verizon decides not to pick up a particular HTC device, it&#8217;s a loss of hundreds of millions of dollars for HTC. Android is open source, so many hardware manufacturers use it to base their software on, but in the end they have to cater to whatever the carriers demand. It&#8217;s been noted several times that carriers demand differentiation &#8211; which you and I read as fragmentation. Unfortunately, that&#8217;s what sells phones in the retail stores.</p>
<p>Google has tried using every carrot it can to practice more control because it doesn&#8217;t have a stick to make everyone fall in line. Google&#8217;s only recourse it to keep putting out devices that set the gold standard and hope the market reacts by demanding equal or better from rival devices.</p>

<p>You can&#8217;t possibly say that though with any sort of actual information beyond your personal dedication to all things Google.<br />
You saw a few basic, command like voice searches on stage.<br />
There was no indication that Google Search is better than Siri at recognizing and properly parsing natural language.</p>
<p>Siri&#8217;s strength is not in it&#8217;s ability to hear your voice and produce search results based on what you said, it&#8217;s in it&#8217;s ability to know that when you say &#8220;do I need an umbrella this afternoon&#8221; it is a query for a weather forecast, or when you say &#8220;remind me to take out the trash when I get home&#8221; you want a geo-fence based reminder triggered at your home address. Siri is more than search.</p>
<p>The future is not in the software&#8217;s ability to give you better search results or respond to commands, it is in the software&#8217;s ability to understand what you mean, even if you don&#8217;t say it explicitly, and for it to be able to do so for many tasks, not just search related things. Siri isn&#8217;t 100% there either, but it&#8217;s still ahead of Google in it&#8217;s ability to parse and understand natural conversational language.</p>
<p>This is a good articulation of the difference in purpose between the two. Personally, I&#8217;d rather be able to flawlessly and consistently get the results I want using a subset of defined commands than to have the software attempt to parse conversational English and give hit or miss results. I do like that Siri can (once in a while) pull out the relevant results and present them right there in the window (vs. opening a google search in the browser for every request), but the consistency just isn&#8217;t there. I&#8217;ll be very happy if the improved Google voice search/actions can do this well.</p>
<p>On iOS I get both.<br />
The Google Search app has voice search.</p>

Maybe Apple has a reset button, or hopefully as more people use it, it will get smarter again.</p>

<p>What I find ironic about your statement is that the &#8220;UI&#8221; of iOS is hardly original nor is it beautiful. The grid of icons will always find its origins with Xerox. Then when you talk about colorful icons with a consistent background, you have Palm&#8217;s PDA iconography. The beauty of iOS is in its simplicity because it defaulted to the lowest common denominator in only being a grid of icons. Apple&#8217;s imposed restrictions also don&#8217;t allow you to put icons wherever you want or in a disarrayed fashion, so there is an &#8220;order&#8221;. It satisfies the OCD in all of us. Beautiful is subjective; original it proves not.</p>
<p>Metro UI is very much like iOS in that there a physical restrictions on the UI elements. You have forms of rectangles and they&#8217;re limited to where they can be placed. I would argue (and have voiced previously) that the new changes to the UI that allows users to change the size of the Live Tiles has introduce some disorder to what was otherwise a clean aesthetic. Clutter is a distinct possibility now with Metro.</p>
<p>Android&#8217;s UI was never meant to be constrained by these aesthetic rules which most people gauge beautiful, but I would argue that Android&#8217;s UI is the most original. You need only take a look through the Verge Forums, at the entry entitled &#8220;Post Your Homescreens.&#8221; The exercise of a user&#8217;s individual aesthetic has produced a number of original creations. How you access apps, controls, functions are all different. You can make Android to emulate Windows Phone. You can throw a grid of apps on the homescreen. Or you can mix and match apps with widgets. Beauty is there fore in the eye of the beholder. Originality is their expression.</p>
<p>All the other elements of the UI are pretty much similar. How you access menus, toggle, etc. are pretty standard. What you think about the faux-realism aesthetic (fake brushed aluminum, linen, leather bindings, etc.) is a personal take. We know many are not fans. I&#8217;ve read vegans who absolutely abhor that their iDevice simulates leather.  But all that is also part of the UI.</p>
<p>At the end of the day, choose what you think is right for you. If you hate the UI so much on the GNex, sell it. Sounds like you&#8217;re an iOS guy anyways. It&#8217;ll relieve a lot of the stress you&#8217;re feeling when you interact with your device. No one should have to use a device that brings them so much disdain.</p>

<p>You&#8217;re confusing speed with responsiveness. If I tap something and something happens (albeit a transitionary state) that <em>feels responsive</em>. Not doing anything then showing the result of my interaction instead gives the impression of laggy response.</p>
<p>This is the excuse I keep hearing but it makes no sense. When I scroll a web page on Android it takes a split second to respond then the page lags a few pixels behind my finger. On WP7 it begins to move a lot sooner (enough so that it&#8217;s imperceptible) and seems to scroll at a 1:1 rate. When I had my Galaxy Nexus I tested this by starting at the bottom of the page and moving my finger really slowly across the screen, it was obvious that the web page and my finger were moving at completely different rates; the page element that my finger was directly above when I started the scroll wasn&#8217;t the same as when I ended it. How exactly are iOS and WP7 employing trickery to hide this?</p>
<p>Or how about the keyboard, on my Galaxy Nexus it was still easy to get my keyboard to severely lag at will. On WP7 this is near impossible. How exactly is MS employing trickery to make it seem as if the keyboard is keeping up with my taps?</p>

<p>It&#8217;s the price of a bad core design decision. iOS favors UI rendering above anything else. Android doesn&#8217;t.</p>
<p>When scrolling a webpage in iOS, the page stops loading until you stopped scrolling. in Android it keeps loading up, seemingly slowing down the device.</p>
<p>Hence, iOS looks smoother but loads more slowly. I prefer smooth looking over faster loading though.</p>
<p>I would think with a quad core device they could afford to give the UI a dedicated thread.</p>
<p>iOS does not stop the page loading while you are scrolling.  In any case, once the page loads iOS is still smoother.  And I don&#8217;t think iOS loads pages more slowly in any significant way.  Most comparisons of similar generation devices show similar page load speeds.  Add to that the fact that even a large fairly complex page  (say, theverge home page) only takes several seconds to load.  I usually don&#8217;t need to begin scrolling and reading like mad before it finishes. :)</p>
<p>THAT&#8217;S NOT INPUT LAG.</p>
<p>Watch the video. It&#8217;s more likely acceleration and deceleration. I noticed no dropped frames in the video.</p>
<p>Whatever you want to call it, the scrolling doesn&#8217;t keep up with the finger. It&#8217;s not nearly as close to 1:1 movement as in iOS.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s well documented. Android users need to stop living in denial about it. Project Butter is more evidence that it&#8217;s a legitimate issue in the user experience.</p>
<p>Scrolling actually does move with your finger as long as the finger stays on screen. There is an elastic band effect, that is not lag. The thing is there by design. Now you might not like it, but it&#8217;s not technically lag.</p>

<p>The main problems are:</p>
<p> (1) that &#8220;time between major updates&#8221; and &#8220;time not up to date&#8221; are not the same thing.  No one cares about the former except people looking for an angle that makes Android look better.  Everyone cares about the latter.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m not sure what facts are questionable, I tried to double check everything I put. There could be something wrong, in which case someone can chime in. As for the rhetorical points, well I simply was trying to state my opinion.</p>
<p>At the end of the discussion, the fact is the update/software set-up for Google is less than ideal than Apple. That isn&#8217;t Google&#8217;s fault.</p>
<p>Apple can show something, work on it, release it for every iteration of their hardware because they control it.</p>
<p>Google can show something, release it for their Nexus devices and the source code, and then other manufacturers have to go to work. Are some of them much worse than others at getting updates out? Yes of course.</p>
<p>To address point #1, the &#8220;time not up to date&#8221;  is controlled by Apple. It&#8217;s why I said it&#8217;s &#8220;smoke and mirrors&#8221;. Apple is the hardware and software developer, they are developing software that runs on their hardware.</p>
<p>OEMs do not have access to the Android code until it is finished. This difference means that Apple can release when it&#8217;s finished. OEMs have to take the code and adapt it. Are their skins and changes crap sometimes? Yes. But the fact is even at its stock core there are changes that need to be made.</p>
<p>So naturally there is a &#8220;time not up to date&#8221; that is 100% out of control of the OEMs (and Google). Once again, some are worse than others at extending that time, but it will NEVER be as perfect as Apple because of the different structure. People need to accept that. It&#8217;s why phones still get released on Gingerbread. All the engineering was based around that OS level.</p>
<p>As for #2, I don&#8217;t know the complete change logs of each update. But I believe most of what you mentioned were brought about in &#8220;major&#8221; jumps. All Android phones have gotten OTA updates that consist of bug fixes/security enhancements,/etc. that aren&#8217;t considered part of the direct Android upgrade cycle. <p>The good news is its already on XDA&#8230;<br />
 <br />
Download the file from post # 1 of this thread:<br />
<a href="http://forum.xda-developers.com/showthread.php?t=2064074"></a><br />
 <br />
■Copy file from above and drop on SD card (not internal storage)<br />
 ■Power phone off<br />
 ■Hold Power and both Volume Up and Down until boot screen appears<br />
 ■From boot screen, scroll down to "Recovery" with Volume Down<br />
 ■Press Volume Up to select it once it has been highlighted<br />
 ■When Android and exclamation show up, press both Volumes at the same time.<br />
 ■Then "install update from external storage" and find the file.<br />
 <br />
Let the update run, and enjoy.<br />
 <br />
If you are rooted you can keep root using OTA Rootkeeper.<br />
 Before you apply the update:<br />
 Run OTA Rootkeeper<br />
 Click on &#8220;Protect Root&#8221;<br />
 Click on &#8220;Temp Unroot&#8221;<br />
 Apply the update<br />
 Run OTA Rootkeeper again<br />
 Click on &#8220;Restore Root&#8221;</p>

<p>From the XDA forums: Using any file manager app, go into your /system folder and open the file called &#8220;build.prop&#8221;. Find the line that starts with ro.product.name. Whatever comes after the equals sign (=), that&#8217;s the firmware you have.</p>

<p>I can&#8217;t believe someone who reads the Verge cannot figure out that XDA ROMs won&#8217;t solve every single problem. For the JB ROM to be stable, the developers need the updated drivers for the various hardware components within the phone. Unless there is a developer reference device out there using the same chipset and running JB, they won&#8217;t be able to pull a dump of the OS image and recreate it for the target device. The best they can do without official drivers is to rebuild the kernel from the source, which is extremely time-intensive and still likely to be full of bugs. It wasn&#8217;t a big deal to move from Froyo to Gingerbread, but for phones that launched with GB and didn&#8217;t get upgraded, most devs have struggled to get a working ICS build without native drivers.</p>

<p>Then why did Google kick up a fuss about LG (was it LG?) having Google apps on their Android fork?</p>
<p>Mind you, the Google Apps can only be used on certified devices. However, once it is a certified device, it does not matter if it is rooted or has a custom ROM.</p>
<p>Forking Android isn&#8217;t allowed by Open Handset Alliance members, <a href="http://www.openhandsetalliance.com/oha_faq.html">it&#8217;s in the FAQ</a>. LG could fork Android but they would be forfeiting their OHA membership, and losing Google support.</p>
<p>But those ROMs aren&#8217;t members of the OHA, so why do Google provide them the apps?</p>

<p>Barely 5% have ICS now and it is almost 7 months out.  I think you are too generous without your estimate.  Maybe .5% would be more accurate.  By the time Jelly Bean has 5 %, KrispyKreme 5.0 will be out and most phones will still be on Gingerbread.</p>
<p>I think you are thinking too simplistically at the numbers and assuming that the current ICS adoption rate will move forward.</p>
<p>Fact is, that Android phones exist on multiple tiers. At the low-end, GB or Froyo might be the best that the hardware can aspire to (ICS really needs 512MB RAM and many phones still ship with or have shipped with 256MB or 384MB).</p>
<p>As time move on, a higher proportion on low-end phones will hit the 512MB RAM threshold as the high-end settles on 1GB and soon to be 2GB. Some low-end phones will never get ICS, or at least not an ICS that would be usable. The Android stats do not split phones up by OS version / RAM size. If they did, you would see a much higher adoption rate on &gt;= 512MB devices and approximately zero on &lt; 512MB devices.</p>
<p>Apple&#8217;s approach is to claim that all phones get the latest update (3GS gets 6.0), but then to disable features that the hardware cannot deal with (lots and lots of features disabled for 3GS). New software cannot magically create new hardware into your phone.</p>
<p>So, ICS adoption rate is slow due to the wealth of low spec Android phones (which is awesome by the way for it allows affordable internet connectivity in the third world).</p>
<p>Another factor in the slow ICS adoption rate is that the kernel and driver model changed between 2.3 and 4.0. This is equivalent to the leap from XP to Vista. Lots of hardware required new drivers compiling and the build process had to be completely changed for 4.0+. I am speculating here, but I don&#8217;t expect this same kind of kernel level change for 4.1, meaning rollouts for compatible hardware should be faster for 4.1 versus 4.0.</p>
<p>Putting this all together. More and more ICS capable hardware is shipping, and 4.1 will likely be a release that involves a lot less effort for carriers to bastardise (assuming they&#8217;ve already pre-bastardised ICS). As such, 4.1 should have a much faster adoption rate than 4.0.</p>

<p>Eclair (2.1) to Froyo (2.2)<br />
Froyo (2.2) to Gingerbread (2.3)<br />
Honeycomb for tablets (3.0)<br />
Ice Cream Sandwich for phones/tablets (4.0)<br />
ICS (4.0) to Jellybean (4.1)</p>
<p>You&#8217;re (conveniently) forgetting:</p>
<p>Eclair (2.0) to 2.1 (also Eclair)<br />
Honeycomb (3.0) to 3.1 and 3.2 (also both Honeycomb)<br />
Reportedly, Google also considered releasing 2.4 (Gingerbread) as an interim update to 2.3, but it never happened.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m not conveniently forgetting anything.  Google has been pretty consistent with the versioning.  Codename changes generally mean significant consumer-facing changes.  Point-releases for the same codename (like your Eclair and Honeycomb examples) are important under the hood changes resulting in a new platform version (aka API level).</p>
<p>At every point release release they&#8217;ve changed the API level. At every .0 release they&#8217;ve changed the API level.</p>
<p>Also: sorry if I sounded threatening when I said (conveniently). I didn&#8217;t mean for it to come across like that, but it&#8217;s very hard to express tone of voice in written text.</p>
<p>2.0  was really Droid/Milestone exclusive.</p>
<p>4.1 probably would mean the APIs aren&#8217;t changing much so there will be little to do for devs to update their apps.  I would expect the next major version jump to require a lot more changes for devs.</p>
<p>Frankly, 4.0 wasn&#8217;t that big of a change. The only thing I did is change the target API and not a single line of code.</p>
<p>That&#8217;s the idea behind Android though. The API levels are supposed to build on each other. So you can be level 12 compliant without changing anything despite originally writing to level 8 or whatever.</p>
<p>The point is now that you have targeted a higher API you have more available to you, though apparently you decided not to use it (or at least not at that point)</p>
<p>When did Google actually mean something they said ? It doesn&#8217;t matter, they change their mind everytime, it&#8217;s actually the company policy to be able to release products more faster.</p>

<p>Yes, and I had speech recognition and actions on my Apricot Portable in 1984 &#8211; your point is? My Dragon and its 10MB HDD didn&#8217;t need the cloud either. FWIW; the speech recognition engine on the Apricot was made by  UK firm Dragon, which is now Nuance, which powers Siri. The real pioneers were the engineers that worked for decades to bring speech recognition to devices when nobody actually wanted it or needed it. And now their hard work is being rewarded.</p>
<p>You pretty much just made my point: Google didn&#8217;t &#8220;pioneer&#8221; any of this. It&#8217;s all been around for a very long time. And your reminder about Dragon is well-made. I used to work for one of their competitors, and Dragon was tough competition, along with IBM and Kurzweil. (BTW, thank you&#8212;I was one of those engineers. People definitely wanted speech recognition, but it wasn&#8217;t quite good enough or fast enough&#8230;yet.)</p>
<p>The Dragon founders actually started out at CMU, then joined IBM, then went solo. They provided Apricot computers with speech recognition software, but I don&#8217;t believe that Dragon itself was ever a UK company.</p>
<p>I don&#8217;t think anybody is arguing that Google didn&#8217;t pioneer voice actions. They <em>did</em> pioneer using voice to do useful things on a smartphone.</p>
<p>After thinking about it a bit, I suppose that my real, underlying point is that smartphones have way, way more than enough hardware resources to do quality speech recognition right on the phone, with no network involved, no cloud needed.</p>
<p>It bothers me quite a bit that the modern approach of shoving the heavy lifting onto a remote server (and database where all the queries can be stored and&#8230;marketed) is completely unneeded from a technical standpoint, and is rather inelegant. It primarily serves the companies that collect the queries and the agencies interested in those queries, rather than the end users. Apple and Google are equally guilty of doing this. Sure, it allows the recognition engine to be refined and enhanced without a software  or model upgrade on the phone itself. But the approach still rubs me the wrong way.</p>

<p>Releasing a 5.0 before you hit 10% adoption of 4.0 would look really bad so I am sure that played into the &#8220;4.1&#8221; version number partly.  But I actually do believe that this is a much smaller upgrade to Android than ICS was.  Let&#8217;s face it, 3.0 Honeycomb was never open-sourced because Google made some big changes to support tablets and the code was likely not in the kind of shape that you would want folks to build on top of it.  ICS was a cleanup of all that code and some big changes to the SDK and (in my opinion) finally brought to Android to maturity.  Ironically, iOS 5.0 (which was released about the same time) is what finally brought iOS to maturity on many features as well.  It seems Android played catch up on the user experience and SDK improvements to reduce fragmentation in the future and that Apple played catch-up on the feature set with things like notification center and voice recognition.</p>
<p>Oddly enough, I think the parity continues with Apple refining iOS further in version 6 with turn-by-turn navigation and better voice control in this release and Google updating voice control and UI smoothness in 4.1.  It will be interesting to see if either Google or Apple can add a truly distinctive break-out feature in the next 12 months or if we are just going into a state of refinement and incremental improvement for mobile operating systems.</p>
<p>In the past, Apple has made a habit of changing the game as soon as competitors &#8220;caught up&#8221; to them on the things they excelled at.  The only positive differentiator that iOS has now over Android (other than somebody&#8217;s personal UX/UI preference) is the third-party app and hardware ecosystem.  It seems to me that the next 24 months will be indicative of whether Apple without Jobs can still &#8220;change the game&#8221;.  Either Apple will double-down on third-party integration with things like automotive integration and television integration or they will tell third parties that they have something even better to start building around.</p>
<p>Android 4.1 looks great &#8212; I&#8217;m sure lots of folks will be clamoring for upgrades.  All those who bought the Galaxy Nexus and Nexus S should be cheering right now &#8212; Nexus devices really make the most sense if you want timely upgrades.  Here&#8217;s hoping that the hardware vendors can get other devices upgraded in less than 6 months time given the ICS foundation of Jelly Bean.</p>

<p>I agree.  I think they need a breakthrough new product or feature in the next 24 months &#8212; something that creates a halo effect for their existing stuff.  Doubling down on third-party integration and ecosystem would likely spell doom because it puts your advantage in the hands of third parties who can then give that advantage to your competitor.  It also smells of protecting your turf and stagnation which is what Microsoft was doing for too long before they started work on Windows Phone and Windows 8 and it is what RIM tried to do with enterprise lock-in &#8212; the enterprises are now moving to iOS because their users have.</p>
<p>Once something gets old you need to canibalize it yourself and move on.  I&#8217;m not saying that iOS is getting old, but I am saying that if there are only incremental improvements on the mobile OS front for all players then mobile operating systems become commodities.  If that occurs, Apple needs to create something new to revolutionize some other sector and that new thing needs to integrate so well with iOS (and OS X) that it gives iOS an intangible advantage over other mobile operating systems.  Apple cannot rely on third parties to own that.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.randsinrepose.com/archives/2012/06/28/someone_is_coming_to_eat_you.html" target="_blank">http://www.randsinrepose.com/archives/2012/06/28/someone_is_coming_to_eat_you.html</a></p>
<p>BC2009 you really have explained it all very well.</p>
<p>Talking about stand out feature&#8230; only 2 weeks ago was I thinking that my phones knows so much about me.. why doesn&#8217;t it let me know that when im about to go to the gym that there is been a crash and it will take me 40mins not the usual 20mins.</p>
<p>Then along comes google now&#8230; the potential to be that stand out feature.. but as google like to do, released early and still in its infancy. So google now won&#8217;t be seens as a amazing tool simple because its not there year and it may be in a years time&#8230;</p>
<p>Where as if apple released it. It would be that amazing feature that really stands out.. but we wouldn&#8217;t have had it for another 12months&#8230; Its tough because apple wow you with what they have hidden over time, google show you what they are doing as they do it (e.g Google Glass)</p>
<p>Neither is the better or worse way. Its just interesting to see how they handle things differently and easy to see why people can get very excited for apple updates while at same time slate them for bring out &#8220;new features&#8221; (e.g. copy and paste)</p>
<p>Very good points.  The only feature I have seen from Apple that was released &#8220;early&#8221; was Siri, and that was because Siri would only get better if they had a larger sampling of input data to work with.  However, by the time Siri starts getting really good (with iOS 6 improvements), along comes Google&#8217;s new voice features and suddenly we have parity again.</p>
<p>Google Now is brilliant, but it will likely be deficient at first.  In a year when it gets really good, then Apple will likely have some equivalent (probably based around Passbook).  And again we get parity.</p>
<p>Your remark about Apple keeping it under covers is spot on.  Look at how they have been collecting traffic data anonymously (its even in their EULA for iOS that they will do this).  Now all of a sudden we see turn-by-turn GPS from Apple with live traffic from established sources and crowd-sourcing.  Google has had turn-by-turn for several iterations in Android, but iOS users have had to pay for their turn-by-turn navigation.  I have used Navigon and have loved it.  But now, Apple brings it to the core operating system in iOS 6 at the same time that both Apple and Google unveil realistic 3D mapping using fly-over captures from airplanes.</p>
<p>It seems to me that Apple and Google are basically trading blows right now.  Its good for consumers since each is driving the other, but the next game changer is going to have to be something that is &#8220;5 years ahead of the competition&#8221; in order to prevent the competitors from copying it.</p>
<p>Keep in mind that patents usually take about 3 to 5 years from application to issuance.  So even if one of these players came out with some awesome software feature, the other could easily copy it until the originator got its patent issued and by then it might not matter as much.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m watching Apple very closely in the next 24 months.  I&#8217;m very interested to see if they have anything cool up their sleeves.  Google has revealed their next great thing: Google Glass.  But at $1500 a pair to preorder the preview version due out in 2014, it is a bit out of most people&#8217;s league.  Apple does not tip their hand that way, so it will be interesting to see what they are cooking up.</p>
<p>Honeycomb code was released the same day they released the ICS code. Sorry I know it&#8217;s just nitpicking.</p>
<p>Yup &#8212; true enough.  May be a nitpick, but it is certainly a relevant and good point to make.</p>
<p>Let&#8217;s be fair though, Apple may release updates to their hardware and make them available to download on a specific day, but the do pick and choose the features that will be available on each of their devices. Obviously, they make that determination by which devices can effectively support a feature, but they also look to marketing too. If the iPhone 4 could have used Siri, then there would not have been much of a reason for upgrade to the 4S.</p>
<p>So Apple&#8217;s devices all read the same version number, but each devices has different features. When the iPhone 5 and iOS 6 comes out, not every phone is going to get turn by turn directions, a feature that has been included on all Android phones for years now. Effectively, some phones will be running iOS 6 with only very minor changes, some phones will only get security updates with iOS 6.</p>
<p>In essence, there is little difference between Apple and Android when it comes to versions. Sure, Android phones may read different version numbers, but in the same way that Apple picks and chooses the features that can be loaded onto their different phones, Android phone manufacturers pick and choose which phones can be updated, and when they can be updated. This allows them to give their new phones a market advantage over their old phones, and new customers will likely be drawn to the updated operating system.</p>
<p>Older phones which cannot handle the features present in newer OS versions will not get updates at all. This may frustrate  some users, especially when they think their phone is still fairly new, but with the way mobile technology advances these days, it doesn&#8217;t take long for a phone to become obsolete.</p>
<p>The same is true even in Apple&#8217;s world. After a year, their phones are obsolete, and not granted the same functionality as their new phones. Now, while Apple only releases a single phone each year (and in one case it took 14 months), Android phones are constantly developed. That leads to greater innovation as each manufacturer competes with another, but the cost is slower update times.</p>
<p>Still, if you bought a phone and you are happy with it, then just be happy with it. It doesn&#8217;t matter the manufacturer or the version, simply enjoy your purchase. Updates for your phone are not a necessity, but rather an added gift of functionality. But if you&#8217;re unhappy with your phone, then maybe there&#8217;s another underlying problem. One that probably won&#8217;t be fixed with new features and a shinier UI.</p>
<p>One key difference.  Some newer apps require the new OS.  Even though some Apple hardware gets very little upgrades from a feature perspective, they get access to the new API&#8217;s that allow users to use newer software that requires them.</p>
<p>Well, it&#8217;s kind of silly to write an application that can be used by a very small percentage of people, is it not? That&#8217;s why Android applications are written for the most popular version, and still work for any higher version.</p>

<p>About a week ago I was on Droid-Life reading the comments in a &#8220;what do you want in Jelly Bean&#8221; post, and of course someone said for it to be smooth. Then a guy explained how the &#8220;smooth OS&#8217;s&#8221; are slower at doing things while Android is fast, yet a bit &#8220;jagged&#8221; and how a smooth yet fast OS would be a technical marvel&#8230; A couple days later Project Butter was released.</p>
<p>They didn&#8217;t necessarily &#8216;redesign&#8217; Android to incorporate Project Butter. The inherent problem with Android (as per my knowledge&#8230; Pardon me if i am wrong) is that the &#8216;Touch Input&#8217; thread didn&#8217;t have a high priority. In programming, you have to use threads for assigning tasks. iOS and windows phone both assign the highest priority to a touch input whereas in Android, the touch input thread was given equal precedence compared to other thread.</p>
<p>In layman terms, if you had a thread running loading of images and you touched the screen, iOS would stop any runnng thread (put it on hold) and give the touch input highest precedence and cpu time to run. On the Android pre JB, the task would actually line up in a queue and not get highest priority. This is why iOS always feels more &#8216;responsive&#8217; than Android.</p>
<p>The reason why Google implemented such a mechanism was to incorporate the low spec devices&#8230; However, the high end phones also suffered from this. Apple never really cared as they only cater to a few devices.</p>
<p>With JB update, they seem to have upped the requirement and now se hardware has matured enough, they can easily just implement the internals as iOS has&#8230; So don&#8217;t fall under the marketing stuff companies use like &#8216;butter&#8217; and all&#8230;. It&#8217;s not a huge upgrade and should have been there from day 1 on ICS the day it released for high end phones. About time they implemented this.</p>
<p>They are minor changes? I thought all the Android fans were claiming that iOS 6 with over 200 new features was a letdown compared to the awesome new Jelly Bean update.</p>
<p>FYI: From the technical PoV, iOS6 hasn&#8217;t changed at all compared to iOS5. Features != technical changes.</p>
<p>iOS already has Project Butter since 2007 and Google Now (aka Siri) since 2011, so what technical POV needs to change. Why fix something that ain&#8217;t broke?</p>

<p>For updates to work as the cell phone business model stands now, the manufactures need to strong arm the carriers into allowing the updates because it costs them money. The manufacturers don&#8217;t always want to do this because they want to sell new phones with the latest and greatest. Only select phones of theirs will get any updates.</p>
<p>For example, I have a T-Mobile SGS2 and have had a good experience with the ICS update, but the T-Mobile boards are full of people complaining about the update, bricking phones, calling support, trading in phones, etc.  It&#8217;s costing T-Mobile money.</p>
<p>For the business model of Android to work in the current climate, they&#8217;ve got to limit the hardware like Windows Phone or control the experience from end to end like Apple does. This isn&#8217;t going to change unless the hardware and OS software is separated like PCs and Windows are today, where the updates come directly from the OS maker and not some third party, and the carriers need to just be a data pipe. This way you&#8217;ll have hardware, OS and carrier all competing on only the pieces they own, not across all of the pieces.</p>

<p>The OEM&#8217;s and carriers are getting a lot of neg press for being unwilling to respond to user demand for timely updates. If one of them actually took time to take care of consumers and not destroy them with bloatware, then the could actually win customers over by taking care of them.</p>

I&#8217;d personally be happier if they got out of the way and let us decide when we want to install the updates.</p>

<p>That&#8217;s sadly very true. The vast majority of the world doesn&#8217;t know about jelly bean, Google Now, the disadvantages of skinning, update delays due to skins, bloatware, etc. All they see is a nice phone in the commercials and they run after it.</p>
<p>The Nokia guy was correct when he said &#8220;the average customer doesn&#8217;t care about updates&#8221;. It was the wrong thing to say, but he was right. And that applies to iOS, Android AND WP7.</p>
<p>Then why does MS or Apple update their phones?</p>
<p>The main problem with updates on Android isn&#8217;t the complexity of updating; it&#8217;s that the OEMs have no real reason to update the software once you&#8217;ve purchased, and especially once they&#8217;ve phased out the device you&#8217;re on. Sure, there is brand loyalty to those who will buy based on availability of updates&#8230;but in practice, most users don&#8217;t care (Verge readers excluded). It&#8217;s cheaper for the OEMs to just pretend that 18 month old tablet you&#8217;re using never existed, and move on to the next big thing.</p>
<p>Apply this scenario to the PC industry. Just think if you bought an HP desktop, and you couldn&#8217;t buy Windows 9 from Microsoft, you had to get it from HP. But your computer is 24 months old, and they stopped even selling your computer 6 months ago. What possible reason does HP have to update Windows for you? They won&#8217;t make any money off of it, and in fact, you might not buy that NEW HP computer because your old one is working just fine. From a financial perspective, this makes perfect sense, and it&#8217;s why this situation doesn&#8217;t exist on the desktop.</p>
<p>The solution needs to be Google handling the updates. I know, it&#8217;s very hard, what with all the various hardware configs out there, and the cell industry being their typical pains in our collective asses. That&#8217;s irrelevant though, the bottom line is, Google is the ONLY one that has some incentive to make these updates available to previously-purchased hardware owners. Until that happens, this will always, ALWAYS be a problem.</p>
<p>Unfortunately the cat is already out of the bag. The OS is open source. If Google decided that it wanted to handle all the updates tomorrow the OEMs can simply stick with the current free and open one and fork their own versions like Amazon did. Google has no power to solve this problem unless the future updates are released not to OEMs but directly to the consumer for installation on whatever hardware they might have even though I&#8217;m sure all devices will get locked down every which way possible.</p>
<p>OEMs and carriers would HATE it if Google were to start pushing out updates themselves. OEMs don&#8217;t like being dumb manufacturers; they want to have as much control over their devices as possible so the customer gets locked in to their and only THEIR devices.</p>
<p>Laptop OEMs dislike it already because MS controls updates on Windows laptops, and that&#8217;s why they ship laptops with as much bloatware as possible to &#8220;differentiate&#8221; their offering. Sadly it works out really well among the masses, I know one person who buys Dell laptops &#8220;just because the Dell dock is very good&#8221;.</p>
<p>Same goes for Sense and TouchWiz, and OEMs won&#8217;t like Google to be fiddling around with their custom modifications. OEMs want to take care of skins themselves.</p>
<p>As I see it you have two options.</p>
<p>1) Learn to like the OS version the phone came with, because in all likelihood thats the one you will be using two years later.</p>
<p>2) Vote with your wallet: buy an iPhone, Nexus-class device, or Windows Phone (I kid, I kid!) that is free from crapware and comes with a guarantee of a reasonable timeframe for software upgrades.</p>
<p>It is far too late for Google to take back control of the software update process without strong harm politics. If I recall, only 7 % of Android devices are running ICS. Compare that to 80% of iOS device running iOS 5. It is a real mess for Android developers. <br />
I don&#8217;t know how Google can manage that but if they don&#8217;t the situation can only get worst.</p>
<p>The update situation irks technical people to no end but the reality of android is the vast majority of android users don&#8217;t know and don&#8217;t care about these updates.  My wife has a droid 4 and could care less about ICS or jelly bean.  Droid 4 is a mediocre phone btw but she like the keyboard.</p>

Further, how many people know what specific features the next Android OS offers (or what features they have that the previous OS did not have)? At least with Apple&#8217;s iOS iterations, the company advertises pretty clearly what they are adding and subtracting (maybe because they have more functionality to add that they purposely left out, but that is another issue).</p>
<p>Very few people care about getting a &#8220;Nexus&#8221; device so they can have the latest OS. I have seen plenty of Droid RAZRs in the real world. A friend let me play around with her RAZR extensively, it looks like a cool phone. When the average user doesn&#8217;t really know the different between Android OS versions or skins, why would he or she choose a Nexus over a RAZR when the Verizon associate is pushing RAZRs?</p>
<p>The fact of the matter is having access to the latest OS really isn&#8217;t a big drawback for most users. Given the way the US market is priced, these are not computers &#8211; smartphones (for better and for worse) have become relatively cheap, disposable technology that is best replaced very 18 months to 2 years. These aren&#8217;t laptops and desktops that you aim to keep for four years. Get rid of carrier subsidies, make people carry phones around for four years, and more people will care about subsidies</p>
<p>Only slightly related to this article (and because I&#8217;m currently hungry) &#8211; if you&#8217;re a Jelly Belly fan, go to your local dollar store and buy a bag of Jelly Belly Flops. It&#8217;s a grab bag of all the mistakes off the production line.  So while they may look like freaks, they taste just as good, and only cost a buck.</p>
<p>The bigger issue here that isn&#8217;t really being addressed is the ramifications of Android 2.x being the lowest common denominator environment for developers to target. Google does a few things to ease this but I&#8217;m wondering how much, if at all, this problem is responsible for the poor quality of many Android apps? It seems to me having the latest &amp; greatest APIs available makes your life easier and allows you to build better apps faster.  I haven&#8217;t developed for Android but I&#8217;ve dabbled in iOS development and even for my simple needs I would hate to go back and work with the iOS4 SDK. Apple has added so much in iOS5/6 for developers. If I had to target iOS4 I would have to re-invent the wheel for quite a few things. (and this is for extremely bare-bones apps I&#8217;m developing mostly for educational purposes. I can imagine a real app would be even more of a struggle)</p>
<p>Customers don&#8217;t appear to know or really care &#8211; RAZR continues to outsell the Nexus on Verizon:</p>
<p><a href="http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/12/06/26/apples_iphone_4s_remains_top_selling_smartphone_at_verizon.html" target="_blank">http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/12/06/26/apples_iphone_4s_remains_top_selling_smartphone_at_verizon.html</a></p>

<p>When will we get the update to JB? Well, to answer that question, I suppose you have to know what kind of user you are. If you&#8217;re the type of person who doesn&#8217;t really care about which updates your phone gets, and you&#8217;re perfectly happy with just having a phone that does the the things that let you live your online life more pervasively and your offline live more efficiently, then who cares about the update to JB? There really are only a few minor upgrades, and they deal with the UI. As we&#8217;ve all seen time and time again, when a UI changes, a lot of non-technophiles feel uncomfortable with it.</p>
<p>However, if you&#8217;re the kind of person that really cares about having the latest and greatest operating system version, then you&#8217;re probably the kind of person who knows how to load custom ROMs. In that case, the update to JB will be released quickly for your device, and you&#8217;ll probably swear up and down how great it is to have a phone without all the proprietary junk installed by the manufacturer.</p>

<p>This is an incredibly revealing quote:<br />
<blockquote>We&#8217;ve actually started with this release — a beta of the Jelly Bean PDK has already been available to a few partners for the last few weeks and they&#8217;ve been providing us valuable feedback. We&#8217;ve incorporated that feedback and now it&#8217;s available to everyone on an ongoing basis. PDK enables Android OEMs and chipset makers to innovate in parallel with Google and ensure the latest Android release can be well-optimized for their hardware.</blockquote></p>
<p>In other words, given the PDK ahead of time, the manufacturers didn&#8217;t leap to start porting Jelly Bean to their devices. Instead, they <em>asked for changes in Jelly Bean</em>. And Google made some of those changes, meaning nobody could count on the PDK to be final until the changes were made.</p>
<p>The result here isn&#8217;t a shortening of the development cycle, it&#8217;s a lengthening. Now there&#8217;ll be a get-approval-from-manufacturers cycle before they start porting. That may speed up the process of porting somewhat, because the changes asked for may be the ones that the manufacturers would have had to make on their own, but count on it to be marginal.</p>
<p>There&#8217;s simply no incentive for these companies to waste money on a device they already shipped and that, like all phones released today, is fast approaching obsolescence.</p>
<p>That&#8217;s the reason I&#8217;ll never buy an Android device unless it is shipped and designed to work with a stock firmware. I hate stupid skinning and branding made by manufacturers that nobody cares about.</p>

<p>I struggle with his constant reiteration of &#8220;no compromises&#8221;.  Let&#8217;s just list them off:</p>
<p>1) Targeted at content consumption, not creation<br />
2) No micro SD (was on the previous incarnation from Asus, pulled to save money)<br />
3) No HDMI (again, on the previous Asus model, but removed)</p>
<p>In fact <a href="http://www.theverge.com/2012/6/28/3124041/asus-me370t-nexus-7-transformation-google-nvidia">this article</a> is pretty much a recount of the compromises made to get the tablet under $200.  Compared to the Kindle Fire, there are FAR less compromises.  I just found it strange that he kept harping on that phrase when Microsoft is using that same phrase to mean &#8220;the full PC experience on a tablet&#8221; &#8212; which incidentally brings about a different set of compromises.</p>
<p>Maybe I am goring weary of the phrase altogether, because every design decision you make is about a trade off (or compromise).  Each design should be targeted at a different sweet spot.  The Nexus 7 has a sweet spot but represents a huge set of compromises for another type of user.</p>
<p>no comprises doesnt mean add everything and the kitchen sink</p>
<p>I think the only thing that seems odd is the removal of HDMI out. It kinda seems like a good selling point, but I wonder what kind of use-rate those ports even get on most tablets/phones.</p>
<p>HDMI would have required additional licenses resulting in driving the price up.  They kept the base model cheap and will likely provide HDMI via a dock accessory.</p>
<p>Smart move, imo.</p>
<p>So, in other words, a compromise was made to keep the price down.</p>
<p>First off, I am going to recommend your post because YOU ARE CORRECT.  But I never said that you have to &#8220;throw in everything but the kitchen sink&#8221; to be able to declare &#8220;no compromises&#8221;.  Throwing in everything but the kitchen sink ALSO introduces some compromises.  Everything has compromises.</p>
<p>- iPad compromises portability for screen real estate<br />
- iOS compromises flexibility for ease of use and support<br />
- Android compromises seamless built-in integration for third-party extensibility <br />
- Galaxy SIII compromises one-handed use for more usable screen real estate<br />
- iPhone 4S compromises usable screen real-estate for portability and one-handed use<br />
- MacBook Air compromises processing power for portability and battery life<br />
- Kindle Fire compromises processing power for price and media-consumption focus<br />
- Windows 8 RT compromises the desktop experience for better battery life, performance, and security on ARM</p>
<p>I could go on and on.  I just feel that this constant usage of &#8220;no compromise&#8221; is getting ridiculous.  Microsoft jumped on the phrase and now to hear Duarte repeating it in a different context hurts my ears.  Everything has a trade-off, to believe otherwise is fooling yourself.</p>
<p>I bought a Logitech Ultrathin Keyboard Cover for iPad a few months ago.  It gets me over the hurdle for the &#8220;iPad has no keyboard compromise&#8221;; however it introduces compromises on portability and awkwardness when using the iPad (much like the Surface keyboard will).  Incidentally the Surface keyboard compromises lap-usage while letting you flip it around the back of the tablet for easy storage.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m certain there are Asus Transformer owners who look at the Nexus 7 and say &#8220;that&#8217;s nice, but I prefer my huge 10-inch screen with massive resolution and I will just wait for the Jelly Bean update&#8221;.  They are willing to sacrifice price for a tablet that provides more of other features.</p>
<p>I hope my point is more clear now.  I am hardly one to say that you should include everything in order to target everyone.  That would be the worst product ever.</p>
<p>I see what you&#8217;re saying. I think what Duarte means when he says no compromises is that you get a full-featured Jellybean experience, you don&#8217;t really lose functionality compared to other tablets, or at least very little. I think comparing the tablet to say, a laptop, is stretching what he means too far. I guess you&#8217;re still right, but I think &#8216;no compromises&#8217; has to be taken more in the context of what&#8217;s being delivered: you don&#8217;t really lose anything that you would have got had you gone 10&quot;.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m fine with an HDMI adaptor.  But plenty of folks have told me how silly I was for buying an iPad which lacks an HDMI output and SD card slot when Apple sells an adaptor for each (both of which I happen to own).  These folks felt the compromise was not worth it.  Others may feel at a certain price point its not an acceptable compromise, but at a lower price point it is.</p>
<p>I&#8217;ve always acknowledged that no HDMI on iPad is a compromise because it requires an adaptor, but I am fine with that because if I am carrying an HDMI cable or even an HDMI to mini-HDMI adaptor then I might as well be carrying an Apple 30-pin-dock-to-HDMI adaptor.  Same goes for SD cards and importing photos to iPad.  Its something I need on vacation so I leave it in a pouch that always comes with me on trips.  No big deal, but still a compromise.  Another compromise is that Apple only lets the SD card adaptor work for photo import and not for files, but with things like DropBox and iCloud I am okay with this compromise (some apps can even do bluetooth file transfer).</p>
<p>Just saying there are compromises every where you look.  I think the compromises made on the Nexus 7 were the right ones to make a successful product, but to emphasize &#8220;no compromises&#8221; is silly.  I think RIM tried a variation on that same theme when they introduced the Playbook&#8217;s &#8220;Full Web Experience&#8221; with &#8220;Flash!&#8221;.  Things did not work out for them because the compromises they did make were in other areas which left the device crippled and confusing to most users.</p>
<p>I would argue that if a product is selling successfully then they likely have made the right combination of compromises and provided the right combination of features.  The Nexus 7 looks like it did what Amazon should have done with the Fire.  The Fire sold well around Christmas, but has reportedly trailed off.  I think the Nexus 7 will pickup where the Fire left off and take things to the next level for the 7-inch tablet market.  I also think Apple should put together a 7.85-inchiPad mini sooner rather than later.  I know that an iPad mini would be the perfect device for my three kids because it would run all the same apps I have for iPad and their current iPod touches.  If the Nexus 7 would run our collection of iOS apps or could be rooted to run iOS, I would likely buy three of them for my kids today.</p>
<p>No compromises that non-geeks care about.</p>
<p>1) Agree.  That said, in my opinion, any tablet is a compromise when it comes to content creation.</p>
<p>2) There has been no Nexus device since the Nexus One with MicroSD.  The Nexus S and Galaxy Nexus did fine without microSD.  Every iDevice has done fine without microSD slots.  It&#8217;s a Google Experience device.  They expect you to use Google&#8217;s services to store and manage your content.</p>
<p>3)  They probably did it for cost.  But it&#8217;s also like the microSD.  How many average Joes care?  I suspect that very  few people today have ever used HDMI from their phone.  I&#8217;ve used Android for 2.5 years and I never have.  And I&#8217;m a little more tech savvy than most.</p>
<p>There&#8217;s only two compromises that really matter when it comes to tablets. The first is screen quality.  The second is battery life.  The Nexus 7 nailed them both.</p>

<p>I love what Matias said, one design philosophy for all apps that can scale to any screen size.</p>
<p>I like how principled he is, but I can&#8217;t see it working for truly complex apps.</p>
<p>For example look at Apple&#8217;s iPhoto, Keynote and so on, on iPhone and iPad. The UI is completely re-thought for interacting at those two sizes. It&#8217;s not scaled according to an auto-layout system, it just wouldn&#8217;t work. These apps have singular design philosophies, but the implementations are essentially two separate projects that each value their own use-case scenarios, goals, and workflows.</p>
<p>When you use an app on your phone, you approach it with different emotions — and often different goals — than you would when you approach it on a tablet. For example, you don&#8217;t tend to start large creative projects on your phone, but you would probably edit them. So your apps may even have a slightly different focus on different devices.</p>
<p>That said, a lot of simpler apps can adopt one design and scale to any screen size. Especially ones that just display content and don&#8217;t rely on complicated interaction.</p>

<p>Let&#8217;s take a look at what Google is doing with their OS and their own line of Nexus phones. When Google can not efficiently or speedily update their own OS on their own line of Nexus phones before the OEM&#8217;s, there is a major problem. It is now March and we still have no idea what went wrong with the ICS update for the Nexus S and 4G as Google has been completely silent on the matter for the last three months. Three months without a word from Google does not instill any kind of confidence in their competence of supporting their own OS on just their own line of Nexus phones, let alone every other device with Android on it. Not to mention that this is a long time to strand your users on an OS (rooting and flashing a downgrade is not a viable fix as it voids manufacturers warranty) that is draining their phones battery in less than six hours. There is also a very large problem with Google&#8217;s customer service for Android and the Nexus line of phones. The Nexus is special in that if there is any kind of software problem the manufacturer (Samsung, HTC) and the carrier (Sprint, T-Mobile, AT&amp;T, Verizon) will refer you to Google to find any kind of help. They are not on the hook, as the Android OS is Google&#8217;s responsibility on the Nexus line. Problem being that Google does not have any kind of customer service for the Nexus and it&#8217;s OS other than a forum. This forum goes largely ignored with even the most basic of questions and problems. Imagine if Apple only supplied a forum (no 800 number, no e-mail address, no Genius bar) as customer service for the iPhone. People would flip out. How is it okay for Google to treat it&#8217;s users and customers in this manner?</p>
<p>Please take a look at Google&#8217;s forums here: <a href="http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/Google+Mobile/label?lid=551c5c4cca..." target="_blank">http://www.google.com/support/forum/p/Google+Mobile/label?lid=551c5c4cca&#8230;</a><br />
Almost every question marked as answered is not actually answered. They are just some reply from another user saying they have the same problem. On the off chance you finally find a question that Google has responded to, it is just some low level employee stating they know it&#8217;s a problem (offering no solution) or asking for bug reports. In fact it has gotten so bad on these forums that it&#8217;s Nexus users have resorted to spamming Android&#8217;s Google+ page <a href="https://plus.google.com/104629412415657030658/posts" target="_blank">https://plus.google.com/104629412415657030658/posts</a> in the hopes that Google will finally say something, anything on the issue. There are a lot of ignored and angry Nexus users out there.</p>
<p>Frankly I am tired of beta testing Google&#8217;s android OS and am appalled by their lack of customer service for the number one mobile OS in the world and their Nexus line of phones. Really, all of you should be too.</p>
<p>Then don&#8217;t? Buy a different phone? And telling other people what they &#8220;should&#8221; do is asinine. I like my Desire HD better than I liked my iPhone 4, so, I guess I&#8217;ll keep &#8220;beta testing&#8221;.</p>

At this time iOS only offers Twitter &amp; FaceBook services but if they were to add something else developers will get it for &#8216;free&#8217; with the Social Framework.</p>

<p>Mobile devices have less power, so to make them budget friendly and have better performance, apps are optimized for chips.</p>
<p>It is the same for console vs pc gaming. PC&#8217;s can be easily upgraded with new chips. To avoid people from getting mad about yearly releases, they only release consoles near 10 years (that is the plan, anyways). Do to old hardware, they optimize like crazy. So mobile phones are like consoles, underpowered (not exactly the same, one is due to age and the other is due to space and/or economics), while PC gaming rigs are like general purpose PC&#8217;s (for this analogy, anyways).</p>

<p>Android is just another base level OS upon which to layer Chrome. Chrome OS is more like a technical preview than anything. Chrome on more mature OSes is much more functional at this point.</p>
<blockquote>it just needs to be open for application authors to add new targets (which it is not).</blockquote>
<p>There seems to be some misunderstanding on this point. Apple, effectively, just does this the opposite way of Android (at least for everything but sharing on social networks). The &#8220;Open In&#8230;&#8221; menu is populated with choices of any apps that register their file type capabilities with the OS, so if Evernote wants to be able to open text files, they just have to register that file compatibility with the system, and the other app just has to implement the &#8220;open in&#8221; menu API. It&#8217;s a result of Apple&#8217;s file system sandboxing, and the steps are just different than on Android, only better or worse depending on your workflow.</p>
<p>As for sharing (social networks) that&#8217;s not part of the same API, and could be handled through the iOS app url schemes, but it is not as simple to implement as intents, but I personally think that the separation of the two tasks is actually better on iOS. I don&#8217;t have much interest in sharing a lot of things on social networks, but I do see a lot of value in improving inter-app communication on iOS, and I think the two actions are different enough that, from a UX perspective, they shouldn&#8217;t be lumped in the same &#8220;Share&#8221; menu.</p>
<p>Uh no, jelly bean still isn&#8217;t as smooth as iOS (or WP7). It also maintains the massive amount of response lag endemic to Android, a problem that will never really go away.  And your whole &#8220;city foundation&#8221; comment is silly.  Apple&#8217;s limited number of tightly controlled hardware targets gives them far more flexibility to do whatever they want in software, especially since every device is updated the day a new version of iOS is released.</p>

<p>Why doesn&#8217;t google make the stock android browser, chrome?</p>

<p>I think they left it out of ASOP because that would essentially make Chrome open-source, and allow it&#8217;s design to be modified by OEM&#8217;s like Samsung and HTC.  Not to mention, there could be security problems if that was pure open-source when you think about stuff like how Chrome syncs passwords and stuff.</p>
<p>Perfect answer.</p>
<p>Chromium is open source and OEMs are welcome to do whatever they want with it.</p>
<p>Also, security through obscurity doesn&#8217;t work.</p>
<blockquote>Not to mention, there could be security problems if that was pure open-source when you think about stuff like how Chrome syncs passwords and stuff.</blockquote>
<p>NO! This is a common and HUGE misconception about open source software.</p>
<p>Quite the contrary, open source software on all levels (including kernels such as Linux) are more secure than close source ones. Open source does not mean the user can modify the software while it is running. You cannot modify a login manager to accept any password for instance. Because it has already been compiled and it turned into a binary. It is no more modifiable than a closed source software now. The only advantage a closed source software can have over open source is that it can employ &#8220;security through obscurity&#8221; which is almost universally considered terrible practice.</p>
<p>Besides, stock Browser (which is open source) also does syncing with your Google password.</p>
<p>I take it you&#8217;ve never heard of Chromium&#8230;<br />
You know, the open source project which provides a browser almost identical to Chrome. Because, well, they are the same codebase.</p>
<p>Here, read the FAQ:<br />
<a href="https://developers.google.com/chrome/mobile/docs/faq" target="_blank">https://developers.google.com/chrome/mobile/docs/faq</a><br />

<a href="http://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/AndroidBuildInstructions" target="_blank">http://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/AndroidBuildInstructions</a></p>
<p>As Chris Zielger has said, Chrome is a closed source implentation of the open source Chromium.</p>
