<p>Well, I think I have read somewhere that some Nexus Phones&#8217; updates area aged by Samsung, not Google. The former would rather you just upgrade the phone while the latter prefers you to have the latest update, not caring about buying newer hardware sooner (I think they are called Yakju builds and some other weird name).</p>
<p>Not wishing to feed a troll, but others may find the answer useful. Android receives OTA updates as they are released by the phone carriers. In order to minimize network bandwidth, the carriers stagger the release over several days or sometimes perhaps longer. Installing a ROM upgrade from your computer does not affect the carrier&#8217;s bandwidth, so naturally you can download and install to the millions of devices you allude to. Now that iOS has an OTA update feature, the release will probably be staggered for iPhone users too, but I&#8217;m sure it can still be installed through iTMS as well.</p>
<blockquote>Android receives OTA updates as they are released by the phone carriers.</blockquote>
<p>In the case of the GSM Galaxy Nexus (and all phones sold unlocked in general), carriers have nothing to do with the OTA.</p>
<p>But it is still in the interest of Google in this case to roll the change out slowly at first to make sure there aren&#8217;t widespread problems.  Affect fewer customers if the release is bad instead of causing problems for everyone.  The OTA update still goes over the carrier&#8217;s network, so it is still in everyone&#8217;s interest to roll it out slowly as they do.</p>
<p>They rolled out Jelly Bean to the Galaxy Nexus OTA less than two weeks after announcing it.  iOS 6 was announced when?&#8230;.</p>

<p>Why do you think development lags so far behind Android releases? Even if you&#8217;re experienced with Java getting comfortable working with the SDK takes the better part of a year, and then on top of that you&#8217;ve got to learn all nuances of supporting multiple devices. Honeycomb introduced changes that you wouldn&#8217;t understand without being comfortable with the previous SDKs. Because they introduced things like Fragments that are separate but expand upon existing concepts, so you really can&#8217;t skip getting a clear understanding of the stuff that these new ideas are meant to replace. In a nutshell that is why there&#8217;s been this sort of barrier-to-entry with ICS that didn&#8217;t exist so much in previous versions, but more relevantly why adoption rates are really important. If the install base for 3.0+ devices was higher there would be a bigger push to bring that barrier down.</p>

The camera features are not only interesting with best shot type burst modes &amp; still image from video capability, but the images are just cleaner &amp; videos have less artifacts. This is probably because of the camera greater f ability. It also is true 28mm which makes for a nice image with that includes more of your surroundings, which is great if you are on vacation. <p>Not many developers will be ready to develop for iOS + Android + BB10. Right now they have to choose between BB10 and WP8, Having an Android player gives BB10 an upper hand. Eventually once some of the ported apps are successful, they will put in the extra effort to make a native BB10 app.</p>

<p>Honestly, it isn&rsquo;t that hard to port an Objective-C project to BB10 either: <a href="http://developer.blackberry.com/native/documentation/bb10/porting_ios_intro.html" target="_blank">http://developer.blackberry.com/native/documentation/bb10/porting_ios_intro.html</a></p>
<p>Thing is, I know a lot of people who avoid Objective C. I don&rsquo;t make mobile apps but I imagine i would too</p>
<p>Are these people not building iOS apps? I can&rsquo;t imagine building an iOS app <em>without</em> Obj-C. Apple&rsquo;s Cocoa framework is built for Obj-C. If you want to build an app using just about <em>any</em> of the standard iOS features (like tab bars, navigation controllers, table views, etc), you gotta use Obj-C, or build it from scratch.</p>
<p>The Mono guys have a cross-platform development tool that they claim gives pretty good results&mdash;converting C# to Objective-C, including (most of? many of?) the interfaces to iOS routines.</p>
<p>I don&rsquo;t have personal experience with it, but the Mono team seems <span class="caps">AWFULLY</span> sharp. It&rsquo;s at least imaginable to do it that way.</p>
<p>I haven&rsquo;t used Mono at all. I may have heard of it before, but I never really looked into it.</p>
<p>I personally think that building &ldquo;cross-platform&rdquo; apps is bad practice because each platform has different UI conventions. For instance, I think I could count the number of good cross-platform desktop applications on one hand, and they&rsquo;re mostly web browsers.</p>
<p>My philosophy is that if you want to build a good app for more than one platform, build <em>separate</em> apps for each platform. You&rsquo;ll end up with a better user experience for <em>all</em> your users.</p>
<p>Also, it looks like Mono costs at least $400 if you want to publish your app. Otherwise you&rsquo;re limited to dicking around in the simulator.</p>
<p>You may actually be surprised at what tools exist. There are solutions being made to all things in the world and cross-platform development is one such topic. You can get some great performance from these tools on par with natively built products. It&rsquo;s all a matter of how efficiently you implement these things.</p>
<p>You have to look at it from the point of view from businesses. They don&rsquo;t have a lot of time or maybe even the manpower/resources to devote to developing native apps for all of the major platforms in their native languages. If they could find a solution that would allow them to develop their application on a universal level and penetrate each platform, then you can be damn sure they&rsquo;re going to go for that solution, even if they have to shell out a lot of money. Because in the end, they&rsquo;ll make up what they lost if their app is successful (and much more if it&rsquo;s readily available on all the major platforms).</p>
<p>I mean take a look at something like Xamarin which costs an arm and a leg, but gives you so much damn development power that you don&rsquo;t know what to do with: <a href="http://xamarin.com/" target="_blank">http://xamarin.com/</a></p>
<p>Some people might try to do this in order to keep on using the language they know, however you won&rsquo;t get around ObjC for a native iOS app.</p>
<p>Apart from this: ObjC is a fantastic language. :)</p>

<p>There is no point in security and <span class="caps">BBM</span> if the underlying system isn&rsquo;t considered the most secure and already has a reputation for being prone to malware, as is the case with Android.</p>
<p>As in the case with Apple iPhone as well. How many times do people install apps from the iTunes app store only to realize later that they get notified every second or have popup ads and other annoying sneak up on them.</p>
<p>I think Blackberry has a great chance at carving its own niche again. More BB models should follow but I think they are making headway.</p>

<p>I think the Android runtime is smart, but Blackberry is handling it wrong.</p>
<p>Android apps should be sideload-only. You shouldn&rsquo;t be allowed to submit Android apps to the BB10 store.</p>
<p>That way, as a user, if there&rsquo;s one Android-only app that I <span class="caps">REALLY</span> need, I can install it. But when I&rsquo;m casually browsing the app store to see what&rsquo;s available, I&rsquo;ll only be shown native apps, which will provide a good user experience.</p>
<p>As a developer, I&rsquo;ll have incentive to create native BB10 apps, because I&rsquo;ll know that&rsquo;s the only way to get into the app store.</p>
<p>Everyone wins.</p>
<p>This wouldn&rsquo;t work in the real world because developers have to make money. Sideloading apps wouldn&rsquo;t allow developers to sell their Android apps to BB10 owners. So they would not make them available at all for BB10 owners. Allowing developers to sell their Android apps on BB World was the only possible way for BB to get Android devs on board.</p>

<p>4k and 8k TV makes no sense. VFX shots in a movie are a max of 2k. Even if you scanned all the film in the movie again at 4k, those VFX shots would still be 2k shots that are upscaled. Some films shot on early digital cameras have a resolution cap built in. Many VFX shots in films aren&#8217;t even obvious VFX shots, some rig-removal paint, etc.</p>
<p>People know they&#8217;ll just be paying for upscaling, right?</p>
<p>Well that was true for every other resolution change, &#8220;there is no content on 1080p&#8221; was a common complaint, but content creators adapted fast.</p>
<p>You can just say 1080. Saying &#8220;progressive&#8221; in context of source material is redundant. Scanning mode is just relevant in viewing.</p>
<p>You&#8217;re so right, but it just feels wrong to use numbers without some indicator of what they&#8217;re for.</p>
<p>&#8220;There is no content in 1080 [elephants]&#8221;<br />
&#8220;There is no content in 1080 [of Americas TV channels]&#8221;<br />
&#8220;There is no content in 1080 [degree flips by the world&#8217;s most amazing skateboarders]&#8221;</p>
<p>&#8216;HD 1080&#8217;, &#8216;1080 resolution&#8217; and so on all sound awkward, so the &#8216;p&#8217; serves as a quasi-unit, soothing my mind.</p>
<p>No, that&#8217;s not the same thing. With every other resolution change for consumer television, you could always go back to the higher resolution media and remaster. 1080 is less than 2k. 4k and 8k are greater than 2k theatrical work so you don&#8217;t have the luxury of pulling from higher resolution sources.</p>

<p>The trick to this is, flash Superuser as normal, install <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.koushikdutta.rommanager&hl=en" target="new">Rom Manager</a> and re install CWM from there it will automatically ask you if to move it so you can reboot without loosing your recovery.</p>
<p>Rebooting to Jelly Bean right now on Nexus S 9020T&#8230;For the impatient once like me&#8230;Go to: Settings&#8594;Apps&#8594;All&#8594;Google Service Framework&#8594;Clean cache/data<br />
Then go and search for new updates in Settings&#8594;About&#8594;System Updates<br />
Try this a couple of times and Jelly Bean is yours&#8230;</p>
<blockquote>&#8220;Try this a couple of times&#8221; </blockquote>

<p>by &#8220;this&#8221; I mean do the procedure of clearing the data AND and then search for new updates. It worked a couple of times. I found this procedure in different forums and it works at some time, if the update is available for your device</p>

<p>Well, it looks there haven&#8217;t been any serious comments up to this point, so I&#8217;ll add mine.</p>
<p>CM10 is a great alternative for those brave and patient enough to tinker with a phone and void its warranty. Unfortunately this doesn&#8217;t work for 99% of people. Most people just want a great &#8220;out of the box&#8221; experience. I think it&#8217;s great The Verge is informing people of their options but people need to know how much work it is to install and maintain CM10, and that they could potentially brick their device.</p>
<p>Maintain? Yes, installation can be a tough proposition, especially for devices with complex unlocking procedures. But once it&#8217;s installed, maintainence isn&#8217;t really required. In fact, I&#8217;d say it&#8217;s easier than most stock ROMs  (except Nexus devices), since CM10 now has a built-in OTA updater., and those updates don&#8217;t have to wait for any carrier approval. This actually makes maintenance a possibility, unlike carrier branded devices which just get left to rot with years-old software.</p>
<p>I think the last version I installed was CM7.1, so I didn&#8217;t know about the OTA updater. That&#8217;s pretty nice. I could see how that makes maintenance a breeze.</p>
<p>i&#8217;ve had multiple phones with cm installed on them go back to the manufacturer to repair. Never once have they had a problem with it.</p>
<p>Just for the record, while Cyanogenmod is fairly close to stock, it is nothing like stock Android.  Cyanogenmod is in fact a skinned version of Android with features that aren&#8217;t in stock Android, although the UI is about as close as you can get to stock.  Likewise, AKOP, Bugless Beast, MIUI, Paranoid Android and the like are all skins of Android.</p>
<p>Not all skins of Android are bad and these ROMs show how skinning can be tastefully done.</p>
<p>You can&#8217;t discern the difference between CM and pure stock. Any &#8220;features&#8221; added can be turned on and off. Performance is identical as are All UI elements.</p>
<p>Yes, &#8220;skin&#8221; implies something looks different. CM10 looks and feels virtually identical to JB4.1. There are a couple extras (that can be turned off, try turning anything in Sense/Touchwiz/MotoBlur off), but they don&#8217;t change how the interface in general looks or acts.</p>
<p>I&#8217;ve been running Bugless Beast for a few months and I don&#8217;t know how you can call it a skin.  It&#8217;s visually indentical to stock Jellybean in every way.  There is nothing changed.</p>
<p>You don&#8217;t even know what skinned means.. Please stop trolling.. Skin means theme, font, menu look, launcher, icon and etc changes.. CM has a few small ADDITIONS made to it to cater to the dev crowd. Anyone who is not interested can easily just not use those options</p>
<p>CM actually has some additions (such as multiple user accounts) that are beneficial to non-developers as well.  If you look at some other ROMs, such as the popular MIUI and AKOP (which many Android nerds are moving over to) there are differences in the UI that aren&#8217;t quite within the stock Android standards.</p>
<p>Cyanogenmod also doesn&#8217;t do notification toggles like Google does in Android 4.2.  While Cyanogenmod is 98% of the way to stock Android, it still is a skin, and personally, I feel that Cyanogenmod works better for me than stock Android (I have a Galaxy Nexus).</p>
<p>Ugh, it&#8217;s AOKP, not AKOP. Sorry it really bugs me when it&#8217;s spelled wrong. :) It stands for Android Open Kang Project.</p>

<p>In San Diego, I constantly am getting 20+ up and down still, so I don&#8217;t know when the rate will fall. I don&#8217;t see it looking good past this iPhone launch.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s due to 700mhz spectrum, actually.</p>
<p>700mhz is the reason why Verizon is able to roll out LTE so quickly, as the cell sizes are massive and only a few towers can cover entire cities. On the other hand, there&#8217;s only so much capacity in a given 10mhz block of spectrum. So they have a lot more users per tower than, say, a 1700mhz LTE network would.</p>
<p>Verizon took a shortcut to have a good coverage map which is going to bite them on the capacity front. Eventually they&#8217;re going to roll out LTE on the 1700 band to increase capacity as well, but I wouldn&#8217;t be surprised if things slow down drastically over the next few months.</p>

<p>No money saved, huh? Ok, lets do the math.</p>
<p>$350+$350 = $700. Monthly plan on Straight-Talk (unlimited voice, 2GB data, unl text) which can use either ATT or T-Mobile&#8217;s network (you choose) is $45/mo.</p>
<p>Verizon&#8217;s Galaxy Nexus is $99 today. Cheapest monthly plan is $100/mo for unlimited voice/txt + 2GB data.</p>
<p>Total cost over 2 years for the Verizon route = $2,500.<br />
Total cost over 2 years for the GSM route = $1780<br />
- And that assumes you have to pay the full ETF, and dont change to a cheaper prepaid competitor anytime in those 2 years.</p>
<p>So yes, yes money saved.</p>
<p>clarifying:<br />
1. the $350+$350 refers to $350 for the unlocked Nexus + $350 full ETF.</p>
<p>If you don&#8217;t have to pay the ETF, that drops your total 2 year cost to $1430. If you can keep your minutes to around 100min, then your savings increases even more &#8211; down to $1070 over 2 years.</p>

<p>Google released r6 for instance, just a couple of days ago. You get that on your device by a single click. Why waiting months, either for google or verizon.</p>
<p>My initial root process on my Galaxy Nexus was actually considerably harder than on my old Droid 1. Eventually, of course, the release of the awesome GNex Toolkit made this much, much easier by automating the steps. Anyway, you still have to unlock the bootloader, THEN install a custom recovery (CWM or similar), THEN rename the recovery files so the phone doesn&#8217;t automatically change them back on boot, THEN root, THEN you can finally install Mods. How&#8217;s that easier than other devices, exactly?<br />
Also, it&#8217;s extremely hard to permanently break your phone. As long as you can get back into recovery mode in some fashion, you can always redo the steps, and the stock ROMs are always easily accessible if you decide to backtrack for whatever reason.<br />
The source for Android, as an open product is always made available. True, the drivers and manufacturer skins are proprietary, but the source is always there, via the open-source license.<br />
Cyanogen, for instance, makes official mods for far more phones that are not Nexus versus the ones that are. They don&#8217;t do every phone, true, but it&#8217;s for the most part based on demand and feasibility, so if you research ahead of time and buy a major name brand phone, your chances are pretty good.</p>

<p>Settings &gt; Apps &gt; All Tab &gt; Google Services Framework &gt; Clear Data &gt; Force Stop</p>
<p>Home Button, Kill Settings in Task Manager</p>
<p>Settings &gt; About Phone &gt; Software Update</p>
<p>Give it a couple of tries. Helps if your mobile data is turned off and only your WIFI is on.</p>
<p>Try this&#8230;<br />
Requirements :<br />
Fully stock Galaxy Nexus device<br />
Wifi Connection to download the software update<br />
The Following steps to be Followed :<br />
Go into Setting &#8594; Apps &#8594; All &#8594; Google Services Framework<br />
You will see a button for "Clear Data"; clear it.<br />
Go into your dialer and type <strong>#</strong>#2432546#<strong>#</strong> &#8211; This will cause a ‘force checkin’. You will notice that it shows "checkin succeeded" across the top.<br />
Go back to Setting &#8594; About Phone &#8594; System updates and then click the check now button.</p>

<p>They&#8217;re making it harder and harder to unlock dead people&#8217;s phones.</p>
<p>Face Unlock is a gimmick. Yes, it&#8217;s quick, but it&#8217;s still slower and less reliable that the old trusty pattern lock. I played with it the first day I got my Galaxy Nexus, and then showed it once to a friend who asked about it. That is it.</p>
<p>If you are in good lighting face unlock can unlock the phone in fractions of a second. But most of the time it is a little slower, especially if you&#8217;re in the dark.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s not slower than pattern unlock under the right conditions.</p>
<p>What we need is a passive security method so you can still access the slide unlock with the camera and google now additions. I want this face unlock to get so good and so power efficient that it is always checking and if it doesn&#8217;t recognise someone it requires a PIN. I shouldn&#8217;t even know it is doing it.</p>
<p>I imagine that&#8217;s what they are working towards and why not share their steps towards that goal while working on it?</p>
<p>The PIN is still a weak measure. Do you have any idea how greasy your friends&#8217; hands are? Take a look at anyone&#8217;s screen &#8211; 4 out of 5 times you can guess the unlock pattern just by looking at the smudges.</p>
<p>I like this passive + PIN idea. I always thought it would be cool if they integrated fingerprint scanners (like the kind HP and IBM have been putting in their laptops for years) into the power button, so when you go to wake up the phone it can scan your thumb.</p>
<p>The original Motorola Atrix had a fingerprint scanner.</p>
<p>How is it a gimmick?  Google tells you that it is less secure than a pattern or pin.  But it is absolutely faster then either of them.  Mine unlocks instantaneously.</p>
<p>It is a gimmick because it is a feature that works, but not one that I would depends on. I never says it&#8217;s a gimmick due to it being less secure. I knew that from the very first day.</p>
<p>I don&#8217;t know how people would say that it is not slower than pattern unlock. Perhaps your pattern is way too complicated ( i don&#8217;t see how complicated it can get with 9 points, though). But even in the best lighting condition, it is not faster. And then what with dim lighting? Wait for it to see if it work, and if not, unlock with pin/pattern? How is this convenience, and how is this quick? And I have to have the front facing camera pointing at my face everytime I unlock it?</p>
<p>I&#8217;m not saying it doesn&#8217;t work. It does, and it does well when it does. But it is not useful for getting past lock screen, something that you do a hell lot of times everyday and in very different lighting conditions throughout the day.</p>
<p>You must have a weird face because it works for everyone else.</p>
<p>Also google tell you in the help document which is the most sequre and when to use each one and they don&#8217;t even mention face unlock because it&#8217;s considered a work in progress.</p>
<p>I find it&#8217;s excellent under perfect conditions and lets face it, who carrys a picture you around anyways. The problem is whenever I am at a bar or anywhere that isn&#8217;t well lit I have problems. I also don&#8217;t like seeing my face staring back at me.</p>
<p>Just a side note pattern unlocks aren&#8217;t very (especially if you use all 9 points)  because of all the smudges on the screen. If you want something secure use a 6 number pin that has one number repeated twice or a password.</p>
<p>How is it faster? If you use pattern or pin for a while you become so accustomed to the motion that you can pull your phone out of your pocket, hit the lock switch and already have the pattern complete before you&#8217;ve even seen the phone. It becomes on fluid motion.</p>
<p>Face unlock is instaneous if you do it correctly in the right conditions</p>
<p>Because there&#8217;s nothing to get accustomed to.  As soon as you look at your phone, it&#8217;s unlocked.</p>
<p>With a pattern it&#8217;s unlocked before you&#8217;ve even brought it into a position to look at it. Also, your definition of &#8216;as soon&#8217; must be different from mine because even looking at the phone the delay was long enough that I&#8217;d be able to unlock it with other means faster.</p>

<p>Who is breaking into your phone? The most likely reason someone is going to be breaking into my phone is if Joe Bloggs nicks it off the pub table, or something like that. <p>You don&#8217;t have to pick one or the other &#8212; let&#8217;s just acknowledge that if you choose the HTC or Samsung experience, you&#8217;ll wait longer for upgrades. <p>We&#8217;re already seeing early Jelly Bean builds for the One X and S III. Fully-functioning ROMs should be here in a month or two. So the tradeoff between the latest updates and the latest hardware isn&#8217;t all that bad after all.</p>

<p>Here are my thoughts, in a nutshell:</p>
<p>Software can be changed, <em>hardware </em>cannot.  Though greatly tempted by the unlocked Galaxy Nexus, I couldn&#8217;t get over the fact that the One X has a notably better screen and camera. <p>I still don&#8217;t understand why Samsung and Google insisted on putting such a sub-par camera in the Galaxy Nexus. <p>I know I&#8217;ll get Jellybean, either officially or unofficially, soon enough. I&#8217;d rather have better hardware that takes longer to get updates, then lesser hardware that will be updated faster.</p>

<p>the ONLY things that apple does better than google is closing off their ecosystem and their build quality.</p>
<p>iPhones are made of high quality materials like metal and glass, whereas 90% of android phones are made of cheap plastic (looks at samsung). In addition to this, all the iphones are designed very similar to eachother, so 3rd party accessories are easily made for the platform.</p>
<p>By closing off their ecosystem, developers only have to worry about making apps compatible with a select few devices (iPhone and iPad and their older variants). <br />
In comparison, everyone and their mom makes android devices. The hardware they put on their devices is their own choice. Because of this, developers have to choose the more popular devices to support. This effects the phone update process aswell. Some android phones may never get updated, so unless you buy a nexus series phone you can never be sure. <br />
All iOS devices get updated for at least 2 generations after.</p>
<p>Other than this, iOS lacks in many ways:<br />
-No way of putting attachments into already open draft emails <br />
-no way of downloading files off of the internet <br />
-no way of disabling the text message sending sound (without disabling all sounds)<br />
-no way of setting everything on silent quickly (gotta set it all individually in the options menu)</p>
<p>Even blackberry 5 has most of these basic features.</p>
<p>Hopefully when the rumoured Nexus line comes out this autumn we won&#8217;t need to have this debate, as long as the OEMs go hard on specs.</p>
<p>I hate to say someone&#8217;s opinion is wrong&#8230; But Chris is wrong. I&#8217;ve owned HTC and Samsung phones, both with Sense and TouchWiz. It wasn&#8217;t until I owned the Nexus S that I discovered what Android was meant to be. Hardware is great, but if you don&#8217;t have good software, the phone is gonna run like shit anyway. My Nexus S ran at a smooth 60fps most of the time, while my Evo 3D used to struggle to hit 30fps. So last year, the stock Android experience was superior simply because of performance. The Galaxy S III&#8217;s grating &#8220;nature UX&#8221; is so intrusive, it&#8217;s annoying, and Sense just looks outdated. Both of the new skins run just fine, but are far less visually appealing than stock ICS or JB. The icons in Sense STILL look like they should belong on Windows XP. I know it&#8217;s a small gripe, but as a graphic designer, I just couldn&#8217;t purchase either one of those devices knowing that I have to look at gradient-crazy, faux glass, visuals every day. Then there&#8217;s the whole update situation. My Nexus S had ICS before the Galaxy S III came out, and my new Galaxy Nexus is already running Jelly Bean. The work done on the backend of Android with 4.1 make the aging GNex just as smooth (if not more so) than the GSIII or the One X, all but rendering their powerful specs completely irrelevant. What&#8217;s the point of having the specs if they don&#8217;t translate to a smoother user experience? There isn&#8217;t one. Now, if the Galaxy SIII ends up getting 4.1 in the next few weeks, then it&#8217;ll be a truly formidable device. But it won&#8217;t. The GSIII and One X will be lucky to get 4.1 when the next version of Android (key lime pie?) drops. By then, the Galaxy Nexus will be lined up to receive KLP while the GSIII and One X will just be getting JB. I&#8217;m not going out on a limb here. That&#8217;s what&#8217;s gonna happen. I&#8217;ll take state of the art software over hardware any day, because in the end, it&#8217;s what ends up on screen and how THAT functions that interests me. You can have a quad core under the hood, but if the UI, and software features are slower, less enjoyable, then what the hell is the point?</p>

<p>It comes down to the question, does having the latest and greatest hardware trump having the latest and greatest software? Generally speaking, the Galaxy Nexus hardware will survive the 2-year contract time of the phone and remain viable for running all apps and most games in that time.</p>
<p>The reverse isn&#8217;t true though, awesome hardware won&#8217;t likely see Android support for the full 2-years of the contract depending on the state of Android updates. You are lucky if your non-nexus phone is supported 1 year out from release. If it sees an Android update, it is likely at least 6 months upon release of the source, and if it does see that update, it likely won&#8217;t see the next.</p>
<p>I personally choose OS updates, both carrier supported and with developer support, over hardware, assuming the hardware isn&#8217;t awful to start with. Sure the GNex hardware is getting long in the tooth, especially considering the GPU was a bit disappointing to start, but in general the hardware will stand up and the software will continue to be supported when the likes of the others likely will not be.</p>
<p>I take the side of updates and developer support but the reality is more people buy a phone, expect to keep it for 2 years, and expect it not to change too much. Apple perpetuates that with their updates that don&#8217;t  really add but a few new features, and lock some of those features out depending on which device you have. In Android world, it is perpetuated by the carriers/OEMs being slow to update, or not updating at all.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s only the small but vocal minority that actually get in an uproar about OS updates. A good bit of people who buy these phones just want the latest greatest, thereby making the likes of the SIII and the OneX the &#8220;best.&#8221;</p>

<p>What this is really about: Hardware vs. software.</p>
<p>I won&#8217;t argue for a second that the Galaxy Nexus is &#8220;old&#8221; in terms of hardware by now. It has been comprehensively bettered. But, I&#8217;m not convinced that really matters. Most phones these days are more or less the same in terms of hardware. Every generation of flagship phones brings with it the latest and greatest processors, more RAM, bigger/higher resolution screens, and the next generation is generally just an iteration on what already exists. There are few hardware features on phones that truly add a dramatic increase in functionality. Software, on the other hand, completely changes the experience. Software is what you actually use. Sure, better hardware will run it better. But, in the case of the non-Nexus Android flagships, they simply don&#8217;t have access to the superior software the Nexus has. It&#8217;s like sticking a great engine in a shit car. Sure, it&#8217;ll be powerful, but it ultimately doesn&#8217;t matter because the rest of the experience is inferior.</p>
<p>Of course, if you actually prefer Touchwiz or Sense, this argument is moot. Use it if you like it. But, the general consensus seems to be that Google&#8217;s un-diluted Android is the way to go. It&#8217;s a consensus I do agree with. Were I to buy an Android phone, I&#8217;d feel much more secure about purchasing a Galaxy Nexus than anything else. It&#8217;s longevity and on-going support are HUGE assets that HTC and Samsung have yet to really offer on their own flagships. Their track records suck.</p>
<p>Yep I got my friends 2010 Samsung Vibrant running 4.0 this week and it runs very smooth.</p>

<p>Companies like Google, Samsung, Apple, HTC, Sony, LG: the companies that make the devices we want are held back by outrageous rules from the wireless carriers. In the end these unethical business practice come down to the following ethical violations:</p>
<p>1. The wireless spectrum belongs to the public. <br />
2. Requiring a data plan is unethical if the customers is willing to pay the full retail price of the phone. <br />
3. Price fixing between carriers make the data costs similar no matter which service provider you go with. <br />
4. A lack of real competition keeps the price of mobil data artificially high while service quality is affected by poor network coverage and slow access speeds. <br />
5. While 4G is better than 3G, both technologies are inefficient in terms of power consumption, causing range anxiety with smartphone users: this does not have to be the case: smaller towers located closer together reduce the phones tranmissions power requirements and give end users longer battery life. <br />
6. The lack of HD voice quality services is inexplicable, and evidence of technological lagging and innovation surpression on behalf of the big 4. <br />
7. Our elected officials in the FCC, Congress and Senate are pandering to the special interests (the big 4 and others) that bribe them : this is not a democracy : lobby = briber = oligarchy.</p>

<p>These kind of topics could really use a poll though&#8230;</p>
<p>It&#8217;s extremely subjective. One person may not care about specs as much as the other, rather being interested in updates and how long their phone will last them or how well it works for them while the other person finds solace in the fact that they&#8217;re running a quad-core cpu or 2GB of RAM etc. Some of us want both. We want top specs along with a guarantee that the phones software will be upgrades as long as it&#8217;s possible. To each his own. Over the span of time of my owning smartphones, I&#8217;ve been all 3 types. I currently consider myself to be the latter.</p>
<p>I think Chris is right in that layering doesn&#8217;t matter too much anymore. It mattered a lot when they were heavy and sucked. They used to take up heaps of very important memory (and in some cases, even storage) and weren&#8217;t really worth it vs. what they changed in the OS, but now most of them are thoughtful and actually give vanilla a better experience.</p>
<p>Vlad is correct also in stating that Android 4.0 is not enough. Devices like these should really have the ability to utilize an upgraded OS and firmware as soon as they are available. You just don&#8217;t get that on a non-Nexus device right now. This is at the fault of OEMs and Carriers *(O&amp;Cs). Because of that, the Galaxy Nexus may well end up being a &#8220;better running&#8221; device than even the GS3 and One X. We&#8217;ll have to see the benchmarks when they&#8217;re out or hear from people that don&#8217;t own the device (unbiased).</p>
<p>In a perfect world, O&amp;Cs would be on the ball regarding updates. Consumers wouldn&#8217;t need to worry about OS updates. The only thing the consumer needs to be concerned with are personal preferences like the look, feel, features and specs of their potential device. Bearing the Nexus name would carry no real stock because every phone would get the next Android asap. In this world, Chris would be right.</p>
<p>If you look at what most Android users complain about, it&#8217;s the terrible statistic showing how stagnant updates tend to be. This is getting much better currently, but it&#8217;s still a sore spot. Many phones which could easily be updated to the next Android or even the current version of Android, are still on the version the phones are sold with. It takes O&amp;Cs months upon months generally to get to the current version and that&#8217;s if they bother at all. If it&#8217;s anything we&#8217;ve seen it&#8217;s that updates can breathe new life into these devices. I have an A500 and ICS vs. Honeycomb were day and night. The tablet is just so much peppier with ICS. If it were the case where they didn&#8217;t do much then it&#8217;d still be bad, but not SO bad.<br />
This is the current world we&#8217;re in, where it seems like O&amp;Cs don&#8217;t really give much of an eff after the phones leave the shelf. In this world the Nexus at least gives it&#8217;s owners something to look forward to. They know that in most scenarios, as long as their phones hardware can handle it, they&#8217;ll be able to upgrade to whatever innovative new features the next Android has to offer and on that, I would agree.</p>
<p>I would rather own the device with a guarantee of getting updates than the device with technically faster hardware, but no guarantee that it will get updates down the line.<br />
Let&#8217;s face it. Gone are the days when all we had to appreciate was the phone for what it had currently (as in, when it was sold to us). These are smartphones, they&#8217;re in some ways, mobile computers and we demand more (as we should). Just as we expect our computers to be upgradeable to the next version of Windows or Linux or OSX, we expect our smartphones to be upgradeable to the next version of Android and the next and the next until the OS can  simply no longer run on the hardware (due to speed, memory or gpu restraints)&#8230;and rightfully so. We invest a lot into these things, whether it&#8217;s raw cash or being locked into a contract or a little of both.</p>
<p>In the end, both of you are right on many levels but you&#8217;re also wrong on a few. I agree and identify more with Vlad because personally, I think it&#8217;s the software that drives and gives the hardware power and while what some may consider the best phones right now are hotter in terms of the tech they use and their superpowers as smartphones, the one thing they lack (quick software updates) will make them eventually fall behind the Nexus in terms of what Android has to offer. So the best phone is whatever the consumer prefers For some it will be the phone that guarantees the update (the galaxy nexus) while for others it is the phone with the fastest hardware and extra features (GS3, One S/X, etc.).</p>

<p>&#8220;Yes, the Galaxy S III is running an operating system based on Android 4.0, but I&#8217;m not sure I&#8217;d call it an Android 4.0 phone — it&#8217;s an Android-based phone running Nature UX&#8221;</p>
<p>Ummmm, no.  The UI is different, but the underlying OS is the same.</p>
<p>OS is not just about the underlying  stuff.</p>
<p>Very true, the Nature UX is essentially just a Samsung supported linux distro.</p>
<p>It would have been brilliant to see the Android/Smartphone wars in a desktop context years ago. The most significant differences between linux on the desktop and on the phone is the following:</p>
<p>1. Standardization. Since most linux running smartphones use Android, that helps to provide a consistent set of system utilities and other pieces of software in the stack. Desktop linux has the LSB and can even have software remain portable despite there not being one, but it seems to be a lot more simpler on the phone for some reason.</p>
<p>2. It comes shipped on the hardware. If linux ever took/takes off on the desktop then we would see the same things happening to it that happens to Android.</p>
<p>3. Consistency in the core experience. Despite the different OEM skins/customizations, many of our Android interactions are extremely similar across many phones. If linux ever took off on the desktop, manufacturers would begin to skin it/bring differentiation once there&#8217;s a market for it. My experience is only anecdotal (I work IT on a helpdesk), but some people can&#8217;t configure their wifi without the Dell Wireless Utility. Give them a machine without it and they&#8217;re clueless.</p>
<p>In a perfect world all android phones will get the upgrades as quick as possible. Unfortunately we don&#8217;t live in a perfect world, but buying the Galaxy Nexus will make you feel ahead of the curve and it gives you a better user experience. The android world is devided in hardware updates vs software updates. Because of the imminent release of better hardware and the limit to the amount of money one can spend, some users opt for getting software updates to get a better user experience in comparison to hardware upgraders who want better performance. Software updates are free, hardware upgrades are expensive.</p>

<p>Reading Vlad&#8217;s point of view has made me look at Android phones differently and I agree that the future of Android will not just be a one OS echo-system, but at the same time I feel that this applies only if you look at these phones as just a phone and nothing else.</p>
<p>What makes these phones so amazing is on the development end. The OS is the basic platform and what powers all the great apps created by developers, but I feel that the true power of any phone or OS is it&#8217;s apps. For too long Android has sufford over it&#8217;s app echo-system or lack there of, just because of the fragmentation that goes on. Developers overlook developing for Android many times because of the daunting task that it takes to wrap your head around multiple screen sizes, variable resolutions, and worst of all running outdated operating systems.</p>
<p>So not only do Android users miss out on certain apps that are beautifully build for iOS, but sometimes the apps that are created for Android have memory leak issues, spamming of data and many other random problems. I&#8217;m a proponent of a closed system if it means that developers can focus on building great products and user experience and not if the 1px line will or will not show up because of screen size or resolution.</p>
<p>Building a great product has so many things involved in it and being able to focus on just your product and not be held back by distractions or limitations is what makes any OS and phone a great product. Say what you will about Apple, but they have the right idea and 5 years later it has been proven to work. Take away the phone and the OS and your still left with amazing apps the help people everyday. I&#8217;m far from ever saying something like that about Android. I hope it gets there, but until developing for it because as easy and efficient as it is for iOS no phone no matter how powerful will still just be a phone that makes phone calls well&#8230;hopefully.</p>
<p>I care about these things:<br />
1.. Buttery experience<br />
2. Interface design that is cohesive with industrial design<br />
3. Features (new notifications)<br />
4. Battery life<br />
GNex actually beats every other phone on everything BUT battery life. Tests show it lasts 3 hours of browsing. Dealbreaker.</p>

<p>Those of you who think Samsung has their act together with the design of Touchwiz Nature UX are crazy. Got the Verizon GS3 a couple days ago and it offends the senses (software look-wise, hardware is great). All UI mods that they&#8217;ve done that differ from stock are just plain ugly.</p>
<blockquote>The stock Ice Cream Sandwich user interface hasn&#8217;t been bettered by either HTC or Samsung, which renders their spec supremacy largely irrelevant and leads to the absurdity of community ROM makers having to work to remove their skinning alterations. </blockquote> <p>&#8212; Vlad Savov</p>
<p>The above statement is only partially true. I agree that neither HTC nor Samsung have improved the ICS stock interface, nor Jelly Bean&#8217;s for that matter. However, the last statement from that quote, that this leads or requires a custom ROM to remove HTC&#8217;s or Sammy&#8217;s skins is patently false.  All a Samsung Galaxy S III owner needs to do to avoid TouchWiz is to install <a href="https://play.google.com/store/search?q=nova+launcher" target="new">Nova Launcher</a> or <a href="https://play.google.com/store/search?q=apex+launcher" target="new">Apex Launcher</a> from the Google Play store to return to a near ICS stock launcher experience. Both launchers can be customized to a user&#8217;s particular preference above and beyond the ICS stock launcher. But if left with their default settings, both launchers provide a near ICS stock appearance, and are fast and reliable with no perceptible drain on the battery.  This statement is not true for the HTC One X, primarily because HTC&#8217;s Sense overlay has hooks into the Android kernel for multitasking, etc&#8230;. I use  Nova Launcher as my default launcher on my SGS3 and love the experience.</p>
<p>Because of my job, I have both a Galaxy Nexus and a Galaxy S3. They both have their advantages, and drawbacks. So much so that I don&#8217;t believe one phone can be justified as superior over the other. It basically comes down to this:</p>
<ul>
	<li>The SGS3 (GT-i9300) has the superior camera, CPU (in particular the international quad core version), battery life, and expandable storage experience.</li>
	<li>The GSM Pentaband (GT-i9250) SGNx has the superior stock software experience, and upgradeability.</li>
</ul>
<p>Pick your poison.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m beginning to think that Android&#8217;s plaguing performance issues are due to resolution, not sheer horsepower. Could the OS have some kind of hangup related to higher res displays?</p>
<p>It&#8217;s possible that the GPU isn&#8217;t all that well-suited to powering a 1920&#215;1200 display. That&#8217;s a lot more pixels than the 1366&#215;768 displays we see on most non-iPad tablets. That&#8217;s also likely why no Windows RT tablets have been introduced with 1080p+ displays.</p>
<p>Snapdragon S4 Pro should have no issue at that resolution. And the 5xxx series Exynos.</p>
<p>This is quite likely to be the reason; a composited UI at high resolution takes a hefty GPU and decent memory bandwidth. High-clocked Tegra 3s like this are competitive GPU-wise with the Apple A5, but not with the A5X, which is used in the iPad 3 and is twice as fast. The A5X, very unusually, also has a 128bit memory bus; most high-end SoCs (including the A5 and probably the A6) have a 64bit bus, and the Tegra 3 has a 32bit one.</p>
<p>There&#8217;s no off-the-shelf part for OEMs to use which can match the A5X on GPU performance, though the S4 Pro should when it&#8217;s available; there are also no off-the-shelf parts which can match it on memory bandwidth. This will probably change over the next year.</p>
<p>My Atrix HD works pretty well with HDMI out to my monitor&#8230; Meaning its powering a 1080p 25&quot; screen and a 720p 4.5&quot; screen. <br />
But that&#8217;s with a Qualcomm S4, not a Tegra -might be the GPU is more optimized for HD. <br />
Also, it does lag sometimes, but always as a result of 3rd party apps, or trying to take 60fps video&#8230; Something it can do(rather amazing for a phone, imho), but which caused it to almost completely crash, and stop responding to input. I did stupidly havE a bunch of other apps open when I tried, though.</p>

<p>I sold a &#8216;the new iPad&#8217; so I could buy the Infinity because I couldn&#8217;t seamlessly edit Google Docs with iOS. And yes, before anyone asks, I tried the litany of document editing apps in the App Store, even paying $20 for one of them but they either wouldn&#8217;t handle synchronizing properly and create multiple versions of the doc or the formatting wouldn&#8217;t translate well between the browser-based editor and my local editor.  Also, the keyboard experience with the Infinity is far superior to the iPad+BT keyboard as it feels designed in from the beginning as opposed to being half-baked with the iPad. Even with all that the overall experience was better with the iPad (I still miss the multi-touch gestures on the iPad to close apps and go to the most-recently-used apps) but the Infinity is much more functional given my unique needs.</p>
<p>Oh, and yes, I know Google recently released an update to the Drive app on iOS to allow editing locally but I haven&#8217;t tried it.</p>
<p>If I had one bone to pick with how this (and similar full sized android tablet) reviews, it is that the tendency to be compare the  device to the iPad empirically distorts the reality that very few people are going to use two full size tablets interchangeably. By most measures (gross tablet apps available, PPI, mindshare) this tablet trails the new iPad, but that is not the full story of this device. I think David was fair in his criticisms &#8211; and his praise &#8211; of this device (save a few exceptions), but I would argue that he failed to answer the question, &#8220;Does the Transformer Infinity effectively do what it aims to do?&#8221;  My answer would be a qualified <a href="(since">yes</a> the Jelly Bean update) the Infinity is the best &#8220;light laptop&#8221; on the market, although it could do some things better.</p>
<p>Comparing the Infinity to the iPad really is apples to oranges (lame pun intended). Though both technically work as stand alone tablet devices, the iPad is clearly not designed to be used with a keyboard and the Infinity was designed specifically for hybrid functionality. The fact is though they are comparable on price, the Infinity is $100 less expensive (or $50 more expensive with the dock) for both the 32 and 64 GB Wi-Fi models &#8211; the iPad really is built exclusively for touch input whereas the Infinity has more in common with the soon-to-market Windows 8 hybrid devices. In this way, it makes as much sense criticizing the iPad for lack of secondary battery and trackpad as it does criticizing the Infinity for not having the same breadth of software as the iOS device.</p>
<p>Google has built Android to be scaled to a multitude of devices, which is both a blessing and a curse. The Blessing is that the same OS can power phones, PMPs, tablets, hyrids, and set top boxes. The curse is that many of us users (and even many developers) conflate a flexible OS with flexible software (and for that matter hardware) and that dog don&#8217;t hunt. Google TV has different use cases, power requirements, and limitations than an android phone, and the same is true for tablets and hybrids. Androids app situation is clearly less than ideal (with lots of blame to go around) but this is a different discussion; the question before us is &#8220;Does the Infinity succeed as a hybrid?&#8221;</p>
<p>I live in New York City and ride public transit almost exclusively and often for long trips. My work requires that I have persistent access to email and voicemail, engage in some &#8220;light computing&#8221; (accessing spreadsheets, word processing, viewing things on YouTube), and that I maintain a social media presence while I am out and about, and occasionally requires more intensive computing (which I can almost always put off until I am out of the field and back in an office environment).  In short, I feel like I am the perfect test case for a hybrid device and for me the Infinity is the best option available.</p>
<p>For all the talk of what Android lacks in terms of ecosystem, for my money it is the most capable for someone who prefers the cloud to carting around a full sized laptop. There are a plethora of choices for purchasing/ streaming music and movies, and books, Chrome, Gmail, Google Voice, and now Maps (!) sync  across cloud for something approximating the ever-elusive continuous client utopia, and I can have access up to 100 GBs of my own music, while playing a video game during the commute home. Though there is no US Infinity variant with LTE, much improved WiFi and Bluetooth (thanks to the redesign), GPS, and seriously bonkers battery life ( with the dock handy, you can spend all day watching 1080p movies at automatic brightness and stream the audio over Bluetooth with WiFi, GPS, and background syncing on and you&#8217;ll have to worry more about getting fired for watching movies all day before you worry about running out of juice) is a device that takes full advantage of the myriad content available through Google Play.</p>
<p>This is not to say the Infinity is perfect, nor is it for everyone. Before the Jelly Bean update the device while by no means unusable, had too many performance issues (random app crashes, device restarts) related to stability. Unfortunately, some of those persist, but they have been tremendously reduced. In my experience, Jelly Bean has greatly reduced lag &#8211; and lag specifically related to touch input), but it the OS itself is more computationally intensive. The result is a device that seems to be faster but is not measurably more efficient. For me, I sometimes forget that I am using a hybrid and not a full laptop, only to be reminded of this reality when it try to quickly navigate between 4 or 5 apps. For me, this use case reaffirms the reality that hybrids and tablets are still immature products, but it does not condemn the Infinity; after all is there another full HD device on the market that can multitask better? The answer, new iPad included, is no.</p>
<p>It would be great if folks developed apps for Android with the express knowledge although the OS supports multiple form factors, your app may not &#8211; especially if it was built for phone first. Google bares responsibility for this as their new tablet guidelines seem to acknowledge, and so do developers. Twitter for instance, sucks on iPad as much as it sucks on Android tablets and it is a market leader in social as well on on both platforms. Still, the app story is only part of the Infinity story: the larger narrative is that Asus has pioneered a new class of ARM powered tabet-laptop hybrid devices and the Infinity &#8211; with Jelly Bean- is not only their best iteration, it is the best device in the class available for purchase today.  Surely, there will be stiff competition from Windows 8 devices &#8211; some even made by Asus &#8211; but for users who need the flexibility of a hybrid, the ubiquity of a battery-sipping lightweight full-keyboard device, and the usefulness of Google&#8217;s cloud productivity offerings, this is by far the best device you can buy today and should be the device you measure future hybrids running Windows or iPad-keyboard combos against.</p>
<p>(Written on an Asus TF 700.)</p>
<blockquote> the Infinity is the best "light laptop" on the market/blockquote&gt;<br />

<p>Perhaps i should have said &#8220;laptop light&#8221; &#8211; either way I mean a device that is built to handle simple to moderate productivity-related computational tasks, provide full screen access to media content, and is built to include mobile use cases (long battery life, lightweight, GPS functionality). If you read (my admittedly long-winded post) I believe there is a place in the market between ultrabooks and tablets and this device is fills that place better than anything else currently available.</p>
<p>An Ultrabook/Macbook AIr performs your &#8220;laptop light&#8221; function much better.<br />
The only advantage this has is the ability to remove the keyboard and use a touchscreen.<br />
Against it it has a poor range of apps and functionality versus a laptop and a poor aspect ratio for tablet use</p>
<p>I humbly disagree  that 1)Macbook Airs/ ultrabooks are &#8220;laptop lights&#8221; and 2) that they fill the requirements of a &#8220;laptop light&#8221; better. Core I5 and I7 devices are simply in a different power consumption/ computational class. Though some are &#8220;thin and light&#8221; they are frankly full power machines &#8211; and comparing them to ARM powered tablet -notebook hybrids is kind of silly. Form-factor aside, you are essentially comparing the chip architecture of the iPhone and iPad to that of Apple&#8217;s &#8220;pro-sumer&#8221; notebooks. There is a reason the Infinity with dock cost about half what a decent ultrabook does.</p>
<p>I would also add that the ability to remove the keyboard is not trivial, it creates the opportunity to use the device in a whole host of use cases clam-shell notebooks are ill-suited for, while providing the markedly better typing options than tablets.</p>
<p>Lastly,  Android 4.x is optimized for the 16 &#215; 9 aspect ratio. To say that that aspect ratio is poor for tablets without qualification is just an articulation of your preference.  The OS is built to allow scrollable &#8211; and now dynamically resizeable &#8211; widgets that, in  my opinion, look great in both landscape and portrait  orientation at 16 &#215; 9. For me, homescreen access to my calendar, email, voicemail, RSS feed, and Chrome shortcuts is in itself a &#8220;killer app.&#8221; What&#8217;s more, these widgets work better (in terms of how much information is presented and ease of touch navigation ) in widescreen presentation. And of course, watching HD video content is dramatically improved in 16 &#215; 9 as compared to 4 &#215; 3.</p>
<p>More than just disagreeing with you, I am trying to make the point that there is real market for devices in this hybrid class (and it sure looks like Microsoft agrees). Asus worked with Google to create a great tablet (Nexus  7), but what they have done on their own with the Transformer line is to be the first OEM to produce a viable hybrid device in the modern mobile landscape &#8211; and with the Infinity running 4.1 I believe they have come as close to great without being great as is possible.</p>

<p>In simple terms, coupled with the dock/keyboard, the Transformer Infinity 700 marries the best of two worlds- tablet and netbook. As a tablet it offers exquisite touch screen clarity, brightness, color and balance, smooth/fast performance, reliability and overall superb form, fit and function design. As a netbook, it offers support for unlimited storage expansion, a well integrated keyboard and the ability to experience the superb Android ecosystem of applications, notifications and interactivity.</p>
<p>The only comparable product is Microsoft’s Surface tablet. In comparison there are pros and cons. The Android ecosystem has far more breadth. However Windows 8 on the Surface may offer more interoperability with a desktop running Windows 8. The Surface’s characteristics as a tablet such as screen quality and responsiveness are inferior to the Transformer Infinity. The overall designs of both the Transformer and the Surface have pros and cons.</p>
<p>Both products and the approach they represent have the potential to more effectively move the tablet from a consumption device to a true productivity/content creation device- effectively combining the power and interactivity of a tablet with the productivity of a netbook/laptop.</p>

<p>PenTile <em>is</em> a big deal until the PPI reaches a ridiculous number (much higher than 300), and at that point, the subpixel density will have reached the same level as it would have with a 300 PPI display with an RGB subpixel layout.</p>
<p>The point: you can&#8217;t make a display look as clear as another display using less subpixels.</p>

<p>With the exception of the iPod Photo, they always stuck with &#8216;iPod&#8217; as the name, and would parenthetically refer to the generation as needed only when it came to denoting accessory compatibility in the Apple Store.  Until, of course, they changed the product&#8217;s name to iPod classic.</p>
<p>iPods weren&#8217;t officially called iPod 2G 3G etc, only customers called them that, they were just iPods (or iPod Photo, iPod Color or iPod w/ Video) as they only sold one generation</p>

<p>If you bought the phone upfront for £389.95 and had a £10/month SIM only deal (see GiffGaff), then you start saving money after 19 months (vs £31/month), 17 months (vs £33/month) and 16 months (vs £36/month).</p>

<p>Nexus 4 &#215; 2 = 8gb<br />
Nexus 5 &#215; 2 = 10gb</p>
<p>duh</p>
<p>storage = 2 ^ (7 &#8211; nexus)</p>
<p>duh</p>
<p>Umm&#8230;what?</p>
<p>^ means &#8220;to the power of&#8221;</p>
<p>Nexus 4: 2 ^ (7 &#8211; 4) = 8 GB<br />
Nexus 5: 2 ^ (7 &#8211; 5) = 4 GB</p>

<p>I think another thing to note is that iOS and Android have different philosophies when it comes to updating older, less-capable hardware. If you have a 2-year old iPhone and a new version of iOS is released, you may not be able to run all of the features, but you still get an update and it still counts as the latest version. For Android devices, if your phone is considered less than capable of running the lastest software, you won&#8217;t get it at all. It&#8217;s more all or nothing. So a good proportion of all iOS devices aren&#8217;t actually running the latest software because they don&#8217;t have all the latest features. Fortunately for iOS users, you still get as much of the new software as is reasonable instead of just nothing at all.</p>
<p>And main advantage is access to all all the new APIs, so it&#8217;s really convenient for developers.</p>
<p>The other difference is that most of the core apps (mail, maps, etc) are not part of the OS so they can be upgraded independently of the os core update.</p>

<p>Apart from you being incorrect about Linux, you are right Android will do to iOS what Windows did to Mac&#8230; and Apple will probably end up with a hugely profitable 5-10% of the market and Android will have ~90% with a few percentage points for the &#8216;others&#8217;</p>
<p>People seem to forget that marketshare numbers are typically seasonal with iPhone releases.  Q3 is Apple&#8217;s worst quarter right now because it is the tail end of the product cycle.  Keep in mind that in Q3, 45% of Verizon smartphone sales were iPhone and over 75% of AT&amp;T smartphone sales were iPhone.  Also keep in mind that the world-wide numbers for Android are based on estimates by analysts since no Android manufacturer reports quarterly sales numbers on Android smartphones.</p>
<p>If you look at the full year rather than quarters, you can factor out seasonality.  World-wide iPhone is sitting at about 20% to 25% on an annual basis (when you include the monster quarters following an iPhone release).  However, iPhone has very little penetration in markets like China, India, and Brazil because Apple is just now rolling out iPhone in those markets on a larger scale.</p>
<p>The market in India alone represents a huge base for Samsung.  But the Android phones that are selling in India are very low-cost smartphones to account for the currency conversion and average income.  Apple will never compete with those models in much the same way that Porsche will never compete with GM&#8217;s economy cars.  Sure GM builds the Corvette, Cadillacs, and Yukons on the high-end, but they also produce a lot of low-end stuff.  The low-end stuff will outsell the flagship models in large quantities.</p>
<p>Samsung is like GM &#8212; they cover the whole spectrum.  Other Android manufacturers specifically attack the low-end market in China and India and don&#8217;t bother competing with the flagship phones.  Apple only produces a flagship model.</p>
<p>The marketshare of &#8220;flagship&#8221; phones looks very different.  And the US market showing such a high percentage of iPhone on the two largest carriers in iPhone&#8217;s worst quarter is telling because the US market tends to buy the flagship smartphones from the top manufacturers.</p>
<p>In short:</p>
<p>1) Android market share cannot be determined because no manufacturer reports numbers on a quarterly basis (I wonder why that is).  All we have are estimates that have not been grounded in actual numbers for three years.</p>
<p>2) iPhone market share in a flagship-model-heavy market like the USA is extremely high.</p>
<p>3) Does anybody really care about $40 off-contract phones that get loaded with Gingerbread to run the Calendar app?  If Apple gave away an iPhone that had iOS but could only run the built-in apps and it had a cruddy processor and hardware, would anybody consider that &#8220;iOS market share&#8221;?  Probably not.</p>
<p>Market share can be reported, and is being reported, it&#8217;s about 70% worldwide and as much as iOS sells more each year&#8230; Android sells even more than that.</p>
<p>Unless WP8 gains traction&#8230; and I don&#8217;t see anyone talking about it outside of paid bloggers, shills and tech jerk-circle site then Android&#8217;s growth in share will carry on.</p>
<p>this doesn&#8217;t mean Apple&#8217;s declining, it&#8217;s still selling its phones in ever increasing numbers &#8211; it&#8217;s just that everyone else is too.</p>
<p>To determine market share you need unit sale numbers.  The only manufacturer providing those on a quarterly basis is&#8230;. wait for it&#8230;. Apple.  So what is being reported is estimates from analysts on what they tried to reverse from revenue numbers to try guess a profit margin on an average device without knowing which devices are considered Android smart phones.  So no&#8230; an accurate market share number cannot be reported, but is likely in the 60% to 70% range currently as a best guess and probably closer to 50% when you factor out the garbage phones.</p>
<p>If you look at the top-end devices&#8230;. Samsung sold 30M Galaxy S3&#8217;s in 5 months (we don&#8217;t know which quarter and our best guess is 6M per month which yields about 18M last quarter).  That was the first quarter Samsung had the S3 in a significant number of markets (including the USA) and they sold 18M units (this is an actual hard number we have &#8212; one of the few).  In that same quarter, Apple&#8217;s aging iPhone 4S sold about the same number of units with the iPhone 5 tacking on another 8M units on top of that for a total of 26M units.</p>
<p>We know for a fact that HTC&#8217;s One X sold badly despite it being a high-quality phone (my personal favorite Android phone) &#8212; we know this from revenue numbers.  We also know that Nexus devices like the Galaxy Nexus sold in small quantities from the court documents showing it was no threat to Apple.  That leaves us with Motorola RAZR/RAZR MAXX and then a host of garbage phones to compare against.</p>
<p>This is my point.  I&#8217;m not going to compare iPhone to some $40 Android phone sold in a third-world country because that $40 Android phone does not matter to anybody except Google&#8217;s activation count.  That $40 phone is not going to sway app developers and it is not going to translate into ecosystem or platform dominance.  That $40 phone is also not going to garner any product loyalty when said owner saves up enough to buy a flagship phone.</p>
<p>I will however compare BMW&#8217;s to Mercedes to Teslas to Audis to Corvette &amp; Cadillac and to Acura, Infiniti and Lexus.  Those models of cars are what are pushing the market forward.  They are what is going to appear in Motor Trend magazine.  They are the vehicles we care about.  In the smartphone market the ones that matter are iPhone 5, Galaxy S3, Galaxy Note, Nexus 4, HTC One X/X+, HTC Droid DNA, and Motorola Droid RAZR/MAXX.  Of that group, only the first two are huge sellers with the third one being significant.  Nexus 4 would be the first Nexus device to sell well if it does, but Nexus is typically not a volume phone.  RAZR/MAXX did well in the USA, but not so much world-wide.</p>
<p>So yes, the overall &#8220;market share&#8221; estimate is extremely misleading because it includes all the cruft that gets sold in India and China that is targeted at folks who cannot afford the flagship devices that drive the market forward.  These phones are not going to garner customer loyalty or entice app developers to develop the great apps.  On the same note, Ford&#8217;s best selling car in the 1980s and 1990s was the Ford Escort &#8212; but nobody cared because it sold well because it was cheap &#8212; not because it was great.  If anything the Escort caused more people to swear off owning another Ford than it garnered in repeat purchases.</p>
<p>So if it&#8217;s not premium it doesn&#8217;t matter?  I get the point you&#8217;re making, but I think you&#8217;re being dismissive about &#8220;budget&#8221; products/services.  Look at the distribution of wealth and you&#8217;ll see it clearly.  $20 in groceries for you might include 1 lb of an expensive premium cut of steak for 1 dinner.  $20 in groceries for someone on a budget might include a months worth of Top Ramen.  Top Ramen may not be &#8220;pushing the market forward&#8221; but it&#8217;s certainly keeping those people alive.</p>
<p>And millions of high end devices mean nothing&#8230;. nothing at all.<br />
Android will be the top dog and no matter why that happened saying that it doesn&#8217;t matter is just plain stupid.</p>
<p>Or you are???</p>
<p>Remember what the PC and it&#8217;s compatible clones did to Apple, Amiga and Commodore. Open and commoditized will always zerg rush closed and custom designed. In 5 years time, Android (or less likely, Windows 8/9) will dominate the smartphone and tablet markets much like Windows dominates the desktop today.</p>
<p>MP3 players played out that way too, right?  Hmm&#8230; maybe not.</p>
<p>When all the OEMs were selling PCs with Windows, they were competing against Microsoft selling a bargain-basement version, right?  Oh yeah&#8230; that was not the case either even though Google sells Nexus 4 (and Nexus 7) dirt cheap.</p>
<p>Oh&#8230; I just remembered the similarity between smartphones and PCs&#8230;. Smartphone OEMs have tons of sales reps and account managers pushing their hardware into to businesses and schools and ensuring that if you want to remain relevant you have to have a compatible device because the ecosystem is not compatible or open&#8230;. Oh darn&#8230;I&#8217;m wrong again.  Android is open&#8230; anybody can plugin&#8230; there is no hard tie-in to businesses or schools.  And most businesses have moved to a &#8220;bring your own device&#8221; model.</p>
<p>The PC coup was brilliant because it was NOT open.  It relied on a closed ecosystem that required you have a Windows device to be compatible.  Those compatibility barriers don&#8217;t exist today for Android.  On the other hand, Apple is selling iPads to schools and businesses and integrating that with their Macs and creating a tie-in whereby you have to buy their products to be compatible.</p>
<p>If anybody is playing the game that Microsoft played years ago with Windows, it is Apple.  Except Apple is not leveraging partners for the hardware, they are building it themselves.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m just saying that comparing smartphones to PC&#8217;s is even less correct than comparing smartphones to tablets.  These markets play out different because of very different dynamics.  While Google is licensing their OS to many manufacturers like Microsoft did, they are not creating exclusive tie-ins that require an Android device in order to play.  The likelihood that smartphones will play out like PC&#8217;s of the 80s and 90s is very low.</p>
<p>Microsoft flubbed MP3 players because it couldn&#8217;t find a way to link Office or Exchange to them. Hindsight is 20/20, but their path to success has historically been through the enterprise, and not through the home user. They&#8217;re learning their lesson, but it may yet be too late for them, the success or failure of Windows 8 (on tablets and smartphones) will tell.<br />
I&#8217;m not saying that Android will have a lock on the industry the way Windows locked the desktop market up, but just that they (or Windows 8/9 who knows) will be the marketshare leader, although I expect Apple to consistently get higher margins with their premium sector of the market.</p>
<p>Apple&#8217;s bread and butter used to be the premium market, but they have really changed their focus to the masses.</p>
<p>The greatest tie-in that Microsoft had going for it back in the day was that if you used a PC at work then you wanted a PC at home.  My second computer (after my Atari 400) was an Apple IIc that I bought with my paper route money because the school had Apple computers and I wanted something <strong>compatible</strong> at home.</p>
<p>These days, so much is done on the web at school that your brand of computer is irrelevant.  There is no lock-in setup.  The key factor in this decade is going to be tie-in across your devices.  Every device can get to the web and get Gmail, or Yahoo mail or hotmail.  For work, devices all do exchange mail.  The differentiating factor will be how well devices and computers give you a seamless client.</p>
<p>Google&#8217;s approach is that on the device they integrate directly to their services, but on the PC (or Chromebook) you have to use the browser to get to your stuff.  That is why Chromebook makes the browser a part of the OS, but the experience is degraded nonetheless.</p>
<p>Apple&#8217;s model is that the device/computer is the gateway to the cloud, not the browser.  It looks the same as Google on tablets and smartphones, but Apple ties in the Mac very well with Mountain Lion.</p>
<p>Microsoft is the only company that is in a position to do what Apple is doing with a seamless client because they have a presence (a massive one) on the desktop.  The problem is that their presence is slipping away because they clung to the lock-in they created years ago for too long.  And their presence in mobile is horribly lacking.</p>
<p>Consider DropBox&#8230;. it is widely popular, but DropBox made sure that it behaved natively on each device.  DropBox only makes you use the Web browser to get to your files when you are at somebody else&#8217;s computer.  Otherwise it looks like part of the native operating system.  This is why Apple tried to acquire DropBox &#8212; because they were completely inline with Apple&#8217;s strategy.</p>
<p>What is the achilles heel in all of this?  Apple of years ago trumpeted &#8220;open architecture&#8221; because they needed it to thwart Microsoft.  Google has trumpted it recently.  In practice neither wants to be open except where it will hurt their competitor.  However, the general populous has demanded some things be open because they don&#8217;t want to be locked in again like they were with Microsoft (which is a bad sign for Microsoft, considering the bad memories it has caused for many).  The amount of openness today from each vendor makes the Microsoft-style PC Judo move of the 80&#8217;s and 90&#8217;s near-impossible today.</p>
<p>Of all companies, Apple is currently in the best possible position to deliver a seamless client.  Let&#8217;s look at how they stack up:</p>
<p>Google &#8212; Huge smartphone presence, no PC install base with Chromebook and very small tablet presence</p>
<p>Microsoft &#8211; Huge PC presence, but no mobile install base (smartphone or tablet)</p>
<p>Samsung &#8211; Huge smartphone presence, small tablet presence, and significant PC presence but does not own or dictate underlying operating systems (Android on mobile and Windows on PC)</p>
<p>Apple &#8211; Significant and growing PC presence, dominant tablet presence, and significant smartphone presence (and huge presence among premium buyers).</p>
<p>Quite honestly, I am bit surprised that it is not Microsoft who is in the dominant position today.  Microsoft was the company that was best poised to deliver the complete solution just 10 short years ago.</p>
<p>In the consumer space, Apple executes much better than Microsoft, and their vision regarding smartphones and tablets  was superior to Microsoft&#8217;s. But at the end of the day, it&#8217;s all about market share. The platform with the largest marketshare will win, no matter how cohesive or well designed a smaller platform is. Not to say that Apple is in danger of closing down any time soon, just that soon developers will not be able to ignore Android in favour of iOS, not when the sheer volume of Android users outweighs the deeper wallets of iOS customers.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m pretty sure a billion dollars out of Samsung&#8217;s pocket is a pretty big loss for them.</p>

<p>Building ones own technology based on the idea of another is totally different than seeing technology one wants and buying it outright. To use your same analogy, Ford did not invent the wheel, but they put the car chassis together according to their own vision. The wheel did not NEED to be bought and it was only a small part of the overall idea. All internal combustion engines are not the same either, look at the inline-four cylinder versus the flat-four. These two engines run entirely different, and neither one of the inventors of these engines bought the idea for the original internal combustion engine.</p>
<p>When one buys a previous idea, they are saying that they do not want to create new technology, and they do not want to innovate. Instead they are taking existing technology and placing their own badge on it without making any major changes. The inventor of this technology is screwed in this scenario due to the lack of exposure is company, which does not exist at this point, gets.</p>
