<p>Don&#8217;t forget there is some mysterious video floating around that purportedly shows a slate-type phone protoype prior to the iPhone.</p>
<p>Indeed&#8230;. this is an interesting article regarding the early (pre-G1) days of Android:</p>
<p><a href="http://www.osnews.com/story/25264/Did_Android_Really_Look_Like_BlackBerry_Before_the_iPhone_" target="_blank">http://www.osnews.com/story/25264/Did_Android_Really_Look_Like_BlackBerry_Before_the_iPhone_</a></p>
<p>The article is incorrect. Here&#8217;s the money quote.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>As it turns out, my memory isn&#8217;t playing tricks on me. We&#8217;re talking November 12 2007, and Google released the fist SDK for Android. Other than the keyboard-driven BlackBerry-esque style, the SDK also supported touch screens just fine. And, just as I remembered, Google showed off a reference design with a full touch screen (and, by the looks of it, it&#8217;s capacitive) &#8211; looking suspiciously similar to the HTC Dream, the first Android device &#8211; including gestures and flicks.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>November 12, 2007? As everyone knows, except for the OSNews author, Apple revealed iPhone 2007 on January 9, 2007 and shipped the device on June 29, 2007. They shipped the device in June 2007! The HTC Dream and its badge engineered T-Mobile G1 didn&#8217;t ship until October of 2008.</p>
<p>That&#8217;s 16 months after the iPhone 2007 shipped and 22 months after it was announced. And 18-24 months is your typical design cycle for a phone. Not only that, it took another 6 months before the HTC Magic shipped which was finally a phone that fit the iPhone mold: a slate style device with a soft-QWERTY, made possible by Android 1.1.</p>
<p>There may be evidence that Google had a iPhone-esque phone before iPhone 2007 appeared, but the OSNews article doesn&#8217;t present any.</p>
<p>Give Apple its props.</p>
<p>The &#8220;hardware limitations&#8221; logic is truly a terrible excuse.  As Andrew Munn pointed out in a recent post, the entire architecture of Android was based on the Blackberry model.  Contrast this to iOS, which started development in 2003 and was built from the ground up for touch.  Google bought Android in 2005 and never once thought to redesign the OS foundation for touch before the iPhone came out?</p>
<p>I am well and truly tired of hearing excuses for Google&#8217;s copying.   Same goes for Samsung, Meizu, etc.  There are so many Android fanboys who will so rabidly defend their precious treasures in the face of all evidence.  It&#8217;s quite wearisome.  I hope the courts at least judge honestly on this issue.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>I hope the courts at least judge honestly on this issue.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The courts don&#8217;t give a monkey&#8217;s about copying, they only care about infringing.  It is quite possible to infringe without doing anything so crass as copying.  It is quite possible to copy without ever technically infringing.</p>
<p>If the courts end up ruling in Apple&#8217;s favour that won&#8217;t prove that Samsung or HTC or Google copied Apple,  if they rule against Apple that won&#8217;t prove that Android didn&#8217;t.</p>
<p>Yeah spoken like a true fanboy from the heart. What about the LG Prada (full touch screen)that came out a year before the first iPhone. and 3 years later the iPhone looks exactly like it.. But no apple can never copy it was google and LG and everybody but Apple that copies. Please you need to leave  apple&#8217;s RDF sometime.</p>
<p>It didn&#8217;t come out a year before the iPhone, it came out 3 months before the iPhone. Seems like the one in a RDF is you.</p>
<p>The LG Prada looks nothing like the iPhone both in hardware and software, and operates nothing like an iPhone, including the iPhone 4/4S.</p>
<p>The two devices are about as far apart as possible for &#8220;full touch screen&#8221; devices. The fact that someone may have originally thought of something, doesn&#8217;t grant them exclusive use of the idea. The trunk of a full touch screen handheld device goes back to the 60s, at the beginning of computing age when transistors began to truly enable such devices. They thought about this stuff all the way back then. The idea of a full touch screen device goes back even further than this.</p>
<p>Lastly, there is reason the industry moved to an iPhone type model, and not an LG Prada type model. The LG Prada was basically a touch screen version of a Symbian style candy bar device, replete with T9 text entry. T9 text entry on a touch screen device! Ugh, LG&#8217;s idea was to make a luxury or premium candy bar phone. It was essentially adorning the phone with diamonds.</p>
<p>Amen, can we please stop talking about LG, and just let them die in peace already. FFS, LG in the Smartphone game, are you kidding me?!</p>
<p>Can you show me that Apple had a working prototype of a tablet style, only touch interface dating back to 2003?  Probably not, because the technology didn&#8217;t exist that allowed for a phone to be built at that point with such tech.  The iPhone was released in July 2007, 4 years later, because that was when the technology was available to meet Apples desires.  The iPods in 2003, were not including touch screen, on their OS,  why is this ?  Because the tech didn&#8217;t exist yet.  The new iPods have them, why is this? Because they can have them.  <br />
Apple realized that people would pretty much only carry one device, and these devices were strating to appear with music players. So apple had to build the iPhone to keep from losing their iTunes , digital hub scenario they were developing.  The first designs of the iPhone most certainly had keyboards.  Whether or not they were built to prototypes, I cannot say for certain but in the end, Johnny Ives and Steve Jobs decided, intelligently so, to forgo the keyboard metaphor entirely.<br />
It is important to note that the work began first on the iPad, but the phone was considered the more important device to stall other phones from becoming the de facto portable music devices.  If iPods could have been built with touch screens in 2003, they would have been built as such by Apple instead look at the interface and what the tech allowed .  The tech wasn&#8217;t there. so it wasn&#8217;t built that way. they had small screens, with incredibly low resolutions for that exact reason. If the tech was there, and the battery life, resolutions and quality of response at affordable prices for mass consumerism Apple would have built them that way.<br />
Maybe you should compare the iPod interface and hardware to what Android was doing in 2003-2005 for a less biased view of the evolution of technology.  I am not saying the first iPhone was unoriginal or un-inventive, in my post.  The tech simply was different in 2003, than it is nearing a decade later.  Just as it was different in &#8216;93-&#8217;03.  Hardware limitations are just that.</p>
<p>For the record, your mention of iPad development happening prior to iPhone development is inaccurate. I assume it comes, as always, form that video from a D conference.</p>
<p>What Jobs said in that interview was that he was shown a working prototype of a tablet-sized multitouch display, and he inmediately saw the potential of the technology for smartphones. Let me emfasize, he never says that an actual tablet was even  considered at that time. Amazingly, some people have taken those words out of context to assume the iPad started development before the iPhone, but it isn&#8217;t the case.</p>
<p>Had that screen prototype been only 2 inches ¿would we have to assume that the 2010 iPod Nano started development before the iPhone, too?</p>
<p>Nope, you don&#8217;t have the right record.</p>
<p>Apple started a tablet PC project called &#8220;Safari Pad&#8221; sometime in 2003 or 2004. Wired, the New York Times all have reported this. And they reported this circa 2008. Just look up &#8220;Safari Pad&#8221;.</p>
<p>Not only that, Appleinsider and other Apple rumors sites reported on the &#8220;Safari Pad&#8221; project back in 2004 as well.</p>
<p>Exactly.  The idea and concept was first for a tablet.  The biography goes into more details.  Essentially, Microsoft was hyping the &#8220;Tablet PC&#8221; like crazy back then.  One of the Microsoft engineers working on it was friends with the Jobs family, and at his 50th birthday party (with Gates in attendance), the engineer keep talking about it to Jobs, to the point it annoyed both Jobs and Gates.</p>
<p>Jobs decided &#8220;let&#8217;s show him what a tablet can really be&#8221;, and he gathered his core team to ask for a tablet without a keyboard, and without a stylus.  He wanted something to be sized to allow full typing with fingers.  In about six months, they made a very crude prototype, pulling in some multitouch work from the trackpads in the MacBooks.  (Remember, they were one of the first to introduce two finger scrolling gestures when everyone else had scroll zones).</p>
<p>The phone was another project somewhat in parallel at Apple, though the first versions did use the iPod click wheel to try and build off that.  When the tablet prototype came together, Jobs realized it might work for the phone too.  The iPod prototype kept going for a bit (Project P1), while the touch one started in parallel (P2) at that point.  Six more months, and the P1 and P2 were put to the test, with P2 winning.</p>
<p>This was early 2005, and when Apple also acquired FingerWorks to really help push their multitouch tech forward.  The rest of 2005 and 2006 were used to build the proper iPhone shown in January 2007, with the tablet project being shelved for a little bit.</p>
<p>Ahhhh. so Steve &#8220;copied&#8221; the iPad and therefore the iPhone as it was based on it, from a Microsoft demo, gotcha.</p>
<p>Well you&#8217;re a brilliant man for speculating about Palm, but you&#8217;re dead wrong. Palm was a freaking joke in 2005, and BB was kicking ass and taking names. Thats how it works. High profit margins attract competition, which then lowers industry margins. Palm wasn&#8217;t attracting anything, it was BB from the start.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m with you &#8211; it would also be good to see how Android stacks up against its spiritual predecessor, the Danger Hiptop/Sidekick OS.</p>

<p>lol, the homescreen hasn&#8217;t really changed much =P</p>
<p>What, pray tell, has changed on the home screen?  The background?</p>
<p>iOS 1.x: your basic single page homescreen with what 12 applications?</p>
<p>iOS 2.x: 7 home screens with horizontal swipes and the dots for which homescreen you&#8217;re on, 3rd party apps, Webpage as an app-icon on the homescreen. Jiggly mode (long press on an icon) for app ordering and removal.</p>
<p>iOS 3.x: 9 home screens. swipe right from 1st homescreen for search. Voice controls with long press of home button. Double press and triple press had options to go camera, 1st homescreen page, search, etc. Some of the double tap stuff may have been in iOS 2.&#215;. Dock background change?</p>
<p>iOS 4.x: Wallpaper. Multitasking tray on double tap. Swipe right to get audio control, background audio app, orientation lock, swipe right twice for volume. App folders</p>
<p>iOS 5.x: Swipe down for notification center. 4 &amp; 5 finger gestures on iPad (pinch for homescreen, swipe left for last used app, swipe up for multitasking tray).</p>
<p>That&#8217;s some of it. There&#8217;s a bunch of accessibility stuff that the tech press never talks about with VoiceOver, 2 and 3 finger operations, custom vibrations, big text mode, inverse color mode, etc. For vision and hearing impaired, iOS appears to be much better than AndroidOS.</p>
<p>&#8220;Jiggly mode&#8221; and add webpage to homescreen were added in 1.1.3, not 2.0. The App Store itself was added in 2.0.<br />
There are many other things that changed between versions &#8211; but you&#8217;re absolutely right about the awesome accessibility in iOS.</p>

<p>Chris, great article! I couldn&#8217;t stop reading. And so, I noticed several inaccuracies:<br />
1) FroYo was released on 20 May 2010, and GingerBread on 6 December 2010. Six and a half months just can&#8217;t qualify as &#8220;nearly a year after the launch of FroYo&#8221;<br />
2) You say that GingerBread brought &#8220;support for front-facing camera.&#8221; Let me remind you that HTC EVO (the first phone with FFC in US) launched in June 2010 with Eclair, 2.1, and had front-facing camera support with included Qik app, and, briefly, Skype video through Fring app. HTC may have put some magic to enable FFC on Eclair, but CyanogenMod 6 (based on FroYo) supported videochat long before GingerBread.<br />
3) One potentially major feature of GingerBread that you left out is support for VOIP calls, for example using SIP.</p>
<p>Thanks for the notes! As for the HTC-specific modifications, yeah, I left a few of those out — they also had multitouch gestures working before Android officially supported it. Tried to concentrate on &#8220;stock&#8221; Android for this particular piece. I also couldn&#8217;t cover every single feature that was added from version to version (I was already over 6K words!) and made the tough decision to leave SIP support out&#8230; I feel like Google Voice and Skype are more relevant non-traditional voice calling options for most users, and the SIP integration is kind of underused.</p>
<p>I&#8217;ll definitely update the part about the gap from Froyo to Gingerbread. Thanks!</p>
<p>I agree that SIP support may have been huge, but it did not catch on, so it may deserve to be left out.<br />
But I can&#8217;t agree that front-facing camera support was brought by GB. Granted, there were no &#8220;stock&#8221; Android device with FFC until Nexus S. But CyanogenMod is very very close to &#8220;stock&#8221; Android. Also, as you say, screen resolution independence was enabled in Donut, but the first device to take advantage of it was Motorola Droid with Eclair. It does not mean that screen resolution independence was brought by Eclair, does it?</p>
<p>GB is where an official SDK API for front-facing camera appeared, so this is when it is part of the Android platform.  Manufacturers may make modifications to the platform to implement new features, but these are limited because apps can&#8217;t widely use them and will generally need to be coded with manufacturer-specific APIs for each device.</p>

<p>You didn&#8217;t mention probably the biggest benefit of the new ICS keyboard, the multitouch shift and alt character buttons.</p>
<p>Old keyboard: Press [?123] button, type some numbers, Press [ABC} to get back to letters.</p>
<p>New Keyboard: Press and hold down [?123] button, type some numbers, release [?123] button to get back to letters.</p>
<p>Doesn&#8217;t seen like much of a big difference but sure does feel like it speeds things up a lot.</p>

<p>Its another subtle difference. In the past each time you tapped shift it would alternate between caps, and caps lock</p>

<p>Android has changed a lot in 3 years. I&#8217;ve only been a full fledged user for the past 4months and there are many things I dislike about it and really like about it. My miscellaneous thoughts:</p>
<p>-Is it me or has Android&#8217;s look seemed less friendly since 2.3? From 1.0 to about Froyo it just has a bright look to it but now it has a &#8220;darker&#8221; look (black borders, toolbars etc). I much preferred the look of the G1 era. I think the bright and friendly look, had more in common with Google&#8217;s web products like Search, Calendar, Maps etc. and the Chrome browser. The most recent app that invokes this look is the Google+ app which I really love the look and functionality of. Essentially what I&#8217;m saying is, I just wish Android looked a bit more like Google&#8217;s web products (a unified design language let&#8217;s say) and the Google+ app specifically.</p>
<p>-I wish a manufacturer would release all their phones with stock Android. I hate that I can&#8217;t recommend a phone to someone because the upgrade path is uncertain or if there would be a learning curve in going from one skinned UI to another.</p>
<p>-The OG Droid is still a cool-looking phone, wish they kept that design and just updated the internals. The Droid 4, design-wise, is a major step down and the build quality of the Droid 2-4 seemed to get plastic-ier as it has progressed. I wish more Android phones looked like the first Droid than the ovular-rectangles we get these days. Considering how many manufacturers there are, there aren&#8217;t too many interesting designs coming out, at least not here in the US. Maybe it&#8217;s a case of the grass being greener on the other side thinking, but the most interesting designs are coming out in Japan (Sharp&#8217;s AQUOS line for one) or are not really pushed by carriers/manufacturers (Sony Ericsson). Android always had potential for new/interesting/unique/beautiful industrial design but few have taken advantage of it, and it just seems that everything started to look the same after a while. We need more Droid 1&#8217;s. Is what I&#8217;m saying.</p>

<p>The prototype builds of Android devices looked like a hybrid between blackberry and palm OS. And shortly after the iPhone was announced, Google showed off those prototypes and one of them had a touch interface. The prototypes were incomplete, but there were some obvious indications of widgets and notification drawers coming. When the G1 came out, it didn&#8217;t look like an iOS at all. It looked like Google finished the prototype OS, took the touchscreen version, and slapped the keyboard version&#8217;s keyboard on the back. It looked this way until Froyo, when Android actually started to look a bit more like iOS and felt modern. Then ICS eventually comes along and we have Holo. Even if Google did remove the blue highlighting, the thin lines and animations still give me a Tron-like feel, which is a good thing.</p>
<p>My G1 came with 0.9</p>

<p>Indeed, root. The term jailbreak is most often associated with iOS-based devices and, to my knowledge, the two terms mean different things.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m not familiar with jailbreaking, but rooting just gives you access to the root user, thus the name</p>
<p>I thought jailbreaking an iOS device gave you root access too?</p>
<p>Well, yes, but the term comes from the fact that you&#8217;re breaking the device out of its jail, thus opening it up. Android is already open. They just don&#8217;t give you default access to root user because they don&#8217;t want you doing stupid shit like &#8220;rm -rf *&#8221;.</p>

<p>Correct,<br />
Jailbreak means to leave a walled garden, on Android when you click allow apps from unknown sources you have been &#8220;jailbroken&#8221; since now you can gets app from sources other then Google</p>
<p>Root means to gain root access to the root account on a *nix system such as iOS (BSD) or Android (Linux)</p>
<p>It just happens that to jailbreak an iOS device you have to have root and thus the terms have become conflated</p>
<p>rooting and jailbreaking are not the same thing. I wish internet users would stop using them as if they are.</p>

Has it ever occurred to you that Apple takes their latest software, has it carrier tested without it being news, and then once done, says, &#8220;Here it is&#8221;? Whereas, Android is open-source. It&#8217;s made available to the public when done. Then it gets submitted to carrier testing at the same time. The carriers get it when everyone else gets it. It&#8217;s akin to how developers are now getting iOS6.1 beta to play with. Eventually, Apple will finalize it, send it to carriers. <p>I just got it. I did it like this in the end:</p>
<p>1. Go to Settings &#8594; Apps &#8594; All</p>
<p>2. Find Google Services Framework.</p>
<p>3. Tap on Force Stop.</p>
<p>4. Select Clear Data.</p>
<p>5. Head back to the Nexus 7′s Settings, go to About, and check for a System Update.</p>
<p>(AKA i didnt bother with wifi, this worked on second try)</p>
<p>Tap &#8220;Clear Data&#8221; or &#8220;Clear Cache&#8221;?</p>
<p>Thanks all for your help. I got the update :-)</p>
<p>Here is exactly how you should do it (worked for me twice in a row, on my nexus 7 and my galaxy nexus):</p>
<p>1. Put your phone in Airplane mode (ON)<br />
2. Go to Settings → Apps → All<br />
2. Find Google Services Framework.<br />
3. Tap on Force Stop.<br />
4. Select Clear Data.<br />
5. Head back to the Nexus 7′s Settings, go to About, click on &#8220;System Update&#8221; and put airplane mode to (OFF)<br />
Please TheVerge, change the instruction you currently have.</p>

<p>Most of the time it has no benefit.  Most carriers do not give you any particular advantage to buying off contract as opposed to on contract.  The exception to this is T-Mobile, who reduces your monthly bill.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s disgusting that your fees are the same regardless of whether you are subsidising a phone or not.</p>
<p>Why is it &#8220;disgusting&#8221;? The fact in other countries you have to buy your phone outright is disgusting. That&#8217;s a high bar of entry, i dont know about you but i prefer a lower bar.</p>
<p>Here&#8217;s the thing, most countries have two options: on contract which has a lower up front but higher monthly rates, or off contract which has a higher up front but lower monthly rates.  In the US, the monthly stays the same regardless of whether you pay more up front, making off contract hard to swallow for most people.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m well aware of how phone plans work around the world, but if you look at it, it&#8217;s not necessarily better.  In the good &#8216;ole USA, many people are on family plans and can&#8217;t afford 5 or 6 smart phones @$700 a piece on t-mobile. That&#8217;s a bad deal &#8211; I think people are smarter than you think. People who buy off contract are just paying for the freedom to spend more money in the long run, like the opportunity to buy multiple full price phones within a 2-year cycle, more than someone who is in a 2-year contract would. Also, if the phone breaks within the 2 year cycle (which is likely) off-contractors are on the hook for the full price of the phone plus buying a whole new replacement phone at full price (no insurance when you BYOP).</p>
<p>You don&#8217;t have to buy the phone outright. You can go on a subsidized plan just like you (usually for less money too) or you can buy your phone outright, but if you do, you don&#8217;t pay the same monthly fee as if you were subsidizing like you do&#8230;because that is horrendous.</p>

<p>I see what you mean.  Though it looks almost as if the blue pixels are the same size as the red and green ones, just turned on their sides.  That&#8217;s how I saw them at first.  I&#8217;m looking again and you might be right, it could just be pentile with twice more blue pixels instead of green.</p>
<p>In what way is it still pentile?  Is there some pentile standard I should be aware of including different arrangements all considered pentile?  I thought pentile was defined by the RGBG (or RGBW according to Wiki) arrangement.  Any other arrangement, while possibly not standard RGB, isn&#8217;t necessarily pentile.</p>
<p>I think that the new pixel arrangement is something more like B G/R, or G/R B, what ever you wanna call it&#8230; The Green pixels (or Red, depending on how you look at it) are right above the Red pixels (or Green, depending on how you look at it).  And then, on either side (left or right, I&#8217;m not sure which), is a Blue pixel Shared by the Green/Red (Red/Green) pixels.  That means that it has the exact same Sub pixel quantity as regular RGB, but in a Pentile-esque sub pixel arrangement.</p>
<p>No it is not Pentile!<br />
It has the same sub-pixel quantity than original RGB, so it is TRUE 1280&#215;720 display.</p>
<p>There are equal amounts of each color pixel, all about the same size.  I think it should be fine.</p>
<p>Yeah, that&#8217;s what makes it different than pentile.</p>
<p>GO CARDS!</p>
<p>Instead of going RGBG it seems to go BR and then in the next row go BG. So it&#8217;s in between Pentile and SAMOLED+. The subpixels are also more tightly packed than in the S3.</p>
<p>From close examination of the image above, it is clear to me that there are three subpixels per pixel, just in a different arrangement than the traditional RGB stripe.  This eliminates Pentile&#8217;s cheat of only getting two out of three colors per pixel.  I hope this diagram will serve to clarify.<br />
<img src="http://i.imgur.com/lDSh1.png" /></p>
<p>The question: is that really one blue sub-pixel for each red and green, or two separate blue sub-pixels. As long as it&#8217;s a full triad for each pixel, things should be OK because Android doesn&#8217;t do sub-pixel antialiasing.</p>
<p>However, I think your speculation that it is one pixel might be correct, due to the fact that blue is traditionally the weakest of the three colors in OLED, and they simply made it larger to give the panel longer life.</p>

<p>How?</p>
<p>Lens design is complex and the longer range you have to optimize over the less you can perfect the IQ.</p>
<p>Good lord, I can&#8217;t believe you got that many recommendations, or that readers here are that clueless.</p>
<p>Lens design is a compromise between IQ, aperture, zoom, and size. If you increase the Zoom, either the lens has to be made bigger, or the aperture smaller, or the IQ worse, or all three.</p>
<p>In this case you can see that they&#8217;ve made the physical aperture size miniscule, because the camera only uses a tiiiiny 1/2.3&quot; sensor.</p>
<p>If they&#8217;d used 5x optical zoom, they could&#8217;ve used a much larger sensor (about 10 times the surface area) while sticking to the same lens size.</p>
<p>The really irritating thing about this is nobody&#8217;s going to freaking USE the 21x zoom.  They&#8217;ll try it out, for fun, then realize the pictures it makes are just godawful and totally ruined by shake, then go back to using 1-5x zoom like sane people.</p>

<p>consumers buy stuff, high end consumers are still consumers. Mass marketed product casts a wide net because it&#8217;s a balance between price and value and serves as a first step into an area of interest.</p>
<p>As people hone their interests in a particular direction, the acceptable options for products become fewer and fewer as the products themselves become better and better. Along with those improvements in performance come heftier price tags that do not make sense for the average consumer to purchase initially.</p>

<p>I think most people are going about this the wrong way, comparing it to smartphones. They should be comparing it to cameras. There is still a market for point-and-shoots, and they still take better pictures than smartphones. Out of the box, a smartphone will not compare to it on several factors. True optical zooming &gt; digital zooming, macro photos will be better with the point-and-shoot, low-light pictures will be better, having the flash further away from the lens will help prevent red eye without having to digitally remove it. Having better light sensors than smartphones due to the increased body size, as well as better shutter speed control. The list could go on and on&#8230; all features that are in regular cameras, with the added benefit of having an OS behind it that will let you do more with the pictures <strong>after</strong> you take them.</p>
<p>Honestly, the OS itself makes little difference in how this thing operates (which is why the Nikon camera with 2.3 might still be a good option.) It&#8217;s the fact that you can take a much higher quality picture that matters most. Android lets you edit the photos on the fly using various apps, back them up to the cloud, send them to Google+/Facebook/Picasa/Flickr/etc. But it&#8217;s not meant to replace your current smartphone, it&#8217;s meant to replace your current point-and-shoot. Many people including myself still use point-and-shoots on a regular basis (especially when I don&#8217;t want to lug an DSLR around but still know I&#8217;ll be taking pictures and want better control over the pictures I take.)  I think it&#8217;s only a matter of time until ALL point-and-shoot camera&#8217;s do the same thing.</p>

<p>That&#8217;s is also why I had zero interest in the Kindle Fire. I do have a way of accessing the entire Google system with the Nook, however.   I found a proprietary micro sd card issued by a company called N2A.  Using a Cyanogen Mod rom, the card contains a bootable flash of the Gingerbread OS.  By inserting that card into the slot of the Nook, I have access to the entire Google ecosystem.  The card comes in 8, 16 and 32gb sizes.  It gives you the beauty of a dual boot system because the card doesn&#8217;t alter the native OS of the Nook.  That&#8217;s the good news.  The bad news is that the card is partitioned, with most of the space allocated for &#8220;data.&#8221;:  So that will limit the number and size of apps that you can add from Google.  I got the card through Amazon,</p>
<p>I&#8217;m wondering what people with a Galaxy Note will do.  Can you make a case for a 7 inch tablet if your current screen is 5.3 inches and runs a similar OS?  I&#8217;d be curious to hear if anyone is in that situation..</p>

<p>Key phrase being &#8220;in the UK&#8221;. From what I can tell carriers all across Europe have rolled out, are rolling out or will be rolling out LTE, generally speaking, on 800 and 2600MHz. 1800MHz is the spare, only where available, LTE frequency band. It&#8217;s really only because UK regulators are taking their sweet time to auction off 800/2600 that the roll out there is starting with 1800.</p>
<p>Ofcom is being hurried along to sell the 800 and 2600Mhz band, but there is still a part of the UK using 800Mhz for TV (Northern Ireland) because ROI has yet to stop broadcasting TV on 800Mhz.</p>
<p>800Mhz goes much further then 1800Mhz, but the iPhone 5 supports neither 800 or 2600.</p>
<p>One had hoped that the Iphone 5 would be the one stupid exception though.</p>
<blockquote>800Mhz goes much further then 1800Mhz</blockquote>
<p>If you mean that 800MHz is a better frequency for travelling long distances (beneficial for serving rural areas), then the iPhone 5 supports both 850MHz and 700MHz, which have the same benefit.</p>
<p>1800MHz is pretty well spread worldwide, including Europe.  So is 2600MHz.</p>
<p>The rollout here in the UK has started with 1800MHz for a handful of reasons:</p>
<ul>
	<li>The 2600HMz and 800MHz spectrum has not yet been cleared and auctioned off.</li>
	<li>The iPhone 5 supports LTE on 1800MHz, not 2600MHz or 800MHz.</li>
	<li>Everything Everywhere already owned rights to the 1800MHz range.</li>
</ul>
<p>Without any of those three, I think we might have begun our LTE rollout in late 2013 with 800/2600MHz.</p>
<p>But 4G in 800Mhz will be so much better.</p>
<p> - It covers a MUCH wider range per tower then 1800Mhz, meaning its perfect for the countryside.<br />
 - All operators will be using it, meaning interoperability which is the reason why our prices are already incredibly low (£10 for unlimited data).</p>
<p>Where is this place that offers unlimited data for 10 quid?</p>
<p>GiffGaff currently offers 250 minutes, unlimited texts and unlimited data without tethering for £10.</p>
<p>This offer is due to end soon, replaced by 250 minutes, unlimited texts and 1GB of data with tethering.  The original £10 deal will now cost £12.</p>
<p>I was delighted.</p>

<p>It could be because review sites tend to think the S3 is a better phone overall even in spite of disproportionate specs or features against some of its rivals. It could be because they&#8217;re getting kickbacks from Samsung, which wouldn&#8217;t surprise me given how heavily they are marketing the S3(and how much money they are spending to do it, getting TV spots at virtually every major event). It could also be that buyers are more likely to be considering an S3 upfront so it is more useful to bring it up in comparisons more than some of its rivals simply  because you get more clicks from things like &#8220;how does the S3 compare to the&#8230;&#8221;</p>
<p>I mean, say you&#8217;re reviewing the iPhone 5, does it really make sense to compare the screen to the One X, the processor to the S3, the battery life to the Droid Razr Maxx and the camera to the Lumia 920? If it takes 4 separate devices that on their own <strong>might</strong> have superior individual parts but no singular device has them all, then it&#8217;s not a very useful comparison for the sake of consumer electronics. If you&#8217;re trying to determine what is technically the best, then leave that to sites like Arstechnica and anandtech who will may do those comparisons but also do in-depth analyses on the technical capabilities of each component. But there is a good reason why sites like Verge don&#8217;t specialize in those breakdowns, because smartphones very often are more than the sum of their parts and actual ownership/usage does not always align well with theoretical performance or technical achievement.</p>

<p>ipad isn&#8217;t quad core cpu&#8230;. its a DUAL core CPU with a QUAD CORE CPU. The nexus is a quad core CPU (really 5 cores) with a 12 core GPU!</p>
<p>Your CPU comparison has some merit as they are basically the same architecture.  It would be interesting to see which real world applications benefit &#8211; I haven&#8217;t seen it yet but I&#8217;m sure it&#8217;s out there somewhere?</p>
<p>Your GPU comparison is completely meaningless.  The 12 cores in the Tegra 3 are not as powerful as a quad core PowerVR SGX543MP4.  You can not just count cores across different architectures and make any kind of assumption about performance.  Counting transistors would be a step in a better direction.</p>
<p>You are discounting the architecture though, the tegra 3 is based off of nvidia&#8217;s pc line-up and thus comes with programmable shaders that the PowerVR lacks, so the tegra can actually have more effects with less effect on performance.<br />
The only real feather in the PowerVR&#8217;s hat is its ability to push pixels, the fill rate on it is very very high.  While the memory bandwidth is the limiting factor for tegra 3, which is why in the newer implementations it gets faster ram and has no trouble with the higher resolution of the transformer pad infinity.</p>

<p>Tablet specific apps is a dumb idea. Apps should adapt to the full range of devices. As Duarte explains in the interview.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s incredibly annoying to have different apps for each device.</p>
<p>As a phone and tablet app developer, I disagree with you in part.</p>
<p>There are a certain number of my apps I just would not want people to run on their phones, because it would guarantee a worse experience (coding apps, painting apps, for example). And I wouldn&#8217;t want to be responsible for that poor user experience.</p>
<p>Also there is one game we have developed that can just not be played on a phone — as it requires four simultaneous touches with two hands. Anything lower than a 9&quot; screen for that game is very uncomfortable.</p>
<p>But for a large selection of apps (especially information consumption apps), having them run on both phone and tablet is a very good idea.</p>
<p>That&#8217;s another matter. Sure you can restrict apps from being used on certain devices.</p>
<p>The point is that IF an app is supposed to run on the full range of devices, you should not have a different app for a small phone, big phone, 7&quot;tablet and then a 10&quot;tablet. One app should simply be able to work on all those. It should also work pretty much the same way on all these devices. Just use the extra screen real estate for combining functionality on a bigger screen.</p>
<p>Again I agree in part — I think the app should be the same for both tablet and phone devices (i.e. universal binary or whatever). But some apps need drastically re-designed UIs to work on a smaller (or larger) screen.</p>
<p>Look at Apple&#8217;s iPhoto, Keynote, and Numbers apps. They&#8217;ve re-imagined the workflow for them when they run on iPhone. It&#8217;s really good, and well thought out (I was amazed that Keynote was actually usable at phone size). These are very complicated applications, and they really need a lot of thought about how you approach them at different sizes. The tablet interface for iPhoto on a phone would be ridiculously cluttered and would just not work.</p>
<p>So for a lot of simpler apps, I agree with you — they can mostly preserve their form and show more content. But when you get to more advanced and complex interactions you start to need dedicated designs for different device forms.</p>
<p>I didn&#8217;t say more content, but more functionality. Like showing a menu in a column on the left for a tablet device  (in landscape orientation!) and have the menu on a separate screen from the content on a phone.</p>
<p>True, though I think it goes a bit deeper than optional menus. Sometimes the app&#8217;s design needs to be started from scratch for an alternate form factor.</p>
<p>I&#8217;ve done this a few times with the universal apps I&#8217;ve developed — I was able to reuse some code (individual views) but the best result came when I went back to the design stage and threw everything away. Then thought about how my users would approach the app on a different device, what emotions they would feel, how much time they would have, and so on.</p>
<p>So in the end you essentially design two apps that share some implementation code. I don&#8217;t think this is a bad way to do things, you end up creating a very focused experience on every device you support.</p>
<p>Uh, no.</p>

<p>The Twitter app is just one example, but it&#8217;s an important one. If you ask people about the things that people actually want to do on a tablet, they want simple things. Nobody cares about hundreds of thousands of apps; they want to read, browse the internet, check Facebook and Twitter, and they maybe want to play games. Apple puts out high quality apps all the time for each device. You shouldn&#8217;t have to hunt and seArch for the good ones. They should be front and center, like on the amazon app store.</p>
<p>Android hasn&#8217;t had an OS worthy of developing tablet apps for. You people, yes you people, keep dogging it as if the ecosystem will remain stagnant.</p>
<p>Everything changes, even your beloved iOS and iDevices.</p>
<p>My point is amazon was smart enough to add some quality control. They made it easy like apple. Google hasn&#8217;t even tried, it seems.</p>
<p>As a dev I can tell you it is not that there aren&#8217;t any &#8220;worthy&#8221; tablets, the problem is discovery.</p>
<p>Those with tablets will never find your tablet optimized app, making it not worth the effort. If google had some kind of &#8220;tablet optimized&#8221; designator than adoption would increase, I guarantee it.</p>
<p>That&#8217;s missing the point a little bit. I shouldn&#8217;t be able to download an app on a device it wasn&#8217;t made for. I know you can open iPhone apps on the iPad, but by not trying to make the apps work and rather just scaling them in a weird looking way, Apple kind of shamed devs into updating for the new size quickly. In contrast Google made sure devs supported multiple <em>phone</em> sizes from the beginning, so when tablets started arriving the the designs technically worked, nobody seemed to bother making them work better.</p>
<p>The Android Tablet app system is a bit weird.  There are apps that have technically been updated for a tablet that sucked, like Google+ before the update, but then there are apps that work perfectly even when they&#8217;re not updated, too.  The bottom line is that you can&#8217;t just search &#8220;tablet&#8221; on the Play Store and get all the good apps.</p>
<p>Supporting multiple screen sizes and densities is a real pain. Even though they&#8217;ve got it pretty standardized the emulation just isn&#8217;t good enough, and it feels like there&#8217;s a huge hidden expense there. You really can&#8217;t get a good look of how somethings going to feel without having the device in your hand. Buying all those devices with modernish components and standard screens is almost looking like a necessity. It&#8217;s just not good enough not have something you can feel as a frame of reference.</p>
<p>Our designers also hate it.</p>
<p>When we do iOS apps the designers give the programmers pixel perfect comps of how they want the UI to look, how they want it to move. Their vision gets recreated exactly.</p>
<p>Then when we do Android apps, the most common thing that happens is the iOS design is jammed into the Android system (usually due to client budget constraints). However on the rare occasion we&#8217;ve had more time to spend, the programmers are happy to create flexible layouts, but the designers lament their loss over exact placement, having to use tile-able textures, (and probably until now, lack of something as good as Core Animation on iOS).</p>
<p>Also the HiDPI thing on Android is handled atrociously — they have a lot more DPIs to support, to be fair. But the simplicity of iOS&#8217; automated @2x system is just so easy. We have scripts that we run over our asset folder to generate all the retina and non-retina content. With Android dev that&#8217;s a lot harder due to some of the whacky middle-range DPIs and requirements for everything to be resizable.</p>
<p>quite simply put building an android app is more like building a pc app rather than a dos app supporting only 320&#215;200 and 640&#215;480.</p>
<p>it&#8217;s harder for the designers, sure. but it&#8217;s a lot more future proof.</p>
<p>I understand and value that aspect of it. But so far I have not really seen it done well on Android — I haven&#8217;t seen apps equivalent to some of the most beautiful and usable on iOS. When you let designers have their way, sometimes they make really great things.</p>
<p>Also I question the usefulness of &#8220;future proofing&#8221; apps that are generally priced from $1 to $10 (or mostly free, as is the case on Android). Apple has shown time and time again that they can make their developers jump through hoops. Introduce a new resolution? Every developer is on it immediately, updating to the new system.</p>
<p>I agree with your point when it comes to PC apps. But for devices like the iPad, as a developer, I would be happy to re-write or re-build my app when a brand new Apple device is released (every few years, say). Because it leads to more sales, and forces me to keep my customers happy.</p>
<p>Coding and programming is not sacred — we don&#8217;t have to future proof it and keep it around. Throwing stuff out and starting from scratch can sometimes be the best thing you ever do for your products.</p>
<p>The real problem is that Twitter doesn&#8217;t feel that the Android tablet platform is important enough to optimize their own app. Same with Facebook and Flipboard. If they would bother, why should smaller developers?</p>
<p>Don&#8217;t think that Android get smartphone apps is out of the goodness of developers hearts. Supporting an app costs time and money whereas doing nothing does not.</p>
<p>I find the iPad version of Facebook to be as useful as Facebook on any Android tablet.  Sure, it may be a little prettier, but aside from that, I don&#8217;t see any benefit.</p>
<p>But&#8230;but&#8230;but&#8230;it&#8217;s not tablet specific! OMG!</p>
<p>It&#8217;s tablet optimized.</p>
<p>It takes a very long time to develop an app let alone retrofit it to add functionality, and much like anything else in Android learning how to do things for tablets is time-consuming commitment. Even though I think the Nexus 7 looks promising is spending three months just learning tablet functionality a good use of time? Unless you&#8217;re designing from ground up you&#8217;re almost certainly going to be introducing new bugs you don&#8217;t know how to fix.</p>
<p>Not to mention the word &#8216;developer&#8217; is consistently misused. It&#8217;s like when people talk about OEMs without knowing what they are. On android you&#8217;ve got companies with product teams adding to their service with apps, you got solo guys who develop for search results, there&#8217;s studios producing and managing projects for clients, and there&#8217;s also solo guys who offer a service and are their own product team. That&#8217;s a lot of different scenarios you got to account for. It&#8217;s shit, although most people and companies aren&#8217;t going to add a feature unless it pays them handsomely.</p>
<p>The main problem is finding the apps. They exist, but it&#8217;s hard to see which ones are designed for tablets. And a phone UI just doesn&#8217;t cut it.</p>

<p>How would media that I own get sync&#8217;d to the tablet?  Couldn&#8217;t see any mention of that in the review ( unless I&#8217;ve missed it&#8230;. ).</p>

<p>While it&#8217;s undoubtedly the best 7&quot; tablet and quite possibly the best Android tablet, I did find it that hilarious that Josh shifted up the score by a full point. The scores average out to 7.75, and that&#8217;s with a very generous ecosystem rating.</p>
<p>i doubt &#8220;camera&#8221; for a tablet is weighted as heavily as &#8220;softwre&#8221;</p>
<p>Bottom line is Josh has clearly exercised his power in the final score. While this is a very compelling device, I worry that the adjustment may not stay true in the long run. 8.8 is a seriously high score for any product, and a score not reached by any flagship Android device this year.</p>
<p>&#8220;More times than not, the Verge score is based on the average of the subscores below. However, since this is a non-weighted average, we reserve the right to tweak the overall score if we feel it doesn&#8217;t reflect our overall assessment and price of the product.&#8221;</p>
<p>As you said, Josh obviously decided that the average was not an accurate reflection of his experiences, and the fact that the product is only 199 dollars also goes into it. On the podcasts they have been talking about how future promise also is put into account (the Lytro), and how products can be improved due to their price. What I got out of this was Josh in effect saying at this price point and with the inevitable push from Android into the tablet space, the Nexus 7 is the best option for someone looking to get into the Android space and wants prompt updates.</p>
<p>This is not a minor tweak, it&#8217;s throwing a respectable device into a highly-exclusive club of products with ~9.0 scores. As I&#8217;ve iterated elsewhere, price has commonly been ignored during reviews, receiving a footnote &#8211; many devices are in fact played down because they don&#8217;t measure up to &#8220;competitors&#8221; that are priced hundreds of dollars above the device. If someone told me a product scores a 9/10, I wouldn&#8217;t think that there are still serious questions to be asked regarding the platform and ecosystem (similarly, I didn&#8217;t expect an 8.0+ score for any Windows Phone Mango device for the same reason).</p>
<p>You got around 6000 developers who now own a nexus 7 tablet, so we are bound to see more tablet optimized apps</p>
<p>It&#8217;s really too early to say &#8211; it didn&#8217;t happen with the Galaxy 10.1.</p>
<p>The Galaxy 10.1 started with Gingerbread which is a terrible OS for a tablet, as was Honeycomb. With ICS rolling out (hopefully in a timely fashion) to more and more devices especially tablets, don&#8217;t bet on the tablet ecosystem remaining stagnant as it has.</p>
<p>You&#8217;re getting confused.  The Galaxy Tab 10.1 is the one that Google gave away a year ago to I/O attendees.  It came with Honeycomb.  The guy you&#8217;re replying to is pointing out that a large number of developers received them for free, so it clearly takes more than just giving away free tablets to developers in order to get them on board.</p>
<p>There WAS an earlier version of the tab which only had Gingerbread.  IIRC it was the only one released by a major manufacturer that used the &#8220;phone&#8221; version of the OS.</p>
<p>Now that that&#8217;s out of the way, I think the problem with the Galaxy Tab 10.1 may have simply been that even a blind man could see that Honeycomb was rushed out as quickly as possible with little regard to whether it worked well.  What developer would want to put their support behind that?  Even ICS had a fair number of obvious oversights that JB needed to correct.  It also wasn&#8217;t a proper &#8220;Nexus&#8221; device and there was a clear sense at the time that Google was promoting it only because it was the best they could offer, not because they were satisfied with it.</p>
<p>Also &#8211; and now I&#8217;m just getting into personal opinion &#8211; I&#8217;ve never liked the 10&quot; form factor.  I&#8217;ve tried about half a dozen of them, including the iPad 2 which is the lightest one AFAIK.  But even so, they&#8217;re all too big, heavy, and awkward.  You can&#8217;t really hold it with one hand but to interact with it you need to.  The keyboard&#8217;s obnoxiously huge &#8211; thought that&#8217;s something easily rectified with Swiftkey 3&#8217;s tablet version.  It&#8217;s too big to really be portable.  In short, I just don&#8217;t think it&#8217;s an ideal size for anything intended to be a portable device.  5 to 8 inches is more reasonable, and 7 makes a great compromise.</p>
<p>While I&#8217;m disappointed the Nexus 7 doesn&#8217;t have expandable storage or HDMI output, I gave it some thought and I think the reason these are missing has nothing to do with cost cutting.  If Google included them, they would be cutting the legs out from beneath all of their OEM partners.  A tablet with every conceivable high-end feature, the lightest 7-incher so far, and being sold almost for a loss?  That would piss some people off.  How could anyone possibly compete with that?  I doubt even Samsung could beat that without taking a loss.</p>

<p>I don&#8217;t see why people are so keen on having HDMI or any other video output on this device. Most phones these days have HML ports, and removable storage, so if you have a phone then you&#8217;re already set. If not, there are a variety of cheaper ways to get media from a device to a television. Most DVD or Bluray players have external USB ports that can read a wide variety of drives from external HDDs, to SSDs, thumb drives and even tablets and phones that act like plug and play drives. Then there&#8217;s always a Roku box, Google TV, Apple TV, Xbox 360, PS3, and even cheap media center computers, all with plenty of capabilities.</p>
<p>In essence, anywhere you go with a device, there should be one or more ways to display your media on a television without the need for a tablet with video output.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m far more likely to use video out on a device like this than my phone. <p>The fact of the matter is, a dodgy looking piece of software is usually dodgy. This isn&#8217;t exclusive to Android or mobile phones or anything. If something both looks too good to be true, and seems dodgy, it probably is.</p>
<p>I don&#8217;t get why so many seem to whine over no HDMI and no microSD slot? It&#8217;s a $200 tablet for crying out loud and to complain is spec snobbery true to form. Google won&#8217;t placate to a spec snob&#8217;s desire to be a digital hoarder you know (sounds like an inevitable spin off of A&amp;E&#8217;s Hoarders, eh?). There&#8217;s no logical reason why someone would require a tablet to be capable of keeping an exhaustive local library of every jam, flick, pic and PDF he or she has ever come across. It&#8217;s looney, impractical and blatantly ignorant of the ginormous <em>cloud</em> that hangs over head.</p>
<p>Here&#8217;s a question for the spec snob: Since when did a tablet become the primary media center? As far as I know, it hasn&#8217;t, and it never will be. At most, it&#8217;s for watching short clips and occasionally a movie perhaps when you&#8217;re on a plane, train or bus. I know I like to watch &#8220;my stories&#8221; comfortably on a legit TV screen where it makes sense. If I need to get real work done, I have a pretty slick laptop in arms&#8217; reach (I&#8217;m sure not going to edit a PowerPoint on a 7-inch tablet through some hacky Polaris Office app).</p>
<p>I read once somewhere tablets are pretty much a sofa companion. Show of hands: anyone agree (my hand is up by the way)? It&#8217;s my Roku remote when I can&#8217;t find my actual Roku remote, it&#8217;s what I use to look up Shark Tank contestants in mid-episode so I can learn right then if they&#8217;re still kicking, and it&#8217;s much more to me. But to say I&#8217;m enjoying my tablet and not criticizing the very medium that doesn&#8217;t meet some asinine criteria would be an absolute true statement.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s time to enjoy what smarter people than us have created, dearest spec snob. Google Play, Spotify, Amazon and others have a cutesy, cartoony clouds for you to wiggle your stubby fingers through. Go on, try it! Feels good, right? Let them worry about your storage &#8212; don&#8217;t live in fear of &#8220;what if&#8221; scenarios for not getting to your goods. We have reliable vendors and reliable connections and eventually one or the other will go down, but it&#8217;s not the end of the world, and it&#8217;s time to make peace with the fact that nothing&#8217;s perfect &#8212; not even the tablet.</p>

<p>Wouldn&#8217;t those soft buttons eventually burn into the screen? I used to think LCD&#8217;s can&#8217;t get burn in but after reading my new TV&#8217;s manual, I guess its possible?</p>
<p>LCDs can&#8217;t get &#8220;burn in&#8221; by definition. What people refer to as &#8220;burn in&#8221; on LCD screens is when the pixels cannot return to their &#8220;relaxed&#8221; state. It&#8217;s present in every type of electronic device to some degree.</p>
<p>However, the screens on most devices are static enough that if burn in happened  frequently, you would hear about it all the time. It is very rare for an LCD screen to experience this problem before the screen itself just dies.</p>

<p>ELAN Microelectronics eKTF3624BWS – Controller for Resistive Touchscreen<br />
ELAN Microelectronics eKTH1036BWS – Controller for the Resistive Touchscreen</p>
<p>What is going on? Is this not a capacitative screen? The specs don&#8217;t actually say.</p>
<p>Might be a typo on their side, or some misunderstanding. Basically, resistive screens are soft (since you need to press the upper layer down to make contact with the lower one, to register touch) and allow no multi-touch. The Nexus 7&#8217;s screen is definitely capacitative.</p>
<p>Oh Jushua, shut up about the &#8220;no tablet apps&#8221; for pets sake!   There isn&#8217;t supposed to be! There is supposed to be ONE app which adapts (not that hard under Android) The Apple idea of having different apps is just a greed move to get people to pay more than once.</p>
<p>I think the point here is indeed that most apps currently don&#8217;t adapt/scale properly, because there was no effort to have an interface suited to larger screens. Twitter&#8217;s a good example.</p>
<p>Actually, I think the question of phone apps vs tablet apps is interesting. It&#8217;s accepted that general software may need to be bought twice to run on different platforms because of the extra dev involved. With the seemingly unified OSs of iOS and Android, there&#8217;s now one platform but markedly different screen sizes. That didn&#8217;t exist before, besides for websites (but you don&#8217;t pay for these).</p>
<p>So with these new OSs, it would appear the bulk of the work is on the interface, not on the bolts and gears. Does it justify paying twice for the app? Hardly, I would say. A mid-way solution could be to charge only an extra for the other version, once the first one&#8217;s been bought, to recognise this work.</p>
<p>Finally, there&#8217;s still the question of what you actually download to your device. Its screen size won&#8217;t change, so you may want to optimise, e.g. by not downloading the super high-res data on your phone. That&#8217;s what we do with mobile websites. Yes, I&#8217;m thinking iPhone/iPad here, with the app size blowup due to the new display. Blurring the line on Android with all screen ratios and sizes from 4&quot; all the way to 13&quot; doesn&#8217;t help either. But then this means there still isn&#8217;t one unique app, but several versions of it.</p>

<p>One mistake which a lot of people do is to compare the number of &#8216;tablet optimized&#8217; apps for iPad and Android tabs.</p>
<p>With a 7 inch tablet this problem is by far not as big as many would believe.</p>
<p>Most phone apps work fine on the nexus 7 AND the fact that android fits the phone app much better to the 7 inch size make the &#8216;problem&#8217; even less important.</p>
<p>Example: try a iphone app on an iPad, the results are horrible. If you scale the picture it&#8217;s extremely fuzzy, if not then you have a tiny window in the middle of the ipad screen. Both ways are terrible.</p>
<p>This doesn&#8217;t happen with android, as the app is automatically fit to the whole tablet screen without scaling low res graphics. This might result in smaller font size sometimes but overall the result is leaps and bounds better than iPhone apps on an iPad&#8230;</p>

<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanner_v._United_States" target="_blank">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanner_v._United_States</a></p>
<p><em>&#8217; The court noted that &#8220;the near-universal and firmly established common-law rule in the United States flatly prohibited the admission of juror testimony to impeach a jury verdict.&#8221;&#8217;</em></p>
<p>Even if the Foreman did misinform the jury (and there&#8217;s no evidence that he did) it wouldn&#8217;t help Samsung in the least.</p>
<p>The common law rule is not the Federal (or California) rule. There are still prohibitions on what jurors can discuss, but the quotation from Wikipedia is not the last word on whether or not the jury foreman&#8217;s actions were proper, because Federal Rules of Evidence (606 B 2 b) do allow testimony about whether  &#8220;an outside influence was improperly brought to bear &#8230;,&#8221; and it is possible that the foreman&#8217;s use of his knowledge of patents would be considered &#8220;outside influence.&#8221;</p>
<p>The jury foreman is on the jury &#8211; by definition he&#8217;s not an outside influence.</p>
<p><em>&#8216;An evidentiary hearing, including juror testimony on drug and alcohol use, was not required under petitioners&#8217; Sixth Amendment right to trial by a competent and unimpaired jury. <strong>That right is adequately protected by several aspects of the trial process, including voir dire, </strong>the fact that the preverdict conduct of jurors is observable by the court, by counsel, by court personnel, and by other jurors, and by the fact that, as here, the trial court may allow a post-trial evidentiary hearing to impeach the verdict by nonjuror evidence of juror misconduct.&#8217;<br />
</em></p>
<p>How does that not apply in this case?</p>
<p><a href="http://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/483/107/case.html" target="_blank">http://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/483/107/case.html</a></p>
<p>Tanner was about FRE 606.</p>
<p>This is the rule. Outside influences are things like bribery, extortion- classic jury tampering. It can also, on occasion, include other things (such as improper information brought to the jury from outside the jury). Do you know what it doesn&#8217;t include? People on the jury talking to each other.</p>

<p>There is no standards organization on user interface accept for maybe some standardized keyboard shortcuts by the WAI-ARIA standard from W3C for accessibility.  Because Apple never sought adoption of a standard for their patents then FRAND is out of the question.  That&#8217;s just not how FRAND works.  Apple wanted the nano-SIM standard to be as they proposed.  If Apple held patents pertaining to nano-SIM they would have had to offer them up as FRAND.  As it was, Apple offered FREE licenses to any patent they owned that may pertain to nano-SIM to refute claims that they were pushing their nano-SIM patent to get patent royalties.  Apple&#8217;s purpose for pushing the nano-SIM standard was to meet a production schedule for a device that used it (possibly the new iPhone).</p>

<p>There are FRAND patentes that are purely software, such as the FRAND patents on H.264.  The determinant for whether a patent is FRAND or not is whether the patent holder agreed to make it so in order for it to be included in an industry standard.</p>
<p>Industry standards are created when interoperation is more important than differentiation and competition.</p>
<p>That applies when you&#8217;re talking about making a device talk to its network, or a new video format.  It doesn&#8217;t apply to UI design &#8211; which is why nobody has ever sought to produce an industry standard for UIs.</p>
<p>No it&#8217;s not. Why even bother if you cannot profit from the R&amp;D, there isn&#8217;t any incentive and that is dangerous to innovation.</p>

<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Computer,_Inc._v._Microsoft_Corporation">From Wikipedia:  </a><em>&quot;Apple had agreed to license certain parts of its GUI to Microsoft for use in Windows 1.0, but when Microsoft made changes in Windows 2.0 adding overlapping windows and other features found in the Macintosh GUI, Apple filed suit. Apple added additional claims to the suit when Microsoft released Windows 3.0.</em></p>
<p>Apple claimed the &#8220;look and feel&#8221; of the Macintosh operating system, taken as a whole, was protected by copyright, and that each individual element of the interface (such as the existence of windows on the screen, the rectangular appearance of windows, windows could be resized, overlap, and have title bars) was not as important as all these elements taken together. After oral arguments, the court insisted on an analysis of specific GUI elements that Apple claimed were infringements. Apple listed 189 GUI elements; the court decided that 179 of these elements had been licensed to Microsoft in the Windows 1.0 agreement and most of the remaining 10 elements were not copyrightable—either they were unoriginal to Apple, or they were the only possible way of expressing a particular idea.&quot;</em></p>

<p>Wow. I think this is one of the first Nilay posts that I completely and totally agree with. Great article, Nilay! Thanks for the clarification on something that most people simply don&#8217;t understand, myself included (the nuances of Apple&#8217;s multi-touch patents). Though I think it just further goes to show how ridiculously hard it is to tell if you&#8217;re infringing a patent before you design and create a product. Certainly, the likes of big companies like Google, who have large pockets, can go through and analyze these patents in detail, but for smaller companies, digging into the nuances of these patents exhaustively will be tedious, difficult, and prohibitively expensive. Hence the reason why most smaller companies/start-ups simply ignore software patents.</p>
<p>Is Samsung a smaller company / Start-Up?</p>
<p>I&#8217;m not trying to defend Samsung or anyone else specifically here. Samsung is obviously a larger company among &#8220;the likes of big companies like Google&#8221;. I&#8217;m more musing about the deficiencies of the current patent system, specifically as relates to software patents. It&#8217;s ironic, in fact, that when we discuss the virtues of patents, we often talk about how they protect the innovations of the little guys against the larger corporate monsters like Samsung, Apple, Microsoft, and Google who are trying to steal said innovations. It&#8217;s ironic, because software patents are often too expensive to invest in for many smaller start-ups, and even if the money/resources were there to invest in them, the big guys simply have too many broad software patents for any small company to reasonably stand a chance. Furthermore, when designing a product, if they try to design around existing software patents, their task becomes intractable, as they have the daunting task of finding tens or hundreds of needles (individual patent claims) buried in thousands of haystacks (patents). It&#8217;s a huge investment and a colossal waste of money. There&#8217;s a good read on this over at Ars Technica: <a href="http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2012/03/opinion-the-problem-with-software-patents-they-dont-scale/" target="_blank">http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2012/03/opinion-the-problem-with-software-patents-they-dont-scale/</a></p>
<p>Appreciate the link. <br />
I think there should be some fund created from these lawsuit victories (a small %) to pay for those small start-ups legal defence on strong cases. Yes, I know the big, big companies can still dwarf their legal bills, but it might make some of those companies think twice and just pay a license (or buy the company for their IP)&#8230;</p>

<p>From Wikipedia for scrolling (yes, I know it&#8217;s not the bible but neither is Nilay): <br />
<blockquote>In computer displays, filmmaking, television production, and other kinetic displays, scrolling is sliding text, images or video across a monitor or display, often vertically. &#8220;Scrolling&#8221;, as such, does not change the layout of the text or pictures, but moves (pans or tilts) the user&#8217;s view across what is apparently a larger image that is not wholly seen.</blockquote></p>

<p>You&#8217;re right Nilay, this patent isn&#8217;t pinch to zoom&#8230; It pretty much covers all of multitouch, or at least Claim 8 does. Let&#8217;s look at the claim:<br />
 * A machine readable storage medium storing executable program instructions which when executed cause a data processing system to perform a method comprising:<br />
Which means basically: &#8220;A computer that has the following functionality:&#8221;<br />
  * receiving a user input, the user input is one or more input points applied to a touch-sensitive display that is integrated with the data processing system<br />
  (The computer has a multitouch screen)<br />
 * creating an event object in response to the user input;<br />
 (The computer notices touches as &#8220;event objects&#8221;. I&#8217;m not sure if the way around this is to use a prodedural language vs an object-oriented one.  Otherwise, this line seems to pretty much say nothing at all)<br />
 * Determining whether the event object invokes a scroll or gesture operation by distinguishing between a single input point applied to the touch-sensitive display that is interpreted as the scroll operation and two or more input points applied to the touch-sensitive display that are interpreted as the gesture operation<br />
 (the computer thinks of single finger gestures as &#8220;scrolls&#8221; and multiple finger gestures as &#8220;gestures&#8221;)<br />
 * issuing at least one scroll or gesture call based on invoking the scroll or gesture operation;<br />
 (internal implementation details. Once again, this says nothing, especially when given the points below)<br />
 * responding to at least one scroll call, if issued, by scrolling a window having a view associated with the event object; and<br />
 (scroll if the person did a (one-finger) scroll)<br />
 * responding to at least one gesture call, if issued, by scaling the view associated with the event object based on receiving the two or more input points in the form of the user input.<br />
 (do a gesture action if the person did a (multi-finger) gesture)</p>
<p>This seems to me that this claim would even cover two-finger scrolling. Am I wrong?</p>
<p>My interpretation is that &#8220;invokes a scroll or gesture operation&#8221; separates them out. They are discrete things that happen — one finger scrolls, multiple fingers perform gesture operations. The plain language indicates that they&#8217;re different.</p>
<p>More importantly, Google is on the record in this piece saying that Jelly Bean has software implementation designed around claim 8.</p>
<p>I suppose. I read it to mean that one finger scrolls, multiple fingers can perform a gesture that may include scrolling.  In any case, it&#8217;s a very broad claim: a device that will scroll when one finger is used and perform some sort of gesture when more fingers are used.</p>
<blockquote>More importantly, Google is on the record in this piece saying that Jelly Bean has software implementation designed around claim 8.</blockquote>

<p>Anyway, we&#8217;ll have to wait for the appeal, because the prior art really needs to be looked at again by someone who understands that it&#8217;s not just prior art if it runs on the same processor.</p>
<p>When you design a real-time system events must be mutable by nature &#8211; you can&#8217;t afford to sit around to see if it&#8217;s a single finger gesture or double finger gesture because system must respond within milliseconds and the users (when they want to do two-fingered gesture) won&#8217;t land the two fingers at exact same time for the system to determine which type of event it was. The only correct thing to do is to &#8220;assume&#8221; it was a scroll event when the first touch is registered and turn it into zoom event if second touch is registered within specified amount of time.</p>
<p>In other words &#8211; this patent describes the obvious to us programmers.</p>
<p>Well, this claim doesn&#8217;t really describe how the program determines what is a multiple finger gesture (aside from saying it&#8217;s &#8220;two or more inputs&#8221;). But I agree that this patent is obvious to programmers. Or at least to programmers who saw the Microsoft Surface or Minority Report.</p>
<p>Minority Report came out in 2002, I&#8217;m pretty sure FingerWorks was developing pinch-to-zoom before that.</p>
<p>But you can&#8217;t take Apple&#8217;s software and run it on the Minority Report processor.  Therefore prior art doesn&#8217;t apply.  This is the new standard for validating all prior art as established by the recent jury decision.</p>
<p>There&#8217;s nothing in the patent specific to the processor, there is only the idea.  And the idea, expressed in Minority Report (with pinch to zoom, no less) is prior art to Apple&#8217;s idea. It kills the &#8220;new&#8221; and &#8220;unobvious&#8221; part of their idea&#8217;s patentability.</p>

In his response to you above he says, &#8220;Try scrolling vertically on a page, and once the scroll starts, move your finger horizontally. It won’t pan because the scroll is locked.&#8221;</p>
<p>The simplest way of stating the difference between the platforms is that iOS will situationally lock your scrolling, Android does not at all.</p>
<p>(BTW- it will also lock horizontal scrolling. The &#8216;locking&#8217; occurs almost instantaneously in my experience, as long as you initially start scrolling in a near-horizontal or near-vertical manner.) The threshold is pretty big, trying it right now it seems around +/- 30 degrees to either side. On my 3GS I pretty much have to start scrolling immediately at 45 degrees to prevent the scroll locking (but it&#8217;s still not &#8220;all the time&#8221;.)</p>
<p>The point I&#8217;m making is that the claim states one finger scrolling, two finger gestures. Lock or no lock, one finger is still scrolling in iOS and Android. The fact that it is locked is irrelevant if you consider panning as scrolling.</p>
<p>The only way to avoid the claim is to consider that panning is NOT scrolling, which is not my interpretation. Scrolling considers all directions and is not defined by directional locks.</p>
<p>In fact, what iOS does or doesn&#8217;t is quite irrelevant.</p>

<p>One piece of information (although you&#8217;d have to dig further back than this) is this bit of testimony during the trial:</p>
<p>&#8220;Samsung pulled a similar trick when speaking to Karan Singh, a professor of computer science at the University of Toronto. Singh testified about the patents that cover the tap-to-zoom features and the ability to differentiate between single-finger scrolling and double-finger gestures. During cross-examination, Samsung&#8217;s attorney asked Singh if any Samsung devices could scroll using two fingers. Singh replied they did not.&#8221;</p>
<p><a href="http://www.theverge.com/2012/8/10/3233870/samsung-mislead-jury-apple-patent-experts-trial/in/2971889" target="_blank">http://www.theverge.com/2012/8/10/3233870/samsung-mislead-jury-apple-patent-experts-trial/in/2971889</a></p>
<p>I mean given all this, the only way the patent claims or any of this makes sense is if scrolling and panning are considered different. Because Apple is basically making a claim to the behavior that one finger means 1 behavior (which they say is &#8220;scrolling&#8221;), and 2-finger means a different behavior (which they call &#8220;gestures&#8221; which should include panning as 1 possible gesture.)</p>
<p>I am imagining that this distinction is actually covered in the background section in the Apple patent, and how they reference it there is how it is basically defined for the rest of the patent. If they have decent patent lawyers (how could they not?), they would clarify this for sure.</p>
<blockquote>I mean given all this, the only way the patent claims or any of this makes sense is if scrolling and panning are considered different. </blockquote>
<p>Not really. What the lawyers argued was that gestures &lt;&gt; scrolling. If the phone two finger scrolled which is different then gesture, then it wouldn&#8217;t be infringed.</p>
<p>I looked up patent 7844915 &#8220;Application programming interfaces for scrolling operations&#8221;. Indeed in the background section it states &#8220;Scrolling is the act of sliding a directional (e.g., horizontal or vertical) presentation of content&#8230;&#8221;</p>
<p>So reading between the lines here. Android has no such scrolling behavior at all, which does neatly sidestep claim 8 of this patent.</p>
<p>Samsung enhanced their phones by utilizing the scrolling behavior in the patent, and thus are dinged in court.</p>
<p>What they TRIED to claim is that their devices have BOTH 1-finger and 2-finger scrolling, but it (probably) doesn&#8217;t.</p>
