<blockquote>But don’t hate the reporting. Mobile Safari in iOS locks into a one-dimensional scroll all the time. </blockquote><br />
It doesn&#8217;t. You made me get my iPhone4S out of the box, and it panns, not one finger vertical lock. The problem is you must be using mobile sites, which have no horizontal scroll. On non-mobile sites I can clearly on finger multi-directional pan (see <a href="http://www.publico.pt" target="_blank">www.publico.pt</a> for example).</p>
<p>Hope now you will see that I don&#8217;t really hate you, I just hate bad reporting.</p>
<p>Yes- it can lock you into one-dimensional scroll, but not all the time. It&#8217;s situational. Whereas Google NEVER locks you into one-dimensional scroll.</p>
<p>That being said, it may still be a very valid example of Google designing around an Apple patent.</p>
<blockquote>Yes- it can lock you into one-dimensional scroll, but not all the time. It’s situational.</blockquote>
<p>If it&#8217;s situational then the patent shouldn&#8217;t be infringed. If the scroll only locks after a second, and you consider that panning is not scrolling, then you get  one-finger panning today instead of the one-finger scroll with the claim states.</p>
<p>The point &#8220;it never locks&#8221; shouldn&#8217;t matter since there are situations where you get a one-finger pan.</p>
<p>Actually, I believe Nilay is correct but was not clear.</p>
<p>The Apple implementation will lock you to directional scrolling if that&#8217;s how you start (it&#8217;s basically anticipating that you are scrolling say up or down a page of text and don&#8217;t want to move side to side.) If you tap and start scrolling diagonally, it will let you do that.</p>
<p>Nilay says that Android gets around an Apple patent on this by not limiting scrolling direction AT ALL. That&#8217;s the distinction.</p>
<blockquote>Nilay says that Android gets around an Apple patent on this by not limiting scrolling direction AT ALL. That’s the distinction.</blockquote>
<p>But the claim says nothing about the limitation of scroll direction. That&#8217;s my point. <br />
Even if you don&#8217;t lock, it&#8217;s still scrolling.</p>
<p>I bet the key is the difference between scrolling (unidirectional) and panning (bidirectional). If Android always pans, then there is no scroll operation.</p>
<p>There are several definitions on the web for scrolling. For example this one does not constrain scroll to vertical or horizontal <a href="http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/scroll" target="_blank">http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/scroll</a> or this one <a href="http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/scroll" target="_blank">http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/scroll</a></p>
<p>According to these definitions, it doesn&#8217;t matter if the scrolling is diagonal. It&#8217;s still scrolling. There are other definitions which only talk about vertical and horizontal.</p>
<p>From the Oxford dictionary you linked to<br />
<blockquote>move displayed text or graphics in a particular direction on a computer screen in order to view different parts of them:</blockquote></p>
<p>The &#8220;in a particular direction&#8221; means unidirectional, rather than bidirectional. The other definition says move &#8220;across&#8221;, which seems like a single direction.</p>
<p>So the possible scenario here is that scrolling means any sort of locking, regardless of direction. It just so happens that Apple does up/down and left/right.</p>
<p>Or no lock whatsoever. When you pan you are actually moving the screen in finite unidirectional segments. I know this seems like lawyer talk, but formalism aside, I actually think that moving the screen is scrolling.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s up to the courts (again) my friends.</p>
<p>It&#8217;s all about interpretation.</p>
<p>Here&#8217;s one more tidbit from the Apple patent:<br />
&#8220;At least certain embodiments of the presnt disclosure include scrolling operations for scrolling a display of a device. The scrolling operations include bouncing a scrolled region&#8230;, rubber banding a scrolled region&#8230;, and setting a scrolling angle that locks the scroll in a horizontal or vertical direction.&#8221;</p>
<p>I said previously I am wasting time on this, but actually this is enlightening in terms of studying patents (which I am involved in from time to time.)</p>
<blockquote>and setting a scrolling angle that locks the scroll in a horizontal or vertical direction</blockquote>
<p>So if it &#8220;locks on one of those directions&#8221; then it means that any other direction would still be a scroll ;) If it hasn&#8217;t so, they would just say &#8220;lock into a scroll&#8221;, the vertical/horizontal wouldn&#8217;t be necessary.</p>
<p>Yes, you&#8217;re right. But its that very act of &#8216;locking&#8217; which is relevant and characteristic of a scroll, not whether it&#8217;s horizontal or vertical. It just so happens that those are the directions that are useful, and thus are how Apple and apparently Samsung implemented locking (and therefore &#8216;scrolling&#8217;) in their devices.</p>
<p>And I&#8217;m not mad at all, it&#8217;s nice to discuss the actual patents in a patent case, not all the other sideshow stuff.</p>
<blockquote>But its that very act of ‘locking’ which is relevant and characteristic of a scroll,</blockquote>
<p>Don&#8217;t know about that. And for the record, Samsung implementation of the lock is pretty lame.</p>

<p>Is it really locking, or is it simply not capable of discriminating between very small differences in angle? I think I do see what you mean, but the software may not actually be trying to lock.</p>

<p>With two fingers it&#8217;s complicated since it starts to zoom. It&#8217;s inconclusive :)</p>
<p>Even if their implementation is crappy, it can still infringe upon the patent. Although that&#8217;s more a reason to just not have it&#8230;</p>
<p>Two-finger &#8216;non-scrolling&#8217; seems to bear out in actuality in iOS. If you use 2 fingers on a web page, you never get scroll locking. Whereas with one-finger, you get scroll locking if you start by moving up/down or left/right. I think Apple filed this patent, and then later refined the actual iOS behavior to only selectively apply scroll locking to one-finger behavior. But that it discriminates at all is the critical issue of that particular part of claim 8.</p>
<p>I don&#8217;t think Nilay&#8217;s article is pro-Apple or pro-Samsung. If anything, it splashed water on the opinion pieces that Apple has cornered the market on anything. The easy way out of the patent is pretty clearly explained here, it seems Samsung wanted to have their cake and eat it too. Although I like scrolling (locking), not having it is not that big of a deal and really not worth copying and risking a patent infringement.</p>

<p>Patents are much more complex and detailed (in diferent ways, but design patents are also explicit). The problem is most people then even interpret the article, and commented like this was some sort of &#8220;Apple&#8217;s patent is invalid&#8221; story.</p>

You&#8217;re right- the actual iOS implentation is different. <p>Okay, correct me if I&#8217;m wrong. But the gist of what Nilay is saying:</p>
<p>1. There&#8217;s a lot of misinformation in the press about these patents.<br />
2. The jury ruled that 21 of 24 accused Samsung phones infringed claim 8 of Apple patent 7,844,915<br />
3. It&#8217;s actually pretty easy to design around claim 8 of Apple patent 7,844,915, as well as other Apple patents.<br />
4. Samsung tried to show their accused devices scrolling with two fingers on the screen. Two finger scrolling is beyond the claims of the &#8216;915 patent, so any device that implements it likely doesn&#8217;t infringe.</p>
<p>So the 21 out of 24 Samsung devices- I guess they DO feature 2-finger scrolling? Or don&#8217;t they?</p>
<p>If they do, then the title (and thrust) of the article should not be &#8220;how a confused media gave Apple something it doesn&#8217;t own&#8221;, it should be &#8220;how a confused jury gave Apple something it doesn&#8217;t own.&#8221; How it is being misinterpreted in the press is much less relevant than how the jury interprets or misinterprets the patent (and whether Samsung did design around it.)</p>
<p>There&#8217;s also the trade dress issue, they could&#8217;ve still lost on that. But just trying to be sure about this patent.</p>
<p>Okay, reading the link Nilay posted about Samsung &#8220;trying to show&#8221; their accused devices scrolling with two fingers on the screen:<br />
<a href="http://www.theverge.com/2012/8/10/3233870/samsung-mislead-jury-apple-patent-experts-trial/in/2971889" target="_blank">http://www.theverge.com/2012/8/10/3233870/samsung-mislead-jury-apple-patent-experts-trial/in/2971889</a><br />
The article basically says Samsung failed in their attempt, as the video testimony actually showed pinch and zoom and not 2-finger scrolling. So either these 21 Samsung devices don&#8217;t feature 2-finger scrolling (and thus possibly infringes upon Patent 7,844,915), or Samsung really flat out screwed up big time.<br />
According to the testimony of Karan Singh, a professor of computer science at the University of Toronto, the Samsung devices do NOT have 2-finger scrolling. Can someone pull out a Galaxy 1 (or any of the 21 infringing devices) and confirm this?</p>
<p>I would say the article title should be:</p>
<p>&#8220;How a confused pack of Apple-haters wrongly concluded that the jury gave Apple something Apple never claimed to own.&#8221;</p>
<p>A good analogy is that while tire-makers do not patent the roundness of their tires, they DO all patent their tread designs. And those patents are upheld and enforced with respect to the way they make their tire grip the road under various surface and weather conditions.</p>
<p>Apple had a perfect right to patent the code by which THEY implement pinch-to-zoom. Let others implement it in their own way, and also choose they own look and feel without copying Apple&#8217;s look.</p>
<p>Well, they did. Samsung did NOT copy Apple&#8217;s code, they just solved some problems that Apple also solved. So single-touch and multi-touch gestures cannot be patented, but an interface with both single and multi-touch gestures (which, of course entails some system of discriminating between the two) is somehow a great innovation that should be protected? &#8220;Pull the other one&#8221;, as they say.</p>
<p>PEOPLE OF THE INTERNET- Apple does NOT have a patent on MULTITOUCH- THAT IS IN FACT THE EXACT POINT NILAY IS MAKING HERE. Apple&#8217;s patent covers certain ASPECTS of THEIR IMPLEMENTATION of a multitouch screen, the relevant one here being the interface discriminating between single touch and multi touch, and assigning different responses to each.</p>
<p>Even Google states it as such (again RTFA): <blockquote>according to a Google spokesperson, &#8220;Apple&#8217;s &#8217;915 patent claims a very specific software implementation, and the implementation is different in Jelly Bean.&#8221;</blockquote></p>
<p>Whether you think Apple&#8217;s specific claims are valid or patentable is a different issue. But please, no more photos of multitouch screens of the 60&#8217;s and 70&#8217;s.</p>

<p>&#8220;patents are hard for non-lawyers to read and understand, and it&#8217;s far easier to use a shorthand that obscures important details. &quot;</p>
<p>This is the most salient point i&#8217;ve read regarding intellectual property law on a tech blog. Tech blogs are innundated with bad information when it comes to copyright law, trademark law, and patent law, both in the articles and even worse the comment section. People not only don&#8217;t know the law but don&#8217;t know the foundation of the law and with respect to patents have not come close to reading the patents in sufficient detail to make competent evaluations. On top of that most people, technical or not simply don&#8217;t understand the specifics of the tech that is the topic of the intellectual property law. It&#8217;s much easier to make incorrect statements. Most of the comment readers lack the legal foundation anyways to vet the miss-statements. It&#8217;s even worse when it involves something people are passionate and utterly biased for or against, like iphones, palm devices, the XBox, mp3. Read a webos forum and they&#8217;ll have you believe that they have patent that prevents anyone from making a phone without their permission. Many people think they can use any piece of music of image in their film so long as it&#8217;s not for profit. Another massive misunderstanding of copyright law. Many people incorrectly understand when fair use applies and use it as a catch all. Now granted it&#8217;s not black and white but it&#8217;s also not all encompassing. And with patent law, the most complicated discipline in IP law, requiring admission to it&#8217;s own bar, and a complex understanding of the underlying topic of the layman is simply not properly equipped to comment in the most competent manner on most issues. Now they could inform themselves and do the work but that&#8217;s hard work and consumers time. as the quote says &#8220;it&#8217;s hard.&#8221; So when you read a blog, and i&#8217;ll excuse this post cause it&#8217;s pretty on point., you should be very wary. Ask yourself are there any details? Are they looking at patent specifics? Are they familiar with the the specifics of the claims in the case? Usually that stuff is ignored, glossed over, not read or someone they just read someone else&#8217;s statments an stole them. Many tech posts are just reposts of something they read on foss patents.</p>

<p>Firstly, most GSM carriers in India don&#8217;t offer Unlimited 3G data plans (Although, 2G unlimited data plans are quite commonplace). Only CDMA/EVDO carriers (Like MTS, Tata DoCoMo and Reliance) have unlimited broadband data plans on their tariff-sheets. And even those carriers don&#8217;t offer truly-unlimited data. For instance, MTS&#8217;s top-tier EVDO plan costs Rs.1298 (Approx. $30) and bundles &#8220;15GB Unlimited Data&#8221;. What that entails is that after a user surpasses the 15GB mark on his connection he will be throttled to CDMA 1x Speeds. This is to ensure nobody hogs bandwidth, I guess.</p>

<p>win</p>
<p><img src="https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-q15uIk36jKw/TXGXpffkQmI/AAAAAAAAApA/jMdMNXPSU6E/cats+winning.jpg" /></p>
<p>Maybe next year at Google IO they will have promises to get devices (launched in the last 18 months) with updates the same day as the Nexuses.</p>
<p>They can&#8217;t make promises like that, which is why tools like the PDK are important. Software updates for non-nexus devices are entirely out of Google&#8217;s hands. The PDK is intended to put the ball into manufacturer&#8217;s courts.</p>
<p>Wonder if this initiative will disappear into the ether thanks to lazy OEMs and carriers, like the vaunted update alliance</p>
<p>This is different. That update alliance relied upon everyone in it to keep their word. With this PDK, Google develops and releases it. That&#8217;s it. That&#8217;s the only commitment being made here. It&#8217;s up to everyone else to take advantage of it. This is also being done to improve relationships with OEM&#8217;s and to attract interest from players not yet tapped.</p>
<p>A few examples:</p>
<p>AMD &#8211; They could show off an APU designed for tablets while showing how much performance it has with the latest hotness. A great way to try to grab some more revenue for themselves.</p>
<p>HTC &#8211; They throw their phones everywhere and compete very fiercely on hardware but their thunder gets stolen quite a bit. They can gain much more traction if they (or any OEM really) can move quickly enough to bring their latest flagship device to market with the next OS and their own customizations.</p>
<p>HP &#8211; They were originally going to ship WebOS on PC&#8217;s but gave up. Why not ship hybrid Windows 8/Android X.X laptops? It could be a major differentiator in the x86 market if they had a laptop/tablet that could gain extra attention by providing a beefier version of your cell phone experience.</p>
<p>I could keep going on, this is such an awesome way to try to calm fears about owning Motorola. They&#8217;ve made significant commitments to their OEM&#8217;s and anyone else interested in the platform, all that needs to happen is to have Google follow through on it.</p>
<p>That&#8217;s my point, it&#8217;s up to everyone else to take advantage of it, the same situation we have today with the timescales shifted around a bit. Anybody who thinks this will result in future visions of android penetrating the market faster is likely mistaken.</p>
<p>A handful of flagships will get an update or two, before they are replaced by next years model and largely forgotten. The unwashed masses of handsets won&#8217;t get jack, ever.</p>
<p>The initiative itself is just Google committing to releasing this Platform Development Kit. They didn&#8217;t make an announcement that rivaled the false support promise of the Update Alliance. All that was announced here is that Google is giving better support to OEM&#8217;s at a significantly earlier time. I don&#8217;t believe that they&#8217;ll just stop providing the PDK after 1 or two years. It may eventually become engrained into too many company&#8217;s business plans.</p>
<p>this can&#8217;t disappear this just means they give info earlier&#8230;</p>
<p>Will this go the way of the fabled update alliance, time will tell.</p>
<p>I wonder if this is going to lead to more leaks of future versions of Android.</p>

<p>&#8220;<em>Nexae</em>&#8221;? Get your Latin plurals right. &#8220;Nexus&#8221; is a 4th declension noun, so then the plural is <em>Nexus</em>, same as the singular. Had it been 1st declension, with which more people are familiar, it would get the standard &#8220;<em>Nexus, Nexi</em>&#8221; treatment.</p>
<p>Or you can use the English pluralization, <em>Nexuses</em>. But there&#8217;s no way it can ever be <em>Nexae</em>.</p>
<p>The people who try to use incorrect plurals here are probably the same that try to put Latin pluralization on Greek words.  So I&#8217;ll say <em>Nexodes</em> as a sort of linguistic revenge for <em>octopi.</em></p>
<p>It should be octopodes, correct?</p>
<p>Octopuses is, I believe, the preferred pluralization.  Octopi, like Nexae, is a pedantic overcorrection.  Also, like those words, it&#8217;s not correct since it&#8217;s an loan word based on older roots.  Loan words can wear the plurals of their adopted languages just fine.</p>

It&#8217;s identical to stock Jelly Bean on a GSM Galaxy Nexus, no tweaks just pure 4.1.  You even get native tethering and wallet support.  If you&#8217;re planning on rooting and want a stock experience, I&#8217;d recommend it.</p>
